SeqA: Exercise-Associated Muscle Cramps (EAMC) are a common painful condition of muscle spasms.
SeqB: Exercise-Associated Muscle Cramps (EAMC) are a common type of muscle spasm, in which a muscle continually contracts without intention, causing pain.

SeqA: Despite scientists tried to understand the physiological mechanism that underlies these common phenomena, the etiology is still unclear.
SeqB: Scientists have tried to explain why these cramps happen, but have not been able to.

SeqA: From 1900 to nowadays, the scientific world retracted several times the original hypothesis of heat cramps.
SeqB: An idea commonly returned to throughout the years is that EAMCs may be caused by heat.

SeqA: However, recent literature seems to focus on two potential mechanisms: the dehydration or electrolyte depletion mechanism, and the neuromuscular mechanism.
SeqB: Recently, though, more likely explanations are thought to include dehydration, lack of electrolytes, or issues with the nerves connecting to the muscles.

SeqA: The aim of this review is to examine the recent literature, in terms of physiological mechanisms of EAMC.
SeqB: The aim of this review is to look at recent research into how and why EAMCs happen.

SeqA: A comprehensive search was conducted on PubMed and Google Scholar.
SeqB: We searched common online resources for papers.

SeqA: The following terminology was applied: muscle cramps, neuromuscular hypothesis (or thesis), dehydration hypothesis, Exercise-Associated muscle cramps, nocturnal cramps, muscle spasm, muscle fatigue.
SeqB: For search terms, we used: muscle cramps, neuromuscular hypothesis (or thesis), dehydration hypothesis, Exercise-Associated muscle cramps, nocturnal cramps, muscle spasm, muscle fatigue.

SeqA: From the initial literature of 424 manuscripts, sixty-nine manuscripts were included, analyzed, compared and summarized.
SeqB: The search returned 424 papers.

SeqA: Literature analysis indicates that neuromuscular hypothesis may prevails over the initial hypothesis of the dehydration as the trigger event of muscle cramps.
SeqB: We read and analyzed 69 of them.

SeqA: New evidence suggests that the action potentials during a muscle cramp are generated in the motoneuron soma, likely accompanied by an imbalance between the rising excitatory drive from the muscle spindles (Ia) and the decreasing inhibitory drive from the Golgi tendon organs.
SeqB: From the latest evidence, interactions of nerves with muscles explains muscle cramps better than dehydration.

SeqA: In conclusion, from the latest investigations there seem to be a spinal involvement rather than a peripheral excitation of the motoneurons.
SeqB: Muscle contraction is normally balanced by special cells in the muscles that sense how stretched or contracted the muscles are.

SeqA: Background: Muscle cramp is a painful, involuntary muscle contraction, and that occurs during or following exercise is referred to as exercise-associated muscle cramp (EAMC).
SeqB: Muscle cramps are unconscious contractions of muscles that are painful.

SeqA: The causes of EAMC are likely to be multifactorial, but dehydration and electrolytes deficits are considered to be factors.
SeqB: When they happen during or after excercise, they are called Exercise-Associated Muscle Cramps (EAMC).

SeqA: This study tested the hypothesis that post-exercise muscle cramp susceptibility would be increased with spring water ingestion, but reduced with oral rehydration solution (ORS) ingestion during exercise.
SeqB: There are probably many causes of EAMC, but dehydration and lack of electrolytes (mineral salts dissolved in the blood) are thought to play roles.

SeqA: Methods: Ten men performed downhill running (DHR) in the heat (35-36 ??C) for 40-60 min to reduce 1.5-2% of their body mass in two conditions (spring water vs ORS) in a cross-over design.
SeqB: This study tested whether drinking a special drink called Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS) while exercising made Exercise-Associated Muscle Cramps less likely than drinking spring water.

SeqA: The body mass was measured at 20 min and every 10 min thereafter during DHR, and 30 min post-DHR.
SeqB: Ten men ran downhill in hot conditions for 40-60 minutes, drinking either spring water or ORS.

SeqA: The participants ingested either spring water or ORS for the body mass loss in each period.
SeqB: Their weights were measured 20 minutes into the exercise, then every 10 minutes, and then 30 minutes after the exercise was completed.

SeqA: The two conditions were counter-balanced among the participants and separated by a week.
SeqB: After each measurement, the men drank enough of either the spring water or ORS to make up for the weight they lost.

SeqA: Calf muscle cramp susceptibility was assessed by a threshold frequency (TF) of an electrical train stimulation to induce cramp before, immediately after, 30 and 65 min post-DHR.
SeqB: We did the experiment twice, a week apart, so that each person tried both drinks.

SeqA: Blood samples were taken before, immediately after and 65 min after DHR to measure serum sodium, potassium, magnesium and chroride concentrations, hematocrit (Hct), hemoglobin (Hb), and serum osmolarity.
SeqB: We balanced which order they tried the drinks in.

SeqA: Changes in these varaibles over time were compared between conditions by two-way repeated measures of analysis of variance.
SeqB: Muscle cramps were easier to induce in participants who had drunk spring water than in participants who had drunk ORS.

SeqA: Muscle cramp is a temporary but intense and painful involuntary contraction of skeletal muscle that can occur in many different situations.
SeqB: Muscle cramp is a temporary but intense, painful, uncontrollable muscle contraction that can occur for different reasons.

SeqA: The causes of, and cures for, the cramps that occur during or soon after exercise remain uncertain, although there is evidence that some cases may be associated with disturbances of water and salt balance, while others appear to involve sustained abnormal spinal reflex activity secondary to fatigue of the affected muscles.
SeqB: The causes of and cures for exercise-related cramps remain unknown.

SeqA: Evidence in favour of a role for dyshydration comes largely from medical records obtained in large industrial settings, although it is supported by one large-scale intervention trial and by field trials involving small numbers of athletes.
SeqB: However, some cases may be linked with disturbances of water and salt balance, while others may be from constant abnormal spinal reflex activity linked to fatigue of the affected muscles.

SeqA: Cramp is notoriously unpredictable, making laboratory studies difficult, but experimental models involving electrical stimulation or intense voluntary contractions of small muscles held in a shortened position can induce cramp in many, although not all, individuals.
SeqB: Evidence of lack of water comes largely from medical records from large industrial settings.

SeqA: These studies show that dehydration has no effect on the stimulation frequency required to initiate cramping and confirm a role for spinal pathways, but their relevance to the spontaneous cramps that occur during exercise is questionable.
SeqB: However, it is also supported by one large treatment trial and trials with small groups of athletes.

SeqA: There is a long history of folk remedies for treatment or prevention of cramps; some may reduce the likelihood of some forms of cramping and reduce its intensity and duration, but none are consistently effective.
SeqB: Cramp is very unpredictable, making lab studies difficult, but experiments with electrical stimulation or intense voluntary contractions of small muscles held in a shortened position can cause cramp in many, but not all, individuals.

SeqA: It seems likely that there are different types of cramp that are initiated by different mechanisms; if this is the case, the search for a single strategy for prevention or treatment is unlikely to succeed.
SeqB: These studies show that dehydration does no affect the stimulation amount needed to start cramping and confirm a role for spinal pathways, but their link to the spontaneous exercise-related cramps that occur is questionable.

SeqA: Muscular cramp is a common symptom in healthy people, especially among the elderly and in young people after vigorous or peak exercise.

SeqA: The dystonias are a group of disorders characterized by excessive involuntary muscle contractions leading to abnormal postures and/or repetitive movements.

SeqB: Checking the symptoms can help identify patterns that focus identification testing on possible causes.

SeqB: Treatment includes counseling, education, oral medications, botox (used as a muscle relaxant), and surgeries.

SeqB: A noticeable decrease in symptoms and improved quality of life is achieved in most patients by combining these options.

SeqA: Muscle cramps are a common problem characterized by a sudden, painful, involuntary contraction of muscle.
SeqB: Muscle cramps are a common problem represented by sudden, painful, involuntary muscle contractions.

SeqA: Dystonia is a complex neurological movement disorder characterized by involuntary muscle contractions.
SeqB: Dystonia is a complicated brain-related movement disorder with uncontrollable muscle contractions.

SeqA: Increasing studies implicate the microbiome as a possible key susceptibility factor for neurological disorders, but the relationship between the gut microbiota and dystonia remains poorly explored.
SeqB: Many studies imply microorganisms inside us as a possible factor for brain-related disorders, but the link between the gut microorganisms (microbiota) and dystonia remains poorly explored.

SeqA: Here, the gut microbiota of 57 patients with isolated dystonia and 27 age- and environment-matched healthy controls was analyzed by 16S rRNA gene amplicon sequencing.
SeqB: Here, the gut microbiota of 57 patients with dystonia and 27 age- and environment-matched healthy patients was analyzed by 16S DNA sequencing.

SeqA: Further, integrative analysis of the gut microbiome and serum metabolome measured by high-performance liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry was performed.
SeqB: Further, we analyzed the gut microbiome and molecules in the blood.

SeqA: No difference in ??-diversity was found, while ??-diversity was significantly different, with a more heterogeneous community structure among dystonia patients than among controls.
SeqB: No change in some gut-diversity was found, while other gut-diversity was very different, with a more diverse community among dystonia patients than among healthy patients (controls).

SeqA: The most significant changes in dystonia highlighted an increase in Clostridiales, including Blautia obeum, Dorea longicatena, and Eubacterium hallii, and a reduction in Bacteroides vulgatus and Bacteroides plebeius.
SeqB: The most different change in dystonia showed an increase in certain types of microorganisms labeled Clostridiales, including Blautia obeum, Dorea longicatena, and Eubacterium hallii, and a reduction in other microorganisms labeled Bacteroides vulgatus and Bacteroides plebeius.

SeqA: The functional analysis revealed that genes related to tryptophan and purine biosynthesis were more abundant in gut microbiota from patients with dystonia, while genes linked to citrate cycle, vitamin B6, and glycan metabolism were less abundant.
SeqB: The analysis showed that genes related to the molecules tryptophan and purine creation were more abundant in gut microbiota from patients with dystonia, while genes linked to energy cycles, vitamin B6, and glycan (a specific sugar) breakdown were less abundant.

SeqA: The evaluation of serum metabolites revealed altered levels of l-glutamic acid, taurine, and d-tyrosine, suggesting changes in neurotransmitter metabolism.
SeqB: Analyzing blood molecules revealed changed levels of molecules called l-glutamic acid, taurine, and d-tyrosine, suggesting changes in brain signaling molecule metabolism.

SeqA: The most modified metabolites strongly inversely correlated with the abundance of members belonging to the Clostridiales, revealing the effect of the gut microbiota on neurometabolic activity.
SeqB: The most modified molecules decreased with the abundance of microorganism members belonging to the Clostridiales, revealing the effect of the gut microbiota on brain molecule activity.

SeqA: This study is the first to reveal gut microbial dysbiosis in patients with isolated dystonia and identified potential links between gut microbiota and serum neurotransmitters, providing new insight into the pathogenesis of isolated dystonia.
SeqB: This study is the first to show gut microbial differences in patients with dystonia and found possible links between gut microbiota and blood brain signaling molecules, providing new insight into the causes of dystonia.

SeqA: IMPORTANCE Dystonia is the third most common movement disorder after essential tremor and Parkinson's disease.
SeqB: IMPORTANCE Dystonia is the third most common movement disorder after tremors and Parkinson's disease (a brain disorder affecting movement).

SeqA: However, the cause for the majority of cases is not known.
SeqB: However, the cause for many cases is not known.

SeqA: This is the first study so far that reveals significant alterations of gut microbiome and correlates the alteration of serum metabolites with gut dysbiosis in patients with isolated dystonia.

SeqA: We demonstrated a general overrepresentation of Clostridiales and underrepresentation of Bacteroidetes in patients with dystonia in comparison with healthy controls.
SeqB: We show a general overrepresentation of Clostridiales and underrepresentation of Bacteroidetes in patients with dystonia compared to healthy controls.

SeqA: The functional analysis found that genes related to the biosynthesis of tryptophan, which is the precursor of the neurotransmitter serotonin, were more active in isolated dystonia patients.

SeqA: Altered levels of several serum metabolites were found to be associated with microbial changes, such as d-tyrosine, taurine, and glutamate, indicating differences in neurotransmitter metabolism in isolated dystonia.

SeqA: The gut microbiome changes provide new insight into the pathogenesis of dystonia, suggesting new potential therapeutic directions.

SeqA: Dystonia is a neurological condition characterized by abnormal involuntary movements or postures owing to sustained or intermittent muscle contractions.

SeqA: Dystonia can be the manifesting neurological sign of many disorders, either in isolation (isolated dystonia) or with additional signs (combined dystonia).

SeqA: Hyperkalemia is a frequent clinical abnormality in patients with chronic kidney disease, and it is associated with higher risk of mortality and malignant arrhythmias.

SeqA: Severe hyperkalemia is a medical emergency, which requires immediate therapies, followed by interventions aimed at preventing its recurrence.

SeqA: Current treatment paradigms for chronic hyperkalemia management are focused on eliminating predisposing factors, such as high potassium intake in diets or supplements, and the use of medications known to raise potassium level.

SeqA: Among the latter, inhibitors of the renin-angiotensin aldosterone system are some of the most commonly involved medications, and their discontinuation is often the first step taken by clinicians to prevent the recurrence of hyperkalemia.

SeqA: The International Expert Committee recommends that the diagnosis of diabetes be made if hemo globin A1c (HbA1c) level is greater, similar 6.5% and confirmed with a repeat HbA1c test.

SeqA: Fasting plasma glucose, 2-hour postglucose-load plasma glucose, and oral glucose tolerance tests are recommended for the diagnosis of diabetes only if HbA1c testing is not possible due to unavailability of the assay, patient factors that preclude its inter pretation, and during pregnancy.

SeqA: HbA1c testing has the advantages of greater clinical convenience, preanalytic stability, and assay standardization, but when used as the sole diagnostic criterion for diabetes, it has the potential for systematic error.
SeqB: HbA1c testing is useful for greater convenience, accuracy, and uniformity, but as the single tool for identification, it may lead to measurement errors.

SeqA: Factors that may not be clinically evident impact HbA1c test results and may systematically raise or lower the value relative to the true level of glycemia.

SeqA: For this reason, HbA1c should be used in combination with plasma glucose determinations for the diagnosis of diabetes.

SeqA: If an HbA1c test result is discordant with the clinical picture or equivocal, plasma glucose testing should be performed.

SeqA: Highly sensitive and specific radioimmunoassays have been validated for autoantibodies reacting with the four major autoantigens identified so far in autoimmune diabetes.

SeqA: Intake levels vary across the world owing largely to differences in soil content and factors affecting its bioavailability to plants.

SeqA: Adverse health effects have been observed at both extremes of intake, with a narrow optimum range.

SeqA: The aim of this study was to investigate the effect of vitamin D on circulating thyroid autoantibodies and thyroid hormones profile (T4, T3, and TSH) in females with HT.

SeqA: Forty-two women with HT disease were enrolled in this randomized clinical trial study and divided into vitamin D and placebo groups.
SeqB: We split 42 women with HT disease into two groups and gave one group vitamin D and the other group sham treatment.

SeqA: Patients in the vitamin D and placebo groups received 50 000 IU vitamin D and placebo pearls, weekly for 3 months, respectively.
SeqB: We gave one group 50,000 international units of vitamin D and the other group sugar pills for 3 months.

SeqA: The serum levels of 25-hydroxy vitamin D [25(OH) D], Ca++ion, anti-thyroperoxidase antibody (anti-TPO Ab), anti-thyroglobulin antibody (anti-Tg Ab), T4, T3, and TSH were measured at the baseline and at the end of the study using enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays.
SeqB: We measured blood levels of thyroid autoantibodies and thyroid hormones (T4, T3, and thyroid-stimulating hormone) at the beginning and end of the study using a common antibody-measuring tool.

SeqA: The results of this study showed a significant reduction of anti-Tg Ab and TSH hormone in the Vitamin D group compared to the start of the study; however, there was a no significant reduction of anti-TPO Ab in the Vitamin D group compared to the placebo group (p=0.08).
SeqB: Blood levels of one antibody and thyroid-stimulating hormone were lower at the end of the study in the group taking vitamin D.

SeqA: No significant changes were observed in the serum levels of T3 and T4 hormones.
SeqB: The group taking vitamin D and the group taking sugar pills had similar blood levels of another antibody.

SeqA: Therefore, vitamin D supplementation can be helpful for alleviation of the disease activity in HT patients; however, further well controlled, large, longitudinal studies are needed to determine whether it can be introduced in clinical practice.

SeqA: Background: Hashimoto's thyroiditis is an autoimmune disorder and the most common cause of hypothyroidism.
SeqB: Hashimoto's thyroiditis is caused by thyroid cells that are attacked by infection-preventing cells and is the most common cause of an underactive thyroid.

SeqA: The use of Nigella sativa, a potent herbal medicine, continues to increase worldwide as an alternative treatment of several chronic diseases including hyperlipidemia, hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
SeqB: More people around the world are taking Nigella sativa, a powerful herbal medicine, as a nontraditional way to treat many long-term diseases including high cholesterol, high blood pressure and type 2 diabetes.

SeqA: The aim of the current study was to evaluate the effects of Nigella sativa on thyroid function, serum Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor (VEGF) - 1, Nesfatin-1 and anthropometric features in patients with Hashimoto's thyroiditis.
SeqB: The current study aimed to rate the effects of Nigella sativa on how well the thyroid is working, blood Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor (VEGF) - 1 (a protein that promotes new blood vessels), Nesfatin-1 (a chain of amino acids that affects hunger) and physical body measurements in people with Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

SeqA: Methods: Forty patients with Hashimoto's thyroiditis, aged between 22 and 50 years old, participated in the trial and were randomly allocated into two groups of intervention and control receiving powdered Nigella sativa or placebo daily for 8 weeks.
SeqB: We randomly split forty people with Hashimoto's thyroiditis and between 22 and 50 years old into two group and gave one group powdered Nigella sativa and the other group sham treatment for 8 weeks.

SeqA: Changes in anthropometric variables, dietary intakes, thyroid status, serum VEGF and Nesfatin-1 concentrations after 8 weeks were measured.
SeqB: We measured changes in physical body measurements, what people ate, thyroid function, blood VEGF and Nefastin-1 levels after 8 weeks.

SeqA: Results:
SeqB: Taking Nigella sativa caused lower body weight and body mass index (BMI).

SeqA: Treatment with Nigella sativa significantly reduced body weight and body mass index (BMI).
SeqB: People taking Nigella sativa had lower blood levels of thyroid-stimulating hormone and antibodies that target the thyroid and higher levels of blood thyroid hormone (T4) after 8 weeks.

SeqA: Serum concentrations of thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) and anti-thyroid peroxidase (anti-TPO) antibodies decreased while serum T3 concentrations increased in Nigella sativa-treated group after 8 weeks.
SeqB: People taking Nigella sativa had lower blood levels of VEGF.

SeqA: There was a significant reduction in serum VEGF concentrations in intervention group.
SeqB: None of these changes were seen in the group who took the sham treatmentl.

SeqA: None of these changes had been observed in placebo treated group.
SeqB: Based on a statistical model, changes in the ratio of the waist to the hip and thyroid hormones predicted changes in blood VEGF and Nesgfatin-1 levels in the group who took Nigella sativa.

SeqA: In stepwise multiple regression model, changes in waist to hip ratio (WHR) and thyroid hormones were significant predictors of changes in serum VEGF and Nesgfatin-1 values in Nigella sativa treated group (P < 0.05).
SeqB: We concluded that powdered Nigella sativa improved thyroid function and physical body measurements in people with Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

SeqA: Conclusions: Our data showed a potent beneficial effect of powdered Nigella sativa in improving thyroid status and anthropometric variables in patients with Hashimoto's thyroiditis.
SeqB: Nigella sativa lowered blood VEGF levels.

SeqA: Moreover, Nigella sativa significantly reduced serum VEGF concentrations in these patients.
SeqB: Nigella sativa can be a useful non-traditional treatment for people with Hashimoto's thyroiditis to make the disease less severe.

SeqA: Purpose of review: The aim of the article is to present the basics of oral levothyroxine (LT4) absorption, reasons why patients may have persistently elevated serum thyroid stimulation hormone (TSH) levels, and alternative strategies for LT4 dosing.
SeqB: This article aims to cover the basics of how well levothyroxine (LT4 - a common thyroid medication) is absorbed when taken by mouth, reasons why people may have continuously high blood levels of thyroid stimulating hormone, and other ways to take levothyroxine.

SeqA: Recent findings: Although oral LT4 tablets are most commonly used for thyroid hormone replacement in patients with hypothyroidism, case studies report that liquid oral LT4, intravenous, intramuscular, and rectal administration of LT4 can successfully treat refractory hypothyroidism.
SeqB: Although LT4 tablets taken by mouth are most commonly used for thyroid hormone replacement in people with underactive thyroids, studies show that taking LT4 in liquid-form by mouth, shot to a vein or muscle, and through the rectum can work to treat poorly-controlled underactive thyroid.

SeqA: Summary: Hypothyroidism is one of the most common endocrine disorders encountered by primary care physicians and endocrinologists.
SeqB: Underactive thyroid is one of the most common hormone disorders doctors see.

SeqA: LT4 is one of the most widely prescribed medications in the world and it is the standard of care treatment for hypothyroidism.
SeqB: LT4 is one of the most commonly prescribed drugs in the world and is the recommended treatment for underactive thyroid.

SeqA: Generally, hypothyroid patients will be treated with LT4 tablets to be taken orally, and monitoring will occur with routine serum thyroid tests, including TSH concentrations.
SeqB: Generally, people with underactive thyroids will take LT4 tablets by mouth and track thryoid levels with common blood thyroid tests, including measuring levels of thyroid-stimulating hormone.

SeqA: However, many patients fail to maintain serum TSH levels in the target range while managed on oral LT4 tablets.
SeqB: Taking LT4 tablets by mouth does not keep blood thyroid-stimulating hormone levels at the right level for many people.

SeqA: A subset of these patients would be considered to have poorly controlled hypothyroidism, sometimes termed refractory hypothyroidism.
SeqB: Some of these people may have poorly-controlled underactive thyroids, or refractory underactive thyroids.

SeqA: For these patients, optimization of ingestion routines and alternative formulations and routes of administration of LT4 can be considered, including oral liquid, intravenous, intramuscular, and even rectal formulations.
SeqB: This group of people might need to take LT4 in other forms or other ways, including liquid-form by mouth, shot to a vein or muscle, or even through the rectum.

SeqA: Hypothyroidism is one of the most common hormone deficiencies in adults.
SeqB: Underactive thyroid is one of the most common conditions caused by a lack of specific hormones in adults.

SeqA: Most of the cases, particularly those of overt hypothyroidism, are easily diagnosed and managed, with excellent outcomes if treated adequately.
SeqB: Underactive thyroid is usually easily identified and successfully treated.

SeqA: However, minor alterations of thyroid function determine nonspecific manifestations.
SeqB: However, small changes in thyroid function determine symptoms that can be caused by many conditions.

SeqA: Primary hypothyroidism due to chronic autoimmune thyroiditis is largely the most common cause of thyroid hormone deficiency.
SeqB: Primary underactive thyroid caused by a long-term inflamed thyroid, which in turn is caused by thyroid cells that are attacked by infection-preventing cells, is the most common cause of too little thyroid hormones in adults.

SeqA: Central hypothyroidism is a rare and heterogeneous disorder characterized by decreased thyroid hormone secretion by an otherwise normal thyroid gland, due to lack of TSH.
SeqB: Central underactive thyroid, which is not very common and has many causes, is when an otherwise normal thyroid makes too little thyroid hormone due to lack of thyroid-stimulating hormone.

SeqA: The standard treatment of primary and central hypothyroidism is hormone replacement therapy with levothyroxine sodium (LT4).
SeqB: Thyroid hormone replacement with levothyroxine (LT4) is the normal treatment of primary and central underactive thyroid.

SeqA: Treatment guidelines of hypothyroidism recommend monotherapy with LT4 due to its efficacy, long-term experience, favorable side effect profile, ease of administration, good intestinal absorption, long serum half-life and low cost.
SeqB: Treatment guidelines for an underactive thyroid recommend a single drug, levothyroxine (LT4), because of how well it works, how long it has been used, few side effects, how easy it is to use, how well it is absorbed in the stomach, how long it lasts in the blood, and low cost.

SeqA: Despite being easily treatable with a daily dose of LT4, many patients remain hypothyroid due to malabsorption syndromes, autoimmune gastritis, pancreatic and liver disorders, drug interactions, polymorphisms in DIO2 (iodothyronine deiodinase 2), high fiber diet, and more frequently, non-compliance to LT4 therapy.
SeqB: Although taking LT4 daily treats underactive thyroid, many people still have underactive thyroids due to conditions that do not allow absorption in the stomach, inflammation of the stomach lining caused by thyroid cells that are attacked by infection-preventing cells, pancreatic and live disease, two or more drugs interacting with each other, gene variations, eating too much fiber, and more commonly, not following the prescribed LT4 treatment.

SeqA: Compliance to levothyroxine treatment in hypothyroidism is compromised by daily and fasting schedule.
SeqB: Taking levothyroxine as prescribed for underactive thyroid depends on when and if it is taken on an empty stomach.

SeqA: Many adult patients remain hypothyroid due to all the above mentioned and many attempts to improve levothyroxine therapy compliance and absorption have been made.
SeqB: For all of these reasons, many adults still have underactive thyroids.

SeqA: Objective: Hypothyroidism is relatively common, occurring in approximately 5% of the general US population aged ???12 years.
SeqB: Underactive thyroid is relatively common, occurring in about 5% of the general U.S. population 12 years and older.

SeqA: Levothyroxine (LT4) monotherapy is the standard of care.
SeqB: The recommended treatment is a single drug, levothyroxine (LT4 - a common thyroid medication).

SeqA: Approximately, 5%-10% of patients who normalise thyroid-stimulating hormone levels with LT4 monotherapy may have persistent symptoms that patients and clinicians may attribute to hypothyroidism.
SeqB: About 5%-10% of patients who use LT4 alone to regulate thyroid-stimulating hormone levels may have ongoing symptoms that patients and doctors may think are caused by underactive thyroid.

SeqA: A long-standing debate in the literature is whether addition of levotriiodothyronine (LT3) to LT4 will ameliorate lingering symptoms.
SeqB: Science disagrees as to whether addition of levotriiodothyronine (LT3 - another thryoid medication) to LT4 will improve these ongoing symptoms.

SeqA: Here, we explore the evidence for and against LT4/LT3 combination therapy as the optimal approach to treat euthyroid patients with persistent complaints.
SeqB: We look at whether combining LT4 and LT3 is the best way to treat patients with normal thyroid function but ongoing symptoms.

SeqA: Methods: Recent literature indexed on PubMed was searched in March 2017 using the terms "hypothyroid" or "hypothyroidism" and "triiodothyronine combination" or "T3 combination."
SeqB: We searched PubMed in March 2017 using the terms "hypothyroid" or "hypothyroidism" and "triiodothyronine combination" or "T3 combination."

SeqA: Relevant non-review articles published in English during the past 10 years were included and supplemented with articles already known to the authors.
SeqB: We looked at English articles in the last 10 years in addition to known articles.

SeqA: Findings:
SeqB: We did not find strong proof that combining LT4 and LT3 worked to treat patients with underactive thyroids.

SeqA: Current clinical evidence is not sufficiently strong to support LT4/LT3 combination therapy in patients with hypothyroidism.
SeqB: Genes that cause less conversion of T4 to T3 may explain unsuccessful treatment with LT4.

SeqA: Polymorphisms in deiodinase genes that encode the enzymes that convert T4 to T3 in the periphery may provide potential mechanisms underlying unsatisfactory treatment results with LT4 monotherapy.
SeqB: The benefit of adding LT3 to LT4 treatment is uncertain.

SeqA: However, results of studies on the effect of LT4/LT3 therapy on clinical symptoms and thyroid-responsive genes have thus far not been conclusive.
SeqB: Ongoing symptoms in patients with normal thyroid function may be due to other causes.

SeqA: Conclusions: Persistent symptoms in patients who are biochemically euthyroid with LT4 monotherapy may be caused by several other conditions unrelated to thyroid function, and their cause should be aggressively investigated by the clinician.
SeqB: A doctor should determine the cause of the ongoing symptoms.

SeqA: Objective: Hypothyroidism is relatively common, occurring in approximately 5% of the general US population aged ???12 years.
SeqB: Low thyroid function occurs in around 5% of the US population aged ???12 years.

SeqA: Levothyroxine (LT4) monotherapy is the standard of care.
SeqB: Levothyroxine (LT4) (a thyroid hormonal drug) is standard treatment.

SeqA: Approximately, 5%-10% of patients who normalise thyroid-stimulating hormone levels with LT4 monotherapy may have persistent symptoms that patients and clinicians may attribute to hypothyroidism.
SeqB: Around 5-10% of patients with regular thyroid-stimulating hormone levels after LT4 may still have symptoms attributable to reduced thyroid funciton.

SeqA: A long-standing debate in the literature is whether addition of levotriiodothyronine (LT3) to LT4 will ameliorate lingering symptoms.
SeqB: Experts debate if adding levotriiodothyronine (LT3), another manmade thyroid hormone, to LT4 will help lingering symptoms.

SeqA: Here, we explore the evidence for and against LT4/LT3 combination therapy as the optimal approach to treat euthyroid patients with persistent complaints.
SeqB: We explore evidence for and against LT4/LT3 double treatment for best treating patients with lingering thyroid issues.

SeqA: Methods: Recent literature indexed on PubMed was searched in March 2017 using the terms "hypothyroid" or "hypothyroidism" and "triiodothyronine combination" or "T3 combination."
SeqB: We searched PubMed in March 2017 using the terms "hypothyroid" or "hypothyroidism" (low thyroid function) and "triiodothyronine combination" or "T3 combination" (thyroid hormonal drug therapy).

SeqA: Relevant non-review articles published in English during the past 10 years were included and supplemented with articles already known to the authors.
SeqB: Current evidence does not support LT4/LT3 double treatment for those with reduced thyroid function.

SeqA: Findings:
SeqB: Variations in genes blueprinting enzymes that convert thyroid hormone from one form to another may explain the lack of improvement with LT4 treatment.

SeqA: Current clinical evidence is not sufficiently strong to support LT4/LT3 combination therapy in patients with hypothyroidism.
SeqB: However, studies of LT4/LT3 double treatment are not conclusive.

SeqA: Polymorphisms in deiodinase genes that encode the enzymes that convert T4 to T3 in the periphery may provide potential mechanisms underlying unsatisfactory treatment results with LT4 monotherapy.
SeqB: Lingering symptoms in patients with normal thyroids from LT4 therapy may be from other thyroid-unrelated causes, which should be investigated by the clinician.

SeqA: Hyperthyroidism is an excessive concentration of thyroid hormones in tissues caused by increased synthesis of thyroid hormones, excessive release of preformed thyroid hormones, or an endogenous or exogenous extrathyroidal source.
SeqB: Overactive thyroid is when too much thyroid hormone produced, when too much stored thyroid hormone released, or when there are internal or external thyroid hormone sources outside the thyroid.

SeqA: The most common causes of an excessive production of thyroid hormones are Graves disease, toxic multinodular goiter, and toxic adenoma.
SeqB: The most common causes of too much thyroid hormone made are Graves disease, a disease in which infection-preventing cells attack healthy cells and results in an overactive thyroid, or when one or more glandular growths make extra thyroid hormone.

SeqA: The most common cause of an excessive passive release of thyroid hormones is painless (silent) thyroiditis, although its clinical presentation is the same as with other causes.
SeqB: The most common causes of too much thyroid hormone released is thyroid inflammation, although the signs are the same as other causes.

SeqA: Hyperthyroidism caused by overproduction of thyroid hormones can be treated with antithyroid medications (methimazole and propylthiouracil), radioactive iodine ablation of the thyroid gland, or surgical thyroidectomy.
SeqB: Overactive thyroid can be treated with drugs that block the formation of thyroid hormone, radiation therapy, or surgery to remove the thyroid.

SeqA: Radioactive iodine ablation is the most widely used treatment in the United States.
SeqB: Radiation therapy is the most widely used treatment in the United States.

SeqA: The choice of treatment depends on the underlying diagnosis, the presence of contraindications to a particular treatment modality, the severity of hyperthyroidism, and the patient's preference.
SeqB: The choice of treatment depends on the diagnosis, reasons not to use a particular method, how serious the overactive thyroid is, and what the patient wants.

SeqA: The proper treatment of hyperthyroidism depends on recognition of the signs and symptoms of the disease and determination of the etiology.
SeqB: Successfully treating an overactive thyroid depends on identifying the signs and symptoms of the disease and determining the cause.

SeqA: The most common cause of hyperthyroidism is Graves' disease.
SeqB: Graves' disease, a disease in which infection-preventing cells attack healthy cells, is the most common cause of an overactive thyroid.

SeqA: Other common causes include thyroiditis, toxic multinodular goiter, toxic adenomas, and side effects of certain medications.
SeqB: Other common causes of an overactive thyroid include thyroid inflammation, one or more glandular growths making extra thyroid hormone, and side effects of some medications.

SeqA: The diagnostic workup begins with a thyroid-stimulating hormone level test.
SeqB: A common test that measures blood levels of hormones that acts as messengers to the thyroid is the first step in a medical exam.

SeqA: When test results are uncertain, measuring radionuclide uptake helps distinguish among possible causes.
SeqB: When results of this test are uncertain, a test to measure thyroid function can be used.

SeqA: When thyroiditis is the cause, symptomatic treatment usually is sufficient because the associated hyperthyroidism is transient.
SeqB: When the cause is inflammation of the thyroid, treating the symptoms is enough because the overactive thyroid is short-lived.

SeqA: Graves' disease, toxic multinodular goiter, and toxic adenoma can be treated with radioactive iodine, antithyroid drugs, or surgery, but in the United States, radioactive iodine is the treatment of choice in patients without contraindications.
SeqB: Graves' disease and when one or more growths make extra thyroid hormone can be treated with radiation therapy, drugs that block the formation of thyroid hormone, or surgery.

SeqA: Thyroidectomy is an option when other treatments fail or are contraindicated, or when a goiter is causing compressive symptoms.
SeqB: In the United States, radiation therapy to shrink the thyroid is preferred unless there is a reason not to do so.

SeqA: Some new therapies are under investigation.
SeqB: Thyroid removal is an option when other treatments do not work or should not be used, or when an enlarged thyroid is causing pressure or squeezing.

SeqA: Special treatment consideration must be given to patients who are pregnant or breastfeeding, as well as those with Graves' ophthalmopathy or amiodarone-induced hyperthyroidism.
SeqB: New treatments are being studied.

SeqA: Patients' desires must be considered when deciding on appropriate therapy, and dose monitoring is essential.
SeqB: People who are pregnant or breastfeeding, and people with thyroid eye disease or overactive thyroids caused by amiodarone, a heart medication, must be given special treatment consideration.

SeqA: The chemical structure of a neuroleptic does not relaibly predict the exact profile of its therapeutic action.
SeqB: The chemical structure (arrangement of chemical bonds between atoms in a molecule) of drugs used to treat psychotic disorders does not reliably predict how well the treatment works.

SeqA: We considered the question whether the biochemical action of a neuroleptic, and specifically the ratio between DA-receptor block and NA-receptor block, might have a higher predictive value in this respect.
SeqB: We looked into whether the biological and chemical changes made to the body by a drug to treat psychotic disorders might better predict how well the treatment works.

SeqA: In this context we carried out a double-blind study of the therapeutic value of clozapine and perphenazine in acute psychoses of varying symptomatology and aetiology.
SeqB: We did a study of how well antipsychotics clozapine and perphenazine treat short-term impaired relationships with reality with varying symptoms and causes.

SeqA: There are strong indications that clozapine has only a slight inhibitory effect on transmission in central DA-ergic neurons, but markedly inhibits transmission in central NA-ergic neurons, and that the reverse applies to perphenazine.
SeqB: Data suggest that clozapine and perphenazine have opposite effects on two types of neurons or brain cells.

SeqA: In view of these data we expected perphenazine to be a stronger antipsychotic and a weaker sedative than clozapine, and vice versa.
SeqB: We thought that perphenazine would be a stronger drug to treat impaired relationships with reality and a weaker sedative than clozapine, and vice versa.

SeqA: The plausibility of this hypothesis was demonstrated.
SeqB: This assumption proved reasonable.

SeqA: Partly also on the basis of earlier research, we concluded that the biochemical action of a neuroleptic is a more faithful predictor of its therapeutic action profile than the chemical structure.
SeqB: Partly based on earlier research, we concluded that the biological and chemical changes to the body made by a drug used to treat psychotic disorders better predicts how well the treatment works than the arrangement of chemical bonds between atoms in a molecule.

SeqA: CLINICAL experience with tranquilizers has shown the need for prolonged therapy for chronic neurotic and psychotic disorders.
SeqB: Use of tranquilizers on patients has shown the need for long-term treatment of long-term neurotic and pyschotic mental disorders.

SeqA: Since phenothiazine derivatives such as perphenazine are being employed in this manner and since there have been rare reports of jaundice and leukopenia associated with its administration, questions about a potential deleterious effect of this drug on the liver and blood have to be answered.
SeqB: Because antipsychotic drugs like perphenazine are being used to treat long-term mental disorders and there have been rare cases of yellowing of the skin and a decrease in disease-fighting cells in the blood of people who take it, we must figure out whether this drug harms the liver and blood.

SeqA: In the effort to improve treatment effectiveness in glioblastoma, this short note reviewed collected data on the pathophysiology of glioblastoma with particular reference to intersections with the pharmacology of perphenazine.
SeqB: To improve how well treatment for glioblastoma, a type of brain cancer, works, we looked at studies on the disease-related processes associated with glioblastoma and their interaction with how the antipsychotic perphenazine affects the body.

SeqA: That study identified five areas of potentially beneficial intersection.
SeqB: That study found five areas of possibly helpful interaction.

SeqA: Data showed seemingly 5 independent perphenazine attributes of benefit to glioblastoma treatment - i) blocking dopamine receptor 2, ii) reducing centrifugal migration of subventricular zone cells by blocking dopamine receptor 3, iii) blocking serotonin receptor 7, iv) activation of protein phosphatase 2, and v) nausea reduction.
SeqB: Studies showed 5 independent qualities of perphenazine that might help treat glioblastoma, including changing how cells grow and move and reducing nausea.

SeqA: Perphenazine is fully compatible with current chemoirradiation protocols and with the commonly used ancillary medicines used in clinical practice during the course of glioblastoma.
SeqB: Perphenazine can be taken with current chemotherapy and radiation treatments and with commonly prescribed glioblastoma drugs.

SeqA: All these attributes argue for a trial of perphenazine's addition to current standard treatment with temozolomide and irradiation.
SeqB: These qualities suggest the addition of perphenazine to current chemotherapy and radiation treatment should be studied.

SeqA: The subventricular zone seeds the brain with mutated cells that become recurrent glioblastoma after centrifugal migration.
SeqB: Part of the brain sends out damaged cells that become recurring glioblastoma after they move outward.

SeqA: The current paper shows how perphenazine might reduce that contribution.
SeqB: This paper shows how perphenazine might decrease this activity.

SeqA: Perphenazine is an old, generic, cheap, phenothiazine antipsychotic drug that has been in continuous clinical use worldwide since the 1950's.
SeqB: Perphenazine is an old, generic, cheap drug used to treat psychotic disorders worldwide since the 1950s.

SeqA: Clinical experience and research data over these decades have shown perphenazine to be well-tolerated in psychiatric populations, in normals, and in non-psychiatric, medically ill populations for whom perphenazine is used to reduce nausea.
SeqB: Studies over time have shown perphenazine does not cause many side effects in normal people, people with mental illness, and ill people taking perphenazine to reduce nausea.

SeqA: For now (Summer, 2020) the nature of glioblastoma requires a polypharmacy approach until/unless a core feature and means to address it can be identified in the future.
SeqB: As of Summer 2020, glioblastoma requires multiple drugs to treat it until and unless it is better understood and a single treatment drug is found.

SeqA: Conclusions: Perphenazine possesses a remarkable constellation of attributes that recommend its use in GB treatment.
SeqB: We conclude that perphenazine has many qualities that suggest its use in treating glioblastoma.

SeqA: In the effort to improve treatment effectiveness in glioblastoma, this short note reviewed collected data on the pathophysiology of glioblastoma with particular reference to intersections with the pharmacology of perphenazine.
SeqB: To try improving treatment in glioblastoma (a brain cancer), this work collected data on the cancer's symptoms and traits along with references to perphenazine (an anti-psychotic medication).

SeqA: That study identified five areas of potentially beneficial intersection.
SeqB: This study found five areas of possibly beneficial treatment.

SeqA: Data showed seemingly 5 independent perphenazine attributes of benefit to glioblastoma treatment - i) blocking dopamine receptor 2, ii) reducing centrifugal migration of subventricular zone cells by blocking dopamine receptor 3, iii) blocking serotonin receptor 7, iv) activation of protein phosphatase 2, and v) nausea reduction.
SeqB: 5 perphenazine attributes of benefit to glioblastoma treatment include blocking two target sites for chemical messengers, reducing movement of specific cells, activating certain enzymes, and reducing nausea.

SeqA: Perphenazine is fully compatible with current chemoirradiation protocols and with the commonly used ancillary medicines used in clinical practice during the course of glioblastoma.
SeqB: Perphenazine works with current chemradiotherapy and common medicines used to treat glioblastoma.

SeqA: All these attributes argue for a trial of perphenazine's addition to current standard treatment with temozolomide and irradiation.
SeqB: Perphenzaine attributes argue for a trial to add it to current standard treatment with temozolomide (an anti-cancer drug) and irradiation.

SeqA: The subventricular zone seeds the brain with mutated cells that become recurrent glioblastoma after centrifugal migration.
SeqB: A specific brain region seeds the brain with mutated cells that become reappearing gliobastoma after outward movement.

SeqA: The current paper shows how perphenazine might reduce that contribution.
SeqB: The current work shows how perphenazine may reduce this outward growing brain cancer.

SeqA: Perphenazine is an old, generic, cheap, phenothiazine antipsychotic drug that has been in continuous clinical use worldwide since the 1950's.
SeqB: Perphenazine is an old, common, cheap antipsychotic drug used clinically worldwide since the 1950's.

SeqA: Clinical experience and research data over these decades have shown perphenazine to be well-tolerated in psychiatric populations, in normals, and in non-psychiatric, medically ill populations for whom perphenazine is used to reduce nausea.
SeqB: Perphenzaine has been well-tolerated in psychiatric groups, in healthy groups, and in non-psychiatric but medically ill groups who use perphenazine to reduce nausea.

SeqA: For now (Summer, 2020) the nature of glioblastoma requires a polypharmacy approach until/unless a core feature and means to address it can be identified in the future.
SeqB: For now (Summer, 2020), glioblastoma needs a multi-drug approach until a core treatment can be identified.

SeqA: Conclusions: Perphenazine possesses a remarkable constellation of attributes that recommend its use in GB treatment.
SeqB: Perphenazine has many attributes that recommend its use in glioblastoma treatment.

SeqA: Background: Perphenazine is an old phenothiazine antipsychotic with a potency similar to haloperidol.
SeqB: Perphenazine is an old drug used to treat psychotic disorders with strength similar to haloperidol, another drug to treat psychotic disorders.

SeqA: It has been used for many years and is popular in the northern European countries and Japan.
SeqB: Perphenazine has been used for many years and is popular in the northern European countries and Japan.

SeqA: Objectives: To examine the clinical effects and safety of perphenazine for those with schizophrenia and schizophrenia-like psychoses.
SeqB: We aimed to look at the effects and safety of perphenazine in people with schizophrenia (a reality-distorting mental illness) and schizophrenia-like disorders.

SeqA: Authors' conclusions: Although perphenazine has been used in randomised trials for more than 50 years, incomplete reporting and the variety of comparators used make it impossible to draw clear conclusions.
SeqB: We conclude that although perphenazine has been used for more than 50 years, incomplete results and the variety of drugs used to compare perphenazine to make it impossible to make clear judgements.

SeqA: All data for the main outcomes in this review were of very low quality evidence.
SeqB: The results used in this review were not reliable.

SeqA: At best we can say that perphenazine showed similar effects and adverse events as several of the other antipsychotic drugs.
SeqB: The most we can say is that perphenazine had similar results and side effects as many other drugs used to treat psychotic disorders.

SeqA: Since perphenazine is a relatively inexpensive and frequently used compound, further trials are justified to clarify the properties of this classical antipsychotic drug.
SeqB: Because perphenazine is a cheap and often used drug, more studies are needed to fully understand the drug's properties.

SeqA: Background: Antipsychotic drugs are the core treatment for schizophrenia.
SeqB: Drugs used to treat psychotic disorders are the main treatment for schizophrenia (a reality-distorting mental illness).

SeqA: Treatment guidelines state that there is no difference in efficacy between the various first-generation antipsychotics, however, low-potency first-generation antipsychotic drugs are sometimes perceived as less efficacious than high-potency first-generation compounds by clinicians, and they also seem to differ in their side effects.
SeqB: Treatment recommendations say there is no difference in treatment effect among older drugs used to treat psychotic disorders.

SeqA: Authors' conclusions: The results do not show a superiority in efficacy of high-potency perphenazine compared with low-potency first-generation antipsychotics.
SeqB: However, doctors sometimes think older drugs with lower strength used to treat psychotic disorders do not work as well as older drugs with higher strength, and they also seem to have different side effects.

SeqA: There is some evidence that perphenazine is more likely to cause akathisia and less likely to cause severe toxicity, but most adverse effect results were equivocal.
SeqB: We conclude that the results do not show that the antipsychotic perphenazine with its higher strength works better than older antipsychotics with lower strength.

SeqA: The number of studies as well as the quality of studies is low, with quality of evidence for the main outcomes ranging from moderate to very low, so more randomised evidence would be needed for conclusions to be made.
SeqB: Some evidence exists that perphenazine is more likely to cause restlessness and less likely to cause drug toxicity in the bloodstream requiring hospitalization, but most side effects were the same.

SeqA: Endometrial cancer (EC) is one of the most common and fatal gynecological cancers worldwide, but there is no effective treatment for the EC patients of progesterone resistance.
SeqB: Endometrial cancer (EC), cancer of the lining of the uterus, is one of the most common and deadly cancers of the female reproductive system worldwide, but there is no working treatment for EC patients who do not respond to progesterone, a hormone.

SeqA: Repurposing of existing drugs is a good strategy to discover new candidate drugs.
SeqB: Trying drugs used for other things is a good way to find new ways to treat conditions.

SeqA: In this text, perphenazine (PPZ), approved for psychosis therapy, was identified as a potential agent for the treatment of both progesterone sensitive and resistant endometrial cancer for the first time.
SeqB: Perphenazine, used to treat psychotic disorders, might treat people with endometrial cancer who are both sensitive to and resistant to progesterone.

SeqA: Specifically, perphenazine exhibited good cell proliferation inhibition in Ishikawa (ISK) and KLE cell lines according to the CCK-8 assay and colony formation assay.
SeqB: Perphenazine reduced growth of certain cancer-causing endometrial cells based on common lab tests.

SeqA: It also reduced the cell migration of ISK and KLE cell lines in the light of the transwell migration assay.
SeqB: Tests showed perphenazine also reduced movement of certain cancer-causing endometrial cells.

SeqA: Annexin-V/PI double staining assay suggested that perphenazine could effectively induce ISK and KLE cell apoptosis.
SeqB: Tests suggest that perphenazine could kill certain cancer-causing endometrial cells.

SeqA: Moreover, results of western blot assay indicated perphenazine obviously inhibited the phosphorylation of Akt.
SeqB: Perphenazine also could reduce tumor growth in mice without affecting body weight.

SeqA: Endometrial cancer (EC) is one of the most common and fatal gynecological cancers worldwide, but there is no effective treatment for the EC patients of progesterone resistance.
SeqB: Endometrial (outer womb) cancer (EC) is a common, fatal female-related cancer worldwide, but there is no treatment for EC patients of progesterone (specific female hormone) resistance.

SeqA: Repurposing of existing drugs is a good strategy to discover new candidate drugs.
SeqB: Adapting current drugs is useful to discover new candidate drugs.

SeqA: In this text, perphenazine (PPZ), approved for psychosis therapy, was identified as a potential agent for the treatment of both progesterone sensitive and resistant endometrial cancer for the first time.
SeqB: In this text, perphenazine (PPZ), used for psychosis, may treat patients with both progesterone sensitive and resistant outer womb cancer.

SeqA: Specifically, perphenazine exhibited good cell proliferation inhibition in Ishikawa (ISK) and KLE cell lines according to the CCK-8 assay and colony formation assay.
SeqB: Perphenazine (an anti-psychotic) blocked cell growth in two, outer womb cancer cell groups.

SeqA: It also reduced the cell migration of ISK and KLE cell lines in the light of the transwell migration assay.
SeqB: Perphenazine could effectively cause controlled cell death in two, outer womb cancer cell groups.

SeqA: Annexin-V/PI double staining assay suggested that perphenazine could effectively induce ISK and KLE cell apoptosis.
SeqB: Also, perphenazine could block phosphorylation of Akt, which activates the Akt enzyme which monitors cell growth.

SeqA: Moreover, results of western blot assay indicated perphenazine obviously inhibited the phosphorylation of Akt.
SeqB: Delightedly, perphenazine could weaken cancer growth from a different-species organ transplant in mice at various doses without affecting body weight.

SeqA: Background: Antipsychotic drugs are usually given orally but compliance with medication given by this route may be difficult to quantify.
SeqB: Drugs used to treat psychotic disorders are usually given by mouth, but it is hard to measure if people take the drugs as instructed.

SeqA: The development of depot injections in the 1960s gave rise to extensive use of depots as a means of long-term maintenance treatment.
SeqB: Slow-releasing shots, created in the 1960s, became popular as long-term treatment to keep conditions stable.

SeqA: Perphenazine decanoate and enanthate are depot antipsychotics that belong to the phenothiazine family and have a piperazine ethanol side chain.
SeqB: Perphenazine decanoate and enanthate are slow-release shots used to treat psychotic disorders.

SeqA: Objectives: To assess the effects of depot perphenazine decanoate and enanthate versus placebo, oral antipsychotics and other depot antipsychotic preparations for people with schizophrenia in terms of clinical, social and economic outcomes.
SeqB: We aimed to measure the medical, social, and economic effects of slow-releasing perphenazine decanoate and enanthate shots compared to no treatment, drugs used to treat psychotic disorders by mouth, and other slow-releasing shots used to treat psychotic disorders for people with schizophrenia (a reality-distorting mental illness).

SeqA: Authors' conclusions: Depot perphenazine is in clinical use in the Nordic countries, Belgium, Portugal and the Netherlands.
SeqB: We state that slow-releasing perphenazine shots are used in Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway, Sweden, Belgium, Portugal, and the Netherlands.

SeqA: At a conservative estimate, a quarter of a million people suffer from schizophrenia in those countries and could be treated with depot perphenazine.
SeqB: At least 250,000 people have schizophrenia in these countries and could be given slow-releasing perphenazine shots.

SeqA: The total number of participants in the four trials with useful data is 313.
SeqB: The four trials with useful results had 313 total people.

SeqA: None of the studies observed the effects of oral versus depot antipsychotic drugs.
SeqB: None of the studies compared the effects of antipsychotics taken by mouth to a slow-releasing shot.

SeqA: Until well conducted and reported randomised trials are undertaken clinicians will be in doubt as to the effects of perphenazine depots and people with schizophrenia should exercise their own judgement or ask to be randomised.
SeqB: People with schizophrenia should use their own judgement until more studies are done and doctors know the effects of slow-release perphenazine shots.

SeqA: We have found oral perphenazine 8 mg (OP8) useful as follows: (1) as a nonsedating antiemetic; (2) as a preventative measure similar to the antihistamine promethazine against ketamine-induced psychotomimetic effects; and (3) as a safe single-dose drug (only 1.3 extrapyramidal events per 10,000 patients receiving 4??8 mg oral dose, with all events easily treated).
SeqB: Perphenazine 8 mg (OP8) can be taken by mouth for the following uses: (1) as a nonsedating drug to prevent nausea and vomiting; (2) like promethazine, an antihistamine (allergy drug) , to prevent psychotic symptoms caused by ketamine (a pain relief drug); and (3) as a safe one-dose drug.

SeqA: Additionally, we evaluated the efficacy of single-dose OP8 to a single 40 mg dose of aprepitant given preoperatively in colorectal surgery patients at our academic center within an enhanced recovery protocol, which was designed to mitigate opioid utilization, reduce Postoperative Nausea and Vomiting (PONV), and optimize patient recovery.
SeqB: We also rated the success of one-dose OP8 compared to one 40 mg dose of aprepitant, used to prevent nausea and vomiting, given to people before rectum, anus, and colon operations in our center with guidelines designed to help people recover more quickly from surgery, reduce opioid use, and reduce nausea and vomiting after surgery.

SeqA: In this retrospective study, no differences were noted in antiemetic requirement on postoperative days 0 and 1 between patients receiving OP8 versus aprepitant.
SeqB: In this study, we saw no differences in nausea and vomiting prevention on the same day of surgery and one day after surgery between patients who got OP8 versus aprepitant.

SeqA: As enhanced recovery protocols become more widespread and continue to be applied to other surgical specialties, effective PONV prevention is imperative for improving patient outcomes.
SeqB: As guidelines to help people recover more quickly from surgery become more widespread and used for other surgeries, successfully preventing nausea and vomiting after surgery is key to improving patient results.

SeqA: OP8 deserves to be properly evaluated (by clinical study, and/or in routine clinical practice) as a part of a cost-effective multimodal enhanced recovery strategy.
SeqB: OP8 should be studied as part of a cost-effective, multi-process way to help people recover more quickly from surgery.

SeqA: Background and objective: despite the introduction of newer antiemetics in the prevention of postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV), perphenazine is recommended in current guidelines, as the concept of multimodal management of PONV in high-risk patients requires more than two drugs to be combined.
SeqB: Even though there are newer drugs to prevent nausea and vomiting after surgery, current guidelines recommend the drug perphenazine.

SeqA: The aim of this quantitative systematic review was to assess the efficacy and safety of perphenazine in the prophylaxis of PONV in adults and children.
SeqB: A multi-process way to prevent nausea and vomiting in high-risk patients requires using more than two drugs.

SeqA: Results: eleven trials published between 1965 and 1999 including a total of 2081 participants fulfilled the inclusion criteria and were further analysed.
SeqB: We aimed to rate the success and safety of perphenazine in prevention of nausea and vomiting in adults and children.

SeqA: In children, perphenazine 0.07 mg kg was effective in preventing vomiting (RR, 0.31; 95% CI, 0.18-0.54), whereas in adults, a dose of about 5 mg was effective for the prevention of PONV (RR, 0.50; 95% CI, 0.37-0.67).
SeqB: We looked at eleven studies published between 1965 and 1999 with a total of 2081 people.

SeqA: When compared with established newer drugs, for example, ondansetron, dexamethasone or droperidol, no significant differences were observed in the pooled analysis with limited data.
SeqB: Perphenazine 0.07 mg kg and 5 mg prevented nausea and vomiting in children and adults, respectively.

SeqA: Reporting of adverse events was poor.
SeqB: We saw no big differences compared to newer drugs like ondansetron, dexamethasone or droperidol in studies with limited results.

SeqA: Transient sedation was reported in three eligible trials (RR, 0.9; 95% CI, 0.40-2.05).
SeqB: Side effects were not well reported.

SeqA: Conclusion: there is evidence that perphenazine is effective in the prevention of PONV in children and adults without serious adverse effects compared with placebo.
SeqB: Short-term sedation occurred in three studies.

SeqA: We present here a potential new treatment adjunct for glioblastoma.

SeqA: Building on murine studies, a series of papers appeared recently showing that therapeutic irradiation of the ipsilateral subventricular zone (SVZ) retards growth of more peripherally growing cortical glioblastomas in humans, suggesting a tumor trophic function for the SVZ.
SeqB: Based on mouse studies, several recent studies showed that radiation of the part of the brain where brain cells are made reduces growth of some glioblastomas in humans, suggesting this part of the brain might play a role in fueling brain tumors.

SeqA: Further studies showed that SVZ cells migrate out towards a peripheral glioblastoma.
SeqB: More studies showed cells from the part of the brain where brain cells are made move outward toward a glioblastoma.

SeqA: Dopamine signaling through D3 subtype receptor indirectly drives this centrifugal migration in humans.
SeqB: Certain molecule signaling causes this cell movement.

SeqA: Since psychiatry has several drugs with good D3 blocking attributes, such as fluphenazine, or perphenazine, we suggest that adding one of these D3 blocking drugs to current standard treatment of resection followed by temozolomide and irradiation might prolong survival by depriving glioblastoma of the trophic functions previously subserved by dopaminergic signaling on SVZ cells.
SeqB: Because many mental health drugs block molecule signaling, such as fluphenazine, or perphenazine, we suggest adding one of these drugs to the current standard treatment of surgery followed by chemotherapy and radiation to possibly increase survival time by cutting off fuel to the glioblastoma.

SeqA: Objective: This study was designed to explore the clinical application of video laryngoscopy in the diagnosis and treatment of throat foreign bodies (FBs).

SeqA: Objective: This study was designed to explore the clinical application of video laryngoscopy in the diagnosis and treatment of throat foreign bodies (FBs).

SeqB: The most common foreign substance was fish bones, seen in 91.98% of patients.

SeqA: A shorter duration of admission was associated with a higher diagnostic rate under video laryngoscopy.

SeqA: Foreign bodies in the ear, nose, and throat are occasionally seen in family medicine, usually in children.

SeqA: Objective: In the present study, an attempt was made to examine the effects of aural stimulation with ointment containing capsaicin on swallowing function in order to develop a novel and safe treatment for non-obstructive dysphagia in elderly patients.
SeqB: We looked at the effects of rubbing an ointment with capsaicin, found in different types of hot peppers, on the ears to improve swallowing function and create a new and safe treatment for old people who have the sensation of food stuck in the esophagus without physical blockage.

SeqA: Patients and methods: The present study included 26 elderly patients with non-obstructive dysphagia.
SeqB: We looked at 26 old people who had the sensation of food stuck in the esophagus without physical blockage.

SeqA: Ointment containing 0.025% capsaicin (0.5 g) was applied to the external auditory canal with a cotton swab under otoscope only once or once a day for 7 days before swallowing of a bolus of colored water (3 mL), which was recorded by transnasal videoendoscopy and evaluated according to the endoscopic swallowing score.
SeqB: We used a Q-tip to put ointment with 0.025% capsaicin (0.5 g) in the ear only once or once a day for 7 days before drinking 3 mL of colored water, which was recorded using a flexible tube with a camera and rated using a common test that measures how well one swallows.

SeqA: Results:
SeqB: After putting 0.025% capsaicin ointment to the right ear, the common swallowing test showed less difficulty swallowing.

SeqA: After a single application of 0.025% capsaicin ointment to the right external auditory canal, the endoscopic swallowing score was significantly decreased, and this effect lasted for 60 minutes.
SeqB: This effect lasted for one hour.

SeqA: After repeated applications of the ointment to each external auditory canal alternatively once a day for 7 days, the endoscopic swallowing score decreased significantly in patients with more severe non-obstructive dysphagia.
SeqB: After putting the ointment on alternating ears once a day for 7 days, the common swallowing test showed less difficulty swallowing in people with more serious sensations of food stuck in the esophagus without physical blockage.

SeqA: Of the eight tube-fed patients of this group, three began direct swallowing exercises using jelly, which subsequently restored their oral food intake.
SeqB: Of the eight people fed with tubes in this group, three began direct swallowing exercises using jelly, which then returned their ability to eat food by mouth.

SeqA: Conclusion: These findings suggest that stimulation of the external auditory canal with ointment containing capsaicin improves swallowing function in elderly patients with non-obstructive dysphagia.
SeqB: We concluded that putting ointment with capsaicin on the ear improves swallowing function in old people who have the sensation of food stuck in the esophagus without physical blockage.

SeqA: By the same mechanism used by angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors to induce cough reflex, which has been shown to prevent aspiration pneumonia, aural stimulation with capsaicin may reduce the incidence of aspiration pneumonia in dysphagia patients via Arnold's ear-cough reflex stimulation.
SeqB: In the same way as other methods to stimulate the cough reflex, putting capsaicin on the ears may decrease how often people with difficulty swallowing develop pneumonia, caused by something entering the airway or lungs by accident, through a cough reflex stimulated by a nerve.
