SeqA: Objective: To identify through case study the presentation and possible pathophysiological cause of complex regional pain syndrome and its preferential response to stellate ganglion blockade.
SeqB: The objective of this case report (a summary of an individual patient's symptoms, diagnosis, and treatment) is to identify the sign or symptoms and causes of complex regional pain syndrome (a form of ongoing pain that affects the arm or leg) and if a pain treatment called stellate ganglion blockade (an injection of medication into nerves at the front of the neck that can relieve pain) has any effect on the pain.

SeqA: Setting: Complex regional pain syndrome can occur in an extremity after minor injury, fracture, surgery, peripheral nerve insult or spontaneously and is characterised by spontaneous pain, changes in skin temperature and colour, oedema, and motor disturbances.
SeqB: Complex regional pain syndrome can occur in the arms or legs after a minor injury, fracture, surgery, or nerve damage.

SeqA: Pathophysiology is likely to involve peripheral and central components and neurological and inflammatory elements.
SeqB: It appears as sudden, random pain, changes in skin temperatures and color, swelling in ankles, feet or legs, and uncontrollable movements in the body.

SeqA: There is no consistent approach to treatment with a wide variety of specialists involved.
SeqB: Disease-related physical changes are likely to involve outer and central parts, nerve-related elements, and inflammatory elements, the body's natural response to injury or infection.

SeqA: Diagnosis can be difficult, with over-diagnosis resulting from undue emphasis placed upon pain disproportionate to an inciting event despite the absence of other symptoms or under-diagnosed when subtle symptoms are not recognised.
SeqB: There is no consistent approach to treatment with a wide variety of specialists involved.

SeqA: The International Association for the Study of Pain supports the use of sympathetic blocks to reduce sympathetic nervous system overactivity and relieve complex regional pain symptoms.
SeqB: Diagnosis can be difficult.

SeqA: Educational reviews promote stellate ganglion blockade as beneficial.
SeqB: Sometimes it is over-diagnosed (diagnosis of a medical condition that would never have caused any symptoms or problems) from too much attention on the pain even though other symptoms are not present.

SeqA: Three blocks were given at 8, 10 and 13 months after the initial injury under local anaesthesia and sterile conditions.
SeqB: Sometimes it can be under-diagnosed (diagnosed less often than its occurrence) when less obvious symptioms are not recognized.

SeqA: Physiotherapeutic input was delivered under block conditions to maximise joint and tissue mobility and facilitate restoration of function.
SeqB: A professional medical association for the study of pain supports the kind of pain block used in stellate ganglion blockade to reduce sensory nerves and relieve pain sympoms.

SeqA: Conclusion:
SeqB: Educational reviews promote stellate ganglion blockade as beneficial.

SeqA: This case demonstrates the need for practitioners from all disciplines to be able to identify the clinical characteristics of complex regional pain syndrome to instigate immediate treatment and supports the notion that stellate ganglion blockade is preferable to upper limb intravenous regional anaesthetic block for refractory index finger pain associated with complex regional pain syndrome.
SeqB: Three blocks (injections) were given at 8, 10 and 13 months after the initial injury under local anaesthesia and clean conditions.

SeqA: Background and aims: In previous studies, we successfully applied Low Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in patients with non-specific chronic pain of the shoulder joint and lower back.
SeqB: To treat patients with chronic shoulder and low back pain, previous studies have successfully used a treatment called low level laser therapy (LLLT), a laser light used at a low level and applied to the skin of the body to reduce pain or inflammation and help heal wounds, tissues, and nerves.

SeqA: The purpose of the present study was to assess the effectiveness of LLLT for chronic joint pain of the elbow, wrist, and fingers.
SeqB: The purpose of this current study is to find out if LLLT also helps patients with chronic joint pain of the elbow, wrist, and fingers.

SeqA: Subjects and methods: Nine male and 15 female patients with chronic joint pain of the elbow, wrist, or fingers, who were treated at the rehabilitation outpatient clinic at our hospital from April, 2007 to March, 2009 were enrolled in the study.
SeqB: This study included 9 male and 15 female patients with chronic joint pain in the elbow, wrist, or fingers.

SeqA: We used a 1000 mW semiconductor laser device.
SeqB: The tender point (specific area of pain) and three points surrounding the pain were exposed to the LLLT therapy light.

SeqA: Each tender point and three points around it were irradiated with laser energy.
SeqB: Each area was exposed two times for 20 seconds per treatment, giving a total of three minutes for all 4 points.

SeqA: Each point was irradiated twice for 20 s per treatment, giving a total of three minutes for all 4 points.
SeqB: Patients visited the clinic twice a week, and were evaluated after 4 weeks of treatment with LLLT (laser therapy).

SeqA: Patients visited the clinic twice a week, and were evaluated after four weeks of treatment.
SeqB: A tool called the Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) was used to measure pain by asking patients to report how intense their pain is on a scale.

SeqA: Pain was evaluated with a Visual Analogue Scale (VAS).
SeqB: The study analyzed VAS scores (how patients described their pain) after they received the LLLT laser treatment.

SeqA: Statistical analysis of the VAS scores after laser irradiation was performed with Wilcoxon's signed rank sum test, using SPSS Ver.17.
SeqB: All VAS scores that document pain intensity were totaled and analyzed.

SeqA: Results:
SeqB: There was significant improvement in how much pain patients felt after they received the treatment.

SeqA: All VAS scores were totaled and statistically analyzed.
SeqB: The effect of the laser treatment lasted for about one and half days for patients with wrist pain, tennis elbow, and carpal tunnel syndrome (pinched nerve in the wrist).

SeqA: The average VAS score before irradiation was 59.2??12.9, and 33.1??12.2 after the irradiation, showing a significant improvement in VAS score (p<0.001) after treatment.
SeqB: In patients with other types of pain, the effect lasted for about 3-15 hours.

SeqA: The treatment effect lasted for about one and a half days in the case of wrist pain, epicondylitis lateralis (tennis elbow), and carpal tunnel syndrome.
SeqB: There was no change in how far patients could move or stretch the injured part of the body after the treatment.

SeqA: In other pain entities, it lasted for about three to fifteen hours.
SeqB: This study found that low level laser therapy was helpful for chronic pain of the elbow, wrist, and fingers.

SeqA: Background and aims: In previous studies, we successfully applied Low Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in patients with non-specific chronic pain of the shoulder joint and lower back.
SeqB: In previous studies, we used Low Level Laser Therapy (LLLT), therapy with applying light on the body's surface, in patients with non-specific, long-lasting pain of the shoulder joint and lower back.

SeqA: The purpose of the present study was to assess the effectiveness of LLLT for chronic joint pain of the elbow, wrist, and fingers.
SeqB: This work measures the success of this specific light therapy for lasting joint pain of the elbow, wrist, and fingers.

SeqA: Subjects and methods: Nine male and 15 female patients with chronic joint pain of the elbow, wrist, or fingers, who were treated at the rehabilitation outpatient clinic at our hospital from April, 2007 to March, 2009 were enrolled in the study.
SeqB: Nine male and fifteen female patients with long-lasting joint pain of the elbow, wrist, or fingers were treated at our hospital's recovery clinic from April, 2007 to March, 2009.

SeqA: We used a 1000 mW semiconductor laser device.
SeqB: These patients were employed in the study.

SeqA: Each tender point and three points around it were irradiated with laser energy.
SeqB: Patients visited the clinic twice a week and were checked after four weeks of treatment.

SeqA: Each point was irradiated twice for 20 s per treatment, giving a total of three minutes for all 4 points.
SeqB: Pain was measured with a specific pain scale.

SeqA: Patients visited the clinic twice a week, and were evaluated after four weeks of treatment.
SeqB: The average pain score noticeably improved after treatment.

SeqA: Pain was evaluated with a Visual Analogue Scale (VAS).
SeqB: The treatment effect lasted for about one and a half days regarding wrist pain, tennis elbow, and carpal tunnel syndrome, which involves pinched nerves in the wrist.

SeqA: Statistical analysis of the VAS scores after laser irradiation was performed with Wilcoxon's signed rank sum test, using SPSS Ver.17.
SeqB: In other pain types, the treatment effect lasted for about three to fifteen hours.

SeqA: Results:
SeqB: No change in the range of motion was seen in any of the 24 patients.

SeqA: All VAS scores were totaled and statistically analyzed.
SeqB: LLLT at the settings used in this study was useful for long-lasting pain of the elbow, wrist, and fingers.

SeqA: This compilation presents a comprehensive review of the literature on common chronic pain conditions of the hand.
SeqB: This report presents a thorough review of the literature on common chronic pain conditions of the hand.

SeqA: It briefly presents these common conditions with their biological background, diagnosis, and common management options.
SeqB: It briefly presents common conditions with their biological background, diagnosis, and common options to treat and manage pain.

SeqA: It then presents and compares the latest literature available for injection techniques to treat these diagnoses and compares the available evidence.
SeqB: The report also shows and compares the latest literature available for injection methods to treat these diagnoses and compares the available evidence.

SeqA: Results:
SeqB: Hand pain is a common condition occuring in 9.7% of men and 21.6% of women and can cause significant illness and disability.

SeqA: Hand pain is a common condition with 9.7% prevalence in men and 21.6% in women and can cause significant morbidity and disability.
SeqB: It is also costly to the individuals and the healthcare system, totaling in $4 billion dollars in 2003.

SeqA: It also carries a significant cost to the individuals and the healthcare system, totaling in $4 billion dollars in 2003.
SeqB: Injection therapy (a treatment that involves inserting a needle into the skin to deliver medicine and reduce pain) is an option when other non-surgical treatments fail.

SeqA: Injection therapy is an alternative when conservative treatment fails.
SeqB: Osteoarthritis (the wearing down of flexible tissue at the end of bones) is the most common chronic hand pain condition and affects about 16% of the population.

SeqA: Osteoarthritis is the most common chronic hand pain syndrome and affects about 16% of the population.
SeqB: There is disagreement on whether steroid injections are helpful to osteoarthritis.

SeqA: Its mechanism is largely mechanic, and as such, there is controversy if steroid injections are of benefit.
SeqB: Injections of hyaluronic acid (a natural lubricant that can relieve pain) appear to provide significant relief of pain and may increase movement.

SeqA: Hyaluronic acid (HA) appears to provide substantial relief of pain and may increase functionality.
SeqB: More studies of hyaluronic acid are required before deciding how well it works.

SeqA: More studies of HA are required to make a definite judgment on its efficacy.
SeqB: Similarly, steroid injection to reduce a ganglion cyst (a swelling or bump on the wrist joint) may have little benefit.

SeqA: Similarly, steroid ganglion cyst injection may confer little benefit.
SeqB: Injection therapy provides only short-term relief for carpal tunnel syndrome (pinched nerves in the wrist).

SeqA: Carpal tunnel syndrome is a compressive neuropathy, and only temporarily relieved with injection therapy.
SeqB: While severe cases of hand pain may still require surgery, injection therapy may be an additional treatment step before surgery.

SeqA: US-guidance provides significant improvement and, while severe cases may still require surgery, can provide a valuable bridge therapy to surgery when conservative treatment fails.
SeqB: Similar treatments under US-guidance are effective for a condition called trigger finger where the finger gets locked in a bent position.

SeqA: Similar bridging treatments and increased efficacy under US-guidance are effective for stenosing tenosynovitis ("trigger finger"), though, interestingly, inflammatory background is associated with decreased effect in this case.
SeqB: When the cause of the pain is inflammation (the body's response to injury or infection often causing swelling, pain, or redness), corticosteroid or steroid injections provide significant pain relief and increased movement.

SeqA: When the etiology of the pain is inflammatory, such as in RA, corticosteroid (CS) injections provide significant pain relief and increased functionality.
SeqB: Corticosteroid injections do not, however, change the course of disease.

SeqA: They do not, however, change the course of disease (unlike DMARDs).
SeqB: Other conditions such as gout (a type of arthritis that causes sudden pain or swelling, often in the big toe) and De-Quervain tenosynovitis (pain in the tendons in the thumb) may get some benefit from corticosteroid injections.

SeqA: Another such example is De-Quervain tenosynovitis that sees good benefit from CS injections, and an increased efficacy with US-guidance, and similarly are CS injections for gout.
SeqB: Botox injections show encouraging results for Raynaud's phenomenon (spasms caused by slow blood flow in the fingers and other extremities), but more studies are needed to determine safety and how well the injections work.

SeqA: For Raynaud's phenomenon, Botox injections have encouraging results, but more studies are needed to determine safety and efficacy, as well as the possible difference in effect between primary and secondary Raynaud's.
SeqB: Chronic hand pain is a common and serious condition, can cause significant illness and disability, and interferes with independence and the activities of daily living.

SeqA: Conclusions: Chronic hand pain is a prevalent and serious condition and can cause significant morbidity and disability and interferes with independence and activities of daily living.
SeqB: Careful, non-invasive treatment remains the first line of treatment; however, when first-line treatments fail, steroid injections can usually provide benefit.

SeqA: Conservative treatment remains the first line of treatment; however, when first-line treatments fail, steroid injections can usually provide benefit.
SeqB: In some cases, Hyaluronic acid or Botox may also be helpful.

SeqA: In some cases, Hyaluronic acid or Botox may also be beneficial.
SeqB: US-guidance is expanding in hand injections and provides safer, more effective injections.

SeqA: US-guidance is increasing in hand injection and almost ubiquitously provides safer, more effective injections.
SeqB: Hand surgery remains the alternative for pain that is not responding to multiple treatments.

SeqB: Hand osteoarthritis is a common joint disease that may lead to pain, stiffness and problems in performing hand-related activities of daily living.

SeqA: Background: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is characterized by pain, functional disability, poor quality of life (QoL), high socioeconomic impact, and annual costs of over $56 billion in the United States.
SeqB: Rheumatoid arthritis is a disease where the immune system attacks healthy cells in the body by mistake.

SeqA: Acupuncture (AC) is widely in use; however, studies show severe methodological shortcomings, did not consider the functional diagnosis for the allocation of acupoints and their results showed no differences between verum and control groups.
SeqB: It can cause pain, decrease movement, lead to poor quality of life, impact the social and economic parts of communities, and cost over $56 billion in the United States every year.

SeqA: Objective: The authors aimed to objectively assess the safety and efficacy of AC treatments for RA.
SeqB: Acupuncture involves pricking the skin or tissues with thin needles at key points in the body to reduce pain and is widely used.

SeqA: Methods: 105 RA patients with a functional diagnosis of a "Pivot syndrome" or "Turning Point syndrome" were randomly assigned to (1) verum-AC (verum acupoints), (2) control-AC (sham acupoints-points outside of the conduits/meridians and of the extra-conduits), or (3) waiting list (each group n = 35).
SeqB: However, studies show problems in the methods used to measure acupuncture.

SeqA: AC groups experienced the exact same number, depth, and stimulation of needles.
SeqB: The aim of this current study is to evaluate the safety and the performance of acupuncture treatments on rheumatoid arthritis.

SeqA: Assessments took place before and 5 min after AC with follow-ups over 4 weeks.
SeqB: In this study, 105 patients with rheumatoid arthritis and a specific diagnosis were randomly assigned to either the acupuncture group, the sham acupuncture group (where the patient is pricked with thin needles but at different, less key points of the body), or a waiting list group.

SeqA: Results: (1) Verum-AC significantly improved self-reported pain (Z = -5.099, p < 0.001) and pressure algometry (Z = -5.086, p < 0.001); hand grip strength (Z = -5.086, p < 0.001) and arm strength (Z = -5.086, p < 0.001); health status improved significantly (p < 0.001, Z = -4.895); QoL improved significantly in 7/8 survey domains; and number of swollen joints (Z = -2.862, p = 0.004) and tender joints (Z = -3.986, p < 0.001) significantly decreased.
SeqB: Each group had 35 patients.

SeqA: (2) Control-AC showed no significant changes, except in self-reported pain improvement.
SeqB: The acupuncture groups (both normal and sham) experienced the exact same number, depth, and stimulation of needles.

SeqA: (3) Waiting list group showed an overall worsening.
SeqB: A physical and visual exam of patients took place before and 5 minutes after acupuncture treatment with follow-up visits over 4 weeks.

SeqA: Conclusion: This is the first double-blind controlled study on AC in RA of the hand that objectively and specifically assesses positive effects supporting its integration in rheumatology.
SeqB: Patients in the acupuncture group showed signficantly improved pain and pain sensitivity, hand grip and arm strength, as well as improved health status.

SeqA: Acupoint allocation according to Chinese Medicine functional diagnoses is extremely relevant to assess AC effectiveness in a patient group primarily defined by a "western" medicine diagnosis.
SeqB: Quality of life significantly improved in 7 out of 8 parts of a survey.

SeqA: Based on clear allocation criteria for acupoints, the authors minimized the possible bias of unspecific and suggestive effects on the control group, showed the specific effects of the points chosen, improved efficacy, and identified an evidence base for AC.
SeqB: The number of swollen joints and tender joints signficantly decreased.

SeqA: Pain and a loss of feeling in your thumb, index finger, middle finger, and part of your ring finger may be a sign of carpal tunnel syndrome.
SeqB: Pain and a loss of feeling in the thumb, index finger, middle finger, and part of the ring finger may be a sign of carpal tunnel syndrome (pinched nerves in the wrist).

SeqA: This syndrome and the pain, numbness, tingling, and weakness in your hand that result from it are caused by pressure on the median nerve as it travels through the carpal tunnel.
SeqB: This syndrome and the pain, numbness, tingling, and weakness in the hand is caused by pressure on the main nerve at the front of the forearm as it travels through the carpal tunnel, a narrow passageway at the base of the hand that is made of ligaments and bone.

SeqA: Guidelines published in the May 2019 issue of JOSPT make recommendations, based on best practices from the published literature, for evaluating, diagnosing, and treating carpal tunnel syndrome.

SeqB: Hand osteoarthritis is a problem that is associated with hand pain, stiffness, inability to perform normal functional movements, decreased grip strength, and reduced quality of life.

SeqB: A nighttime orthosis is a device or brace worn at night that supports weak or damaged muscles and limits motion of the wrist.

SeqA: Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness of nighttime orthoses on the second or third finger of the dominant hand in controlling pain in women with symptomatic osteoarthritis (OA) in the interphalangeal joint.
SeqB: The objective of this study is to evaluate how helpful using nighttime orthoses on the second or third finger of the dominant hand is in controlling pain in women who have osteoarthritis in the hinge joint of the fingers.

SeqA: Design: Randomized controlled trial.
SeqB: This study used a randomized controlled trial, a type of study that randomly assigns participants to one of two groups: the intervention group that is receiving the treatment or the comparison group not receiving treatment.

SeqA: Setting: Outpatient clinic.
SeqB: The study took place in an outpatient clinic away from a hospital.

SeqA: Participants: Fifty-two women with symptomatic OA and presence of Heberden's and Bouchard's nodes, allocated randomly to the intervention group or the control group.
SeqB: Fifty-two women with osteoarthritis and who also had bony bumps (also called nodes) on the finger joints closest to the fingernail and in the middle of the finger were randomly assigned to the intervention group or the comparison group.

SeqA: Intervention:
SeqB: The intervention group used a nighttime orthosis on the second or third finger of the dominant hand.

SeqA: The intervention group used a nighttime orthosis on the second or third finger of the dominant hand.
SeqB: Both groups participated in an educational session.

SeqA: Both groups participated in an educational session.
SeqB: The following were measured in both groups: pain (using a numbered scale), grip and pinch strength, function (measuring the ability to move and use the hand for daily activities), and manual performance (using a timed test that involves picking up, holding, and operating small objects).

SeqA: Outcomes and measures: The following parameters were measured: pain (numerical rating scale, Australian/Canadian Osteoarthritis Hand Index), grip and pinch strength, function (Cochin Hand Functional Scale), and manual performance (Moberg Pick Up Test).
SeqB: The intervention group (group that used the orthoses) showed a significant improvement in pain and hand function.

SeqA: Results:
SeqB: The improvement in pain matched with measures of movement and the absence of nodes in the middle of the finger on the third finger.

SeqA: The intervention group showed a statistically significant improvement in pain (p < .001) and hand function.
SeqB: This study shows that nighttime orthoses are effective in reducing pain and lead to improvement in hand function in women with hand osteoarthritis.

SeqA: The improvement in pain correlated with Cochin Hand Functional Scale scores and the absence of Bouchard's nodes in the third finger, which are predictors of the best prognosis for treatment with a nighttime orthosis.
SeqB: They are therefore specifically recommended for treatment of hand osteoarthritis that does not involve medications.

SeqA: Conclusions and relevance: This study demonstrates that nighttime orthoses are effective in reducing pain and lead to improvement in hand function in women with hand OA.
SeqB: Orthoses can be considered, together with manual exercises and joint protection, as a way to reduce symptoms and improve hand function in people with hand osteoarthritis.

SeqA: The main source of energy for brain and other organs is glucose.
SeqB: The main source of energy for the brain and other organs is glucose, a type of sugar in the blood that comes from the food people eat.

SeqA: To obtain energy for all tissue, glucose has to come through glycolysis; then as pyruvate it is converted to acetyl-CoA by pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (PDC) and finally enters citric acid cycle.
SeqB: In order for energy to reach all tissues, glucose has to go through a process with several stages.

SeqA: What happens when one of these stages become disturb?
SeqB: One of these stages is called pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (PDC) which converts molecules and links cells to the final stage of creating energy.

SeqA: Mutation in genes encoding subunits of PDC leads to pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency.
SeqB: What happens when one of these stages is disturbed?

SeqA: Abnormalities in PDC activity result in severe metabolic and brain malformations.
SeqB: Genetic changes in the PDC process leads to pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency, a disease where the body cannot properly breakdown food to create fuel or energy.

SeqA: For better understanding the development and mechanism of pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency the murine model of this disease has been created.
SeqB: Errors in PDC (pyruvate dehydrogenase complex) activity also result in severe disruption of the body's ability to process and distribute nutrients and can create brain malformations where the brain or nervous system is damaged or has not formed properly during pregnancy.

SeqA: Studies on a murine model showed similar malformation in brain structures as in the patients suffered from pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency such as reduced neuronal density, heterotopias of grey matter, reduced size of corpus callosum and pyramids.
SeqB: To better understand the pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency, researchers created an experiment that includes common household rats and mice.

SeqA: There is still no effective cure for PDC-deficiency.
SeqB: Studies using an animal experiment showed similar abnormalities in brain structures compared to patients suffering from pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency.

SeqA: Promising therapy seemed to be ketogenic diet, which substitutes glucose to ketone bodies as a source of energy.
SeqB: There is still no effective cure for pyruvate dehydrogenase complex-deficiency.

SeqA: Treatment of PDH deficiency rarely influences the course of the disease.

SeqA: Background: The pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (PDC) catalyzes the irreversible decarboxylation of pyruvate into acetyl-CoA. PDC deficiency can be caused by alterations in any of the genes encoding its several subunits.
SeqB: The pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (PDC) is a chemical process in the body that converts molecules and links cells to the final stage of creating energy.

SeqA: The resulting phenotype, though very heterogeneous, mainly affects the central nervous system.
SeqB: PDC deficiency or shortage is a disorder that can be caused by changes in genes.

SeqA: The aim of this study is to describe and discuss the clinical, biochemical and genotypic information from thirteen PDC deficient patients, thus seeking to establish possible genotype-phenotype correlations.
SeqB: The result of PDC deficiency mainly affects the central nervous system (the spinal cord and brain).

SeqA: Results:
SeqB: This study aims to describe the clinical, biochemical (the chemical processes in living organisms), and genetic information in 13 patients with pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (PDC) deficiency.

SeqA: The mutational spectrum showed that seven patients carry mutations in the PDHA1 gene encoding the E1?? subunit, five patients carry mutations in the PDHX gene encoding the E3 binding protein, and the remaining patient carries mutations in the DLD gene encoding the E3 subunit.
SeqB: All 13 patients carry some type of mutation in the genes that are involved in the PDC process.

SeqA: These data corroborate earlier reports describing PDHA1 mutations as the predominant cause of PDC deficiency but also reveal a notable prevalence of PDHX mutations among Portuguese patients, most of them carrying what seems to be a private mutation (p.R284X).
SeqB: The mutation in the PDHA1 gene (a gene that helps encode a building block of PDC) is the most common.

SeqA: The biochemical analyses revealed high lactate and pyruvate plasma levels whereas the lactate/pyruvate ratio was below 16; enzymatic activities, when compared to control values, indicated to be independent from the genotype and ranged from 8.5% to 30%, the latter being considered a cut-off value for primary PDC deficiency.
SeqB: These data support earlier reports describing PDHA1 mutations as the main cause of PDC deficiency.

SeqA: Concerning the clinical features, all patients displayed psychomotor retardation/developmental delay, the severity of which seems to correlate with the type and localization of the mutation carried by the patient.
SeqB: The data also reveal a notable frequency of the PDHX mutation (another gene that helps encode a building block of PDC) among Portuguese patients who seem to carry a mutation in the community or population.

SeqA: The therapeutic options essentially include the administration of a ketogenic diet and supplementation with thiamine, although arginine aspartate intake revealed to be beneficial in some patients.
SeqB: The biochemical analysis showed high levels of lactic acid (high levels occur when oxygen in the body decreases) and high levels of pyruvate plasma (a molecule that helps change sugar in the blood to energy when oxygen levels are low).

SeqA: Moreover, in silico analysis of the missense mutations present in this PDC deficient population allowed to envisage the molecular mechanism underlying these pathogenic variants.
SeqB: All patients showed developmental delay (delays or slowness in reaching language, thinking, or motor skills).

SeqA: Conclusion: The identification of the disease-causing mutations, together with the functional and structural characterization of the mutant protein variants, allow to obtain an insight on the severity of the clinical phenotype and the selection of the most appropriate therapy.
SeqB: How serious these delays are seems to match up with the type and location of the mutation carried by the patient.

SeqA: Background: The pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (PDC) catalyzes the irreversible decarboxylation of pyruvate into acetyl-CoA. PDC deficiency can be caused by alterations in any of the genes encoding its several subunits.
SeqB: The pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (PDC) quickens the permanent conversion of pyruvate (a particle used for energy-production) into acetyl-CoA (another particle used for energy production).

SeqA: The resulting phenotype, though very heterogeneous, mainly affects the central nervous system.
SeqB: PDC shortage can occur from changes in genes involved in creating its components.

SeqA: The aim of this study is to describe and discuss the clinical, biochemical and genotypic information from thirteen PDC deficient patients, thus seeking to establish possible genotype-phenotype correlations.
SeqB: The resulting physical traits, though very different, mainly affect the brain and spinal cord.

SeqA: Results:
SeqB: This study explores the medical, biochemical and gene-related information from thirteen PDC scarce patients.

SeqA: The mutational spectrum showed that seven patients carry mutations in the PDHA1 gene encoding the E1?? subunit, five patients carry mutations in the PDHX gene encoding the E3 binding protein, and the remaining patient carries mutations in the DLD gene encoding the E3 subunit.
SeqB: The study seeks to create possible gene-physical trait connections.

SeqA: These data corroborate earlier reports describing PDHA1 mutations as the predominant cause of PDC deficiency but also reveal a notable prevalence of PDHX mutations among Portuguese patients, most of them carrying what seems to be a private mutation (p.R284X).
SeqB: The data agrees with earlier reports describing a specfic gene's sequence changes as the main cause of PDC shortage.

SeqA: The biochemical analyses revealed high lactate and pyruvate plasma levels whereas the lactate/pyruvate ratio was below 16; enzymatic activities, when compared to control values, indicated to be independent from the genotype and ranged from 8.5% to 30%, the latter being considered a cut-off value for primary PDC deficiency.
SeqB: However, the results also reveal a large presence of another gene's sequence changes among Portuguese patients.

SeqA: Concerning the clinical features, all patients displayed psychomotor retardation/developmental delay, the severity of which seems to correlate with the type and localization of the mutation carried by the patient.
SeqB: Most carry a possibly private gene sequence change.

SeqA: The therapeutic options essentially include the administration of a ketogenic diet and supplementation with thiamine, although arginine aspartate intake revealed to be beneficial in some patients.
SeqB: Regarding medical characteristics, all patients show coordination setback, the intensity of which seems to parallel the type and location of the patient's gene sequence change.

SeqA: Moreover, in silico analysis of the missense mutations present in this PDC deficient population allowed to envisage the molecular mechanism underlying these pathogenic variants.
SeqB: Treatment options include administration of a low-carb diet and thiamine, although arginine aspartate may also help.

SeqA: Conclusion: The identification of the disease-causing mutations, together with the functional and structural characterization of the mutant protein variants, allow to obtain an insight on the severity of the clinical phenotype and the selection of the most appropriate therapy.
SeqB: Identifying disease-causing gene sequence changes, along with the altered cellular substances, help explain the physical traits caused by the disease and select the best treatment.

SeqB: After being stable and fasting (no food or drinks), feeding with PediaSure?? resulted in the recurrence of lactic acidosis (lactic acid build up that can cause nausea, vomiting, and breathing problem).

SeqB: The MRI (scanned image) of the brain was normal.

SeqA: A metabolic workup revealed an elevated serum pyruvate level.

SeqB: A normal brain MRI is reported in only 2% of patients with PDCD.

SeqA: The severity of PDCD can range from neonatal death to more delayed onset of symptoms as in our index case.

SeqA: Metabolic epilepsies arise in the context of rare inborn errors of metabolism (IEM), notably glucose transporter type 1 deficiency syndrome, succinic semialdehyde dehydrogenase deficiency, pyruvate dehydrogenase complex deficiency, nonketotic hyperglycinemia, and mitochondrial cytopathies.
SeqB: Metabolic epilepsies (seizures) arise in the context of rare hereditary or inborn errors of metabolism (IEM) and can be caused in rare disorders.

SeqA: A common feature of these disorders is impaired bioenergetics, which through incompletely defined mechanisms result in a wide spectrum of neurological symptoms, such as epileptic seizures, developmental delay, and movement disorders.
SeqB: A common feature of these disorders is they cause brain-related symptoms, such as epileptic seizures, developmental delay (delays in reaching language, thinking, social, or motor skills), and movement disorders.

SeqA: The ketogenic diet (KD) has been successfully utilized to treat such conditions to varying degrees.
SeqB: The ketogenic diet, a low-carb/high-fat diet, has been successfully used to treat such conditions.

SeqA: While the mechanisms underlying the clinical efficacy of the KD in IEM remain unclear, it is likely that the proposed heterogeneous targets influenced by the KD work in concert to rectify or ameliorate the downstream negative consequences of genetic mutations affecting key metabolic enzymes and substrates-such as oxidative stress and cell death.
SeqB: How a ketogenic diet exactly impacts inborn errors of metabolism is not known, but it is likely that they influence the negative impacts of genetic mutations.

SeqA: These beneficial effects can be broadly grouped into restoration of impaired bioenergetics and synaptic dysfunction, improved redox homeostasis, anti-inflammatory, and epigenetic activity.
SeqB: Benefits of a ketogenic diet are broadly grouped into restoration of parts of metabolism that are impaired, improved maintenance of cells and cells processes, reduced pain and swelling, and processes that control gene activity without changing the DNA.

SeqA: Hence, it is conceivable that the KD might prove useful in other metabolic disorders that present with epileptic seizures.
SeqB: It is possible that a ketogenic diet may be useful in other disorders of metabolism that include epileptic seizures.

SeqA: At the same time, however, there are notable contraindications to KD use, such as fatty acid oxidation disorders.
SeqB: At the same time, there are some disorders where ketogenic diets should be avoided.

SeqA: Clearly, more research is needed to better characterize those metabolic epilepsies that would be amenable to ketogenic therapies, both experimentally and clinically.
SeqB: More research is needed to better describe metabolic epilepsies that would benefit from a ketogenic diet.

SeqA: In the end, the expanded knowledge base will be critical to designing metabolism-based treatments that can afford greater clinical efficacy and tolerability compared to current KD approaches, and improved long-term outcomes for patients.
SeqB: Expanding knowledge will be important to design metabolism-based treatments.

SeqA: Metabolic epilepsies arise in the context of rare inborn errors of metabolism (IEM), notably glucose transporter type 1 deficiency syndrome, succinic semialdehyde dehydrogenase deficiency, pyruvate dehydrogenase complex deficiency, nonketotic hyperglycinemia, and mitochondrial cytopathies.

SeqA: These beneficial effects can be broadly grouped into restoration of impaired bioenergetics and synaptic dysfunction, improved redox homeostasis, anti-inflammatory, and epigenetic activity.

SeqA: We determined the ability of self-complementary adeno-associated virus (scAAV) vectors to deliver and express the pyruvate dehydrogenase E1alpha subunit gene (PDHA1) in primary cultures of skin fibroblasts from 3 patients with defined mutations in PHDA1 and 3 healthy subjects.

SeqB: Cells are given genetic material with scAAV vectors containing a gene that creates proteins.

SeqA: The transduction efficiency of scAAV2 and scAAV6 vectors was 3- to 5-fold higher than that of the other serotypes, which were subsequently used to transduce fibroblasts with wild-type PDHA1 cDNA under the control of the chicken beta-action (CBA) promoter at a vector:cell ratio of 1000.

SeqB: The use of dichloroacetate did increase productivity of pyruvate dehydrogenase in cells with damaged genes involved in metabolism.

SeqA: Exposure of transduced patient fibroblasts to DCA increased PDH activity up to 90% of the activity measured in untreated control cells.
SeqB: This study shows that a combination of gene therapy and drugs may be a promising treatment for people with pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency or shortage.

SeqA: The coronavirus are a wide group of viruses among that the SARS-CoV-2 is included (family Coronaviridae, subfamily Coronavirinae, genus Betacoronavirus and subgenus Sarbecovirus).

SeqA: Natural killer (NK) cells are important early responders against viral infections.

SeqB: Using an animal model for study, researchers show that after infection, NK cells increase uptake of nutrients and reprogram how cells in metabolism work.

SeqA: As COVID-19 continues to spread rapidly worldwide and variants continue to emerge, the development and deployment of safe and effective vaccines are urgently needed.

SeqA: Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) caused by a novel betacoronavirus SARS-CoV-2 has been an ongoing global pandemic.

SeqA: Further, vitamin D modulates multiple mechanisms of the immune system to contain the virus that includes dampening the entry and replication of SARS-CoV-2, reduces concentration of pro-inflammatory cytokines and increases levels of anti-inflammatory cytokines, enhances the production of natural antimicrobial peptide and activates defensive cells such as macrophages that could destroy SARS-CoV-2.
SeqB: Vitamin D controls several processes of the immune system to minimize the virus.

SeqA: The COVID-19 epidemic is the greatest pandemic that human kind experienced for decades, with high morbidity and mortality.

SeqA: Despite recent development of vaccines there is still many severe cases of COVID-19.

SeqA: The aim of this study is to indicate if herbs administered alone or as a complementary therapy could be used as prophylaxis or treatment of SARS-CoV-2 infection.
SeqB: This study aims to find out if herbs given by themselves or as part of a combination of treatments can be used to prevent or treat SARS-CoV-2 infection (the novel coronavirus that can lead to COVID-19).

SeqA: Over 85% of patients with COVID-19 in China used Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM), and a most common herb is Glycyrrhiza glabra, which in vitro inhibits replication of different enveloped viruses, including coronaviruses.
SeqB: A very common herb is Glycyrrhiza glabra (a root also known as liquorice), which in vitro (experiments in test tubes) stops or slows replication of different viruses, including coronaviruses.

SeqA: Glycyrrhizin in vitro connects and changes conformation of ACE2 receptors, which are vital for SARS-CoV-2 penetration into host cells.
SeqB: In experiments outside of the body, liquorice connects and changes the structure of ACE2 receptors, which are proteins that allow SARS-CoV-2 to enter cells.

SeqA: Pelargonium sidoides show immunomodulatory and antiviral properties in clinical and in vitro studies, and it inhibits replication of HCo-229E coronavirus.
SeqB: Pelargonium sidoides (an herb from a plant also known as African geranium) is able to change the response of the immune system and has antiviral (infection fighting) properties in clinical and lab studies.

SeqA: Glycyrrhiza glabra in combination with standard therapies significantly reduces the hospitalization rate and occurrence of COVID-19 symptoms.
SeqB: It slows or stops replication of HCo-229E coronavirus, a type of coronavirus that infects humans and bats.

SeqA: As complementary therapies lianhuaqingwen capsules and jinhua qinggan granules reduces hospitalization rates, time to symptoms recovery and improve patient psychological comfort.
SeqB: Glycyrrhiza glabra, or liquorice, in combination with standard therapies significantly reduces hospitalizations and occurrence of COVID-19 symptoms.

SeqA: In view of SARS-CoV-2 other herbs are not effective, e.g. maxingshigan-yinqiaosan, or therapeutic concentration would be impossible to achieve, e.g. ephedra herb, or there is simply no proper data.
SeqB: Additional therapies based on a traditional Chinese medicine, lianhuaqingwen capsules and jinhua qinggan granules, reduces the number of hospitalizations and the time it takes to recover from symptoms.

SeqA: Therefore, Liquorice and Pelargonium sidoides are effective against coronaviruses and could be possibly used as prophylaxis and treatment of COVID-19, while lianhuaqingwen capsules and jinhua qinggan granules can be useful as a complementary therapy to conventional treatment.
SeqB: There are some herbs that are either not effective, would be impossible to get enough of into the body safely, or are not usefully documented to fight SARS-CoV-2.

SeqA: Potassium is mainly an intracellular ion.
SeqB: Potassium is mainly an ion (an atom or molecule that carries an electrical charge) within a body of water within cells.

SeqA: The sodium-potassium adenosine triphosphatase pump has the primary responsibility for regulating the homeostasis between sodium and potassium, which pumps out sodium in exchange for potassium, which moves into the cells.
SeqB: A protein pump in cells called the sodium-potassium pump regulates and moves sodium and potassium in and out of cells.

SeqA: In the kidneys, the filtration of potassium takes place at the glomerulus.
SeqB: In the kidneys, the filtering and moving of potassium takes place at the glomerulus, a cluster of tiny blood cells.

SeqA: The reabsorption of potassium takes place at the proximal convoluted tubule and thick ascending loop of Henle.
SeqB: Potassium is reabsorbed at the proximal convoluted tubule (in a filtering unit called the nephron that is part of the kidneys) and the thick ascending loop of Henle (a part of the nephron in the kidneys).

SeqA: Potassium secretion occurs at the distal convoluted tubule.
SeqB: Potassium is released at the distal convoluted tubule (a portion of the kidney nephron that functions in both absorption and secretion or release).

SeqA: Aldosterone increases potassium secretion.
SeqB: A hormone called aldosterone increases the release of potassium.

SeqA: Potassium channels and potassium-chloride cotransporters at the apical membrane also secrete potassium.
SeqB: Potassium is also released through protein channels that allow potassium molecules to pass through the cells and cell boundaries.

SeqA: Potassium disorders are related to cardiac arrhythmias.
SeqB: Potassium disorders are related to cardiac arrhythmias (irregular heart beats).

SeqA: Hypokalemia occurs when serum potassium levels under 3.6 mmol/L??weakness, fatigue, and muscle twitching present in hypokalemia.
SeqB: Hypokalemia occurs when there are low potassium levels in the blood and results in weakness, fatigue, and muscle twitching.

SeqA: Total-body potassium (K+) content and appropriate distribution of K+ across the cell membrane is vitally important for normal cellular function.
SeqB: The total-body content of potassium (K+) and distribution of K+ across the cell membranes (the thick layer that surrounds cells) is very important for normal functioning of the body's cells.

SeqA: Total-body K+ content is determined by changes in excretion of K+ by the kidneys in response to intake levels.
SeqB: Total-body K+ content (a method for measuring body composition and mass of cells) is determined by changes in the release of K+ by the kidneys in response to how much K+ is taken in.

SeqA: Under normal conditions, insulin and ??-adrenergic tone also make important contributions in maintaining internal distribution of K+.
SeqB: Insulin (a hormone that allows the cells in the muscles, fat, and liver to absorb sugar from the blood) and ??-adrenergic tone (a group of organs and nerves where hormones are able to signal to other cells) also help keep potassium (K+) distribution at normal levels.

SeqA: However, despite these homeostatic pathways, disorders of altered K+ homeostasis are common.
SeqB: Despite these different systems, disorders of changing K+ levels are common.

SeqA: Appreciating the pathophysiology and regulatory influences that determine the internal distribution and external balance of K+ is critical in designing effective treatments to restore K+ homeostasis.
SeqB: Understanding the pathophysiology (physical changes that come with a particular syndrome or disease) and regulating processes that determine how the body distributes and balances K+ is key to developing treatments to restore K+ homeostasis (processes used by the body to maintain a normal potassium concentration in the fluid).

SeqA: We provide an up-to-date review of the regulatory aspects of normal K+ physiology as a preface to highlighting common disorders in K+ homeostasis and their treatment.
SeqB: Researchers review the normal regulating process of total-body potassium (K+) before highlighting common disorders in K+ homeostasis and their treatment.

SeqA: This review of K+ homeostasis is designed as a resource for clinicians and a tool for educators who are teaching trainees to understand the pivotal factors involved in K+ balance.
SeqB: This review of K+ homeostasis is a resource for health care providers and a tool for educators teaching students to understand key factors involved in K+ balance.

SeqA: Total-body potassium (K+) content and appropriate distribution of K+ across the cell membrane is vitally important for normal cellular function.
SeqB: Full-body potassium (K+) content and appropriate distribution of K+ across cell boudaries is important for normal cellular function.

SeqA: Total-body K+ content is determined by changes in excretion of K+ by the kidneys in response to intake levels.
SeqB: Total-body K+ content is measured by changes in the removal of K+ by the kidneys in response to intake levels.

SeqA: Under normal conditions, insulin and ??-adrenergic tone also make important contributions in maintaining internal distribution of K+.
SeqB: Normally, insulin (a blood sugar-monitoring protein) and nerve-related, stimulating activity also contribute to maintaing internal potassium distribution.

SeqA: However, despite these homeostatic pathways, disorders of altered K+ homeostasis are common.
SeqB: Despite these balance-maintaining pathways, disorders of altered potassium balance are common.

SeqA: Appreciating the pathophysiology and regulatory influences that determine the internal distribution and external balance of K+ is critical in designing effective treatments to restore K+ homeostasis.
SeqB: Understanding the biological distribution and balance of K+ is crucial to designing treatments for it.

SeqA: We provide an up-to-date review of the regulatory aspects of normal K+ physiology as a preface to highlighting common disorders in K+ homeostasis and their treatment.
SeqB: We review the current biology of K+ to introduce common disorders in K+ balance and their treatment.

SeqA: Histone deacetylase (HDAC) enzymes regulate transcription through epigenetic modification of chromatin structure, but their specific functions in the kidney remain elusive.
SeqB: Histone deacetylase (HDAC) are enzymes that control transcription (the process of copying a segment of DNA into messenger RNA, or mRNA, for protein creation), but their specific functions in the kidney are unknown.

SeqA: We discovered that the human kidney expresses class I HDACs.
SeqB: Researchers discovered that the human kidney uses class I HDACs to activate or build molecules or proteins.

SeqA: Kidney medulla-specific inhibition of class I HDACs in the rat during high-salt feeding results in hypertension, polyuria, hypokalemia, and nitric oxide deficiency.
SeqB: The slowing or stopping of class I HDACs from the kidney medulla region in rats during high-salt feedings results in diseases such as hypertension (high blood pressure) and hypokalemia (low levels of potassium in the blood).

SeqA: Three new inducible murine models were used to determine that HDAC1 and HDAC2 in the kidney epithelium are necessary for maintaining epithelial integrity and maintaining fluid-electrolyte balance during increased dietary sodium intake.
SeqB: Three new animal studies are used to determine that HDAC1 and HDAC2 in the kidney epithelium (cells that cover the inner surface of organs) are necessary for maintaining electrolyte (minerals in the body) balance when the body takes in increased sodium.

SeqA: Moreover, single-nucleus RNA-sequencing determined that epithelial HDAC1 and HDAC2 are necessary for expression of many sodium or water transporters and channels.
SeqB: Additionally, epithelial HDAC1 and HDAC2 are necessary for activating many sodium or water transporters and channels across cells.

SeqA: In performing a systematic review and meta-analysis of serious adverse events associated with clinical HDAC inhibitor use, we found that HDAC inhibitors increased the odds ratio of experiencing fluid-electrolyte disorders, such as hypokalemia.
SeqB: In reviewing all relevant studies of serious side effects connected with clinical HDAC inhibitor use, researchers found that HDAC inhibitors (molecules or enzymes that block actions of an enzyme protein) increased the chance of experiencing fluid-electrolyte disorders (a group of conditions caused by a temporary disturbance in the body's levels of fluids and electrolytes), such as hypokalemia.

SeqA: This study provides insight on the mechanisms of potential serious adverse events with HDAC inhibitors, which may be fatal to critically ill patients.
SeqB: This study provides a greater understanding of potential serious side effects with HDAC inhibitors, which may be fatal to very ill patients.

SeqA: In conclusion, kidney tubular HDACs provide a link between the environment, such as consumption of high-salt diets, and regulation of homeostatic mechanisms to remain in fluid-electrolyte balance.
SeqB: In conclusion, HDACs from the kidney provide a link between the environment, such as consuming high-salt diets, and regulating processes to stay in fluid-electrolyte balance.

SeqA: Background: The basolateral potassium channel in the distal convoluted tubule (DCT), comprising the inwardly rectifying potassium channel Kir4.1/Kir5.1 heterotetramer, plays a key role in mediating the effect of dietary potassium intake on the thiazide-sensitive NaCl cotransporter (NCC).
SeqB: Potassium channels are proteins that allow rapid and careful flow of potassium ions (an atom that carries an electrical charge) across the cell boundary and generates electrical signals in cells.

SeqA: The role of Kir5.1 (encoded by Kcnj16) in mediating effects of dietary potassium intake on the NCC and renal potassium excretion is unknown.
SeqB: Two potassium channels located in cells of the kidneys called potassium channels Kir4.1 and Kir5.1 play a key role on controlling how potassium from foods affect how salt is reabsorbed.

SeqA: Methods: We used electrophysiology, renal clearance, and immunoblotting to study Kir4.1 in the DCT and NCC in Kir5.1 knockout (Kcnj16-/- ) and wild-type (Kcnj16+/+ ) mice fed with normal, high, or low potassium diets.
SeqB: The role of Kir5.1 in how it passes on potassium from foods in the kidneys and how it releases potassium is unknown.

SeqA: Results:
SeqB: Researchers studied Kir4.1 and Kir5.1 in different parts of the kidneys by using two different types of mice (called wild-type mice - or normal mice - and knockout mice - mice without a specific gene like the one encoding Kir5.1)

SeqA: We detected a 40-pS and 20-pS potassium channel in the basolateral membrane of the DCT in wild-type and knockout mice, respectively.
SeqB: fed with normal, high, or low potassium diets.

SeqA: Compared with wild-type, Kcnj16-/- mice fed a normal potassium diet had higher basolateral potassium conductance, a more negative DCT membrane potential, higher expression of phosphorylated NCC (pNCC) and total NCC (tNCC), and augmented thiazide-induced natriuresis.
SeqB: When compared with the wild-type mice, the knockout mice that were fed a normal potassium diet had higher transmission of potassium, had more negative charges in some cell boundaries or membranes, had higher activation of major salt reabsorption pathways, and had an increase in the release of sodium in the urine.

SeqA: Neither high- nor low-potassium diets affected the basolateral DCT's potassium conductance and membrane potential in Kcnj16-/- mice.
SeqB: Neither a diet high nor low in potassium affected the potassium channel that is located at the base or sides of the cell or the negative charges in the cell membranes in the knockout mice.

SeqA: Although high potassium reduced and low potassium increased the expression of pNCC and tNCC in wild-type mice, these effects were absent in Kcnj16-/- mice.
SeqB: Although high potassium reduced activation of major salt reabsorption pathways and low potassium increased activation of major salt reabsorption pathways in wild-type mice, these effects were not found in the knockout mice.

SeqA: High potassium intake inhibited and low intake augmented thiazide-induced natriuresis in wild-type but not in Kcnj16-/- mice.
SeqB: High potassium diets slowed or stopped release of sodium in the urine while low potassium diets increased the release of sodium in the urine in wild-type mice but not in knock-out mice.

SeqA: Compared with wild-type, Kcnj16-/- mice with normal potassium intake had slightly lower plasma potassium but were more hyperkalemic with prolonged high potassium intake and more hypokalemic during potassium restriction.
SeqB: When compared with wild-type mice, knockout mice who had normal potassium level diets had slightly lower plasma potassium (potassium in the blood).

SeqA: Conclusions: Kir5.1 is essential for dietary potassium's effect on NCC and for maintaining potassium homeostasis.
SeqB: However, knockout mice were more hyperkalemic (having a higher than normal level of potassium in the bloodstream) with a long, high potassium diet and hypokalemic (having a lower than normal level of potassium in the blood) with a restricted potassium diet.

SeqA: Kidneys play a pivotal role in the maintenance and regulation of acid-base and electrolyte homeostasis, which is the prerequisite for numerous metabolic processes and organ functions in the human body.
SeqB: Kidneys play a major role in the maintenance and control of acid-base homeostasis (having the right amount of acid and base in the blood and other body fluids) and electrolyte homeostasis (the correct concentration of different ions in the body, such as sodium and potassium), which is required for metabolism and other organ functions.

SeqA: Chronic kidney diseases compromise the regulatory functions, resulting in alterations in electrolyte and acid-base balance that can be life-threatening.
SeqB: Chronic (long-lasting or recurring) kidney diseases weakens the regulatory functions and leads to changes in electrolyte and acid-base balance, which can be life-threatening.

SeqA: In this review, we discuss the renal regulations of electrolyte and acid-base balance and several common disorders including metabolic acidosis, alkalosis, dysnatremia, dyskalemia, and dysmagnesemia.
SeqB: In this review, researchers discuss renal (kidney-related) control functions of electrolyte and acid-base balance and several common disorders, such as disorders with too much acid or base in body fluids, or low potassium levels.

SeqA: Common disorders in chronic kidney disease are also discussed.
SeqB: Common disorders in chronic kidney disease are also discussed.

SeqA: The most recent and relevant advances on pathophysiology, clinical characteristics, diagnosis, and management of these conditions have been incorporated.
SeqB: The most recent and important advances on pathophysiology (functional changes that come with a particular syndrome or disease), clinical characteristics (symptoms and results from lab tests), diagnosis, and management of these conditions have been incorporated.

SeqA: Kidneys play a pivotal role in the maintenance and regulation of acid-base and electrolyte homeostasis, which is the prerequisite for numerous metabolic processes and organ functions in the human body.
SeqB: Kidneys play an important role in monitoring acid-base and electrolyte balance, which is a requirement for many metabolic processes and organ functions in the human body.

SeqA: Chronic kidney diseases compromise the regulatory functions, resulting in alterations in electrolyte and acid-base balance that can be life-threatening.
SeqB: Long-lasting kidney diseases threaten the regulatory functions, leading to changes in electrolyte and acid-base balance that can be life-threatening.

SeqA: In this review, we discuss the renal regulations of electrolyte and acid-base balance and several common disorders including metabolic acidosis, alkalosis, dysnatremia, dyskalemia, and dysmagnesemia.
SeqB: We review the kidney's regulation of electrolyte and acid-base balance and disorders involving their imbalances.

SeqA: Common disorders in chronic kidney disease are also discussed.
SeqB: Common, long-lasting kidney disorders are also discussed.

SeqA: The most recent and relevant advances on pathophysiology, clinical characteristics, diagnosis, and management of these conditions have been incorporated.
SeqB: The most recent and relevant treatments on the biology and treatment of these conditions have been included.

SeqA: Potassium is the most abundant cation in the intracellular fluid and it plays a vital role in the maintenance of normal cell functions.
SeqB: There is a lot of potassium (a mineral the body needs to function well) in the fluid within cells.

SeqA: Thus, potassium homeostasis across the cell membrane, is very critical because a tilt in this balance can result in different diseases that could be life threatening.
SeqB: It plays a key role in the maintenance of normal cell functions and processes.

SeqA: Both Oxidative stress (OS) and potassium imbalance can cause life threatening health conditions.
SeqB: Therefore, potassium homeostasis (the correct balance of potassium in the body that is important for cell function) is very critical because a change in this balance can lead to different diseases, some that are life-threatening.

SeqA: OS and abnormalities in potassium channel have been reported in neurodegenerative diseases.
SeqB: Oxidative stress (a condition that happens when the body has low antioxidant levels, vitamins, minerals, and other nutrients that protect and repair cells), and potassium imbalance (levels of potassium that are not normal) can cause life threatening health conditions.

SeqA: This review highlights the major factors involved in potassium homeostasis (dietary, hormonal, genetic, and physiologic influences), and discusses the major diseases and abnormalities associated with potassium imbalance including hypokalemia, hyperkalemia, hypertension, chronic kidney disease, and Gordon's syndrome, Bartter syndrome, and Gitelman syndrome.
SeqB: Oxidative stress and changes in how potassium passes through cells are reported in neurodegenerative diseases (diseases such as Alzheimer's where nerve cells deteriorate or die).

SeqA: Background: Potassium (K(+)) is the major intracellular cation, with 98% of the total pool being located in the cells at a concentration of 140-150 mmol/l, and only 2% in the extracellular fluid, where it ranges between 3.5 and 5 mmol/l. A fine regulation of the intracellular-extracellular gradient is crucial for life, as it is the main determinant of membrane voltage; in fact, acute changes of K(+) plasma levels may have fatal consequences.
SeqB: There is a large amount of potassium (a mineral the body needs to function properly) in the fluid within cells.

SeqA: Summary: An integrated system including an 'internal' and 'external' control prevents significant fluctuations of plasma levels in conditions of K(+) loading and depletion.
SeqB: Regulating or monitoring how potassium passes in and out of cells is very important, so sudden or major changes of potassium levels in the blood may be life-threatening.

SeqA: The internal control regulates the intra-extracellular shift, a temporary mechanism able to maintain a constant K(+) plasma concentration without changing the total amount of body K(+).
SeqB: The body has a system with 'internal' and 'external' controls that prevents changes of blood levels when potassium is increasing or decreasing.

SeqA: The external control is responsible for the excretion of the ingested K(+), and it has the kidney as the major player.
SeqB: The 'internal' control monitors the change in potassium as it moves in and out of cells to help maintain a stable level of potassium.

SeqA: The kidney excretes nearly 90% of the daily intake.
SeqB: The 'external' control is responsible for excreting (releasing) the potassium, and the kidney is the main part of this process.

SeqA: Along the proximal tubule and the thick ascending limb on Henle's loop, the amount of K(+) reabsorption is quite fixed (about 80-90%); conversely, the distal nephron has the ability to adjust K(+) excretion in accordance with homeostatic needs.
SeqB: The kidney releases nearly 90% of the daily intake of potassium.

SeqA: The present review analyzes: (1) the main molecular mechanisms mediating K(+) reabsorption and secretion along the nephron; (2) the pathophysiology of the principal K(+) derangements due to renal dysfunction, and (3) the effect of ingested K(+) on blood pressure and renal electrolyte handling.
SeqB: In some parts within the kidney, potassium is reabsorbed at a fixed or constant amount, but other portions of the kidneys have the ability to adjust the release of potassium based on what is needed to maintain a potassium balance.

SeqA: Key messages: Maintaining plasma K(+) levels in a tight range is crucial for life; thus, multiple factors are implicated in K(+) homeostasis, including kidney function.
SeqB: This review analyzes the following: (1) the cell processes that reabsorb and release potassium along the nephron (a filter located in the kidneys); (2) the pathophysiology (functional changes in the body that come with a particular syndrome or disease) from renal (kidney-related) problems; and (3) the effect of ingested potassium from food on blood pressure and renal electrolytes.

SeqA: Recent studies have suggested that K(+) plasma levels, in turn, affect renal salt absorption in animal models; this effect may underlie the reduction of blood pressure observed in hypertensive subjects under K(+) supplementation.
SeqB: Key messages in this review are that maintaining potassium levels in the blood in a tight range is very important for life.

SeqA: Purpose of review: Renal potassium (K) secretion plays a key role in maintaining K homeostasis.
SeqB: Renal (kidney-related) secretion or release plays a key role in maintaining potassium homeostasis (processes used by the body to maintain a normal potassium concentration in the fluid outside the cells).

SeqA: The classic mechanism of renal K secretion is focused on the connecting tubule and cortical collecting duct, in which K is uptaken by basolateral Na-K-ATPase and is secreted into the lumen by apical ROMK (Kir1.1) and Ca-activated big conductance K channel.
SeqB: Renal release of potassium mainly takes place within the kidneys through as series of tubes and ducts.

SeqA: Recently, genetic studies and animal models have indicated that inwardly rectifying K channel 4.1 (Kir4.1 or Kcnj10) in the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) may play a role in the regulation of K secretion in the aldosterone-sensitive distal nephron by targeting the NaCl cotransporter (NCC).
SeqB: Potassium is absorbed through the potassium channel that is located at the base or sides of the cell called the basolateral and is released into a tube called the lumen through potassium channels.

SeqA: This review summarizes recent progresses regarding the role of Kir4.1 in the regulation of NCC and K secretion.
SeqB: Recent studies have suggested that potassium channels 4.1 (Kir4.1 or Kcnj10) located within the kidney at the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) (which connects to the duct system in the kidneys and helps with salt and water reabsorption) may play a role in regulating the release of potassium by targeting the NaCl cotransporter (NCC) (the carrier protein that helps reabsorb sodium and chloride ions from tube fluid into the cells).

SeqA: Recent findings: Kir4.1 is expressed in the basolateral membrane of the DCT, and plays a predominant role in contributing to the basolateral K conductance and in participating in the generation of negative membrane potential.
SeqB: This review summarizes recent progress on the role of the potassium channel Kir4.1 in the control of NCC and potassium secretion (release).

SeqA: Kir4.1 is also the substrate of src-family tyrosine kinase and the stimulation of src-family tyrosine kinase activates Kir4.1 activity in the DCT.
SeqB: Recent findings show that Kir4.1 is activated in the basolateral membrane (the thin layer surrounding a cell located at the base or sides of the cell) of the distal convoluted tubule (DCT).

SeqA: The genetic deletion or functional inhibition of Kir4.1 depolarizes the membrane of the DCT, inhibits ste20-proline-alanine rich kinase, and suppresses NCC activity.
SeqB: Kir4.1 plays a major role in helping the basolateral pass potassium through the cell and in helping cell membranes have a negative charge.

SeqA: Moreover, the downregulation of Kir4.1 increases epithelial Na channel expression in the collecting duct and urinary K excretion.
SeqB: Kir4.1 also activates proteins that send signals to other cells which in turn activate Kir4.1 activity in the DCT.

SeqA: Finally, mice with low Kir4.1 activity in the DCT are hypomagnesemia and hypokalemia.
SeqB: Kir4.1 depolarizes (changes the internal charge to make the cell less negative) the membrane of the distal convoluted tubule (DCT), slows down other proteins that regulate cell activity, and suppresses NaCl cotransporter activity.

SeqA: Summary:
SeqB: Additionally, the decrease in function of Kir4.1 increases activity of the epithelial Na channel (the lining of the outer part of the kidney tubule) in the ducts and potassium release through urine.

SeqA: Recent progress in exploring the regulation and the function of Kir4.1 in the DCT strongly indicates that Kir4.1plays an important role in initiating the regulation of renal K secretion by targeting NCC and it may serves as a K sensor in the kidney.
SeqB: Finally, mice with low Kir4.1 activity in the DCT are hypomagnesemia (have a low level of the magnesium mineral in the blood) and hypokalemia (have low levels of potassium).

SeqA: Purpose of review: Renal potassium (K) secretion plays a key role in maintaining K homeostasis.
SeqB: Kidney-related potassium (K) secretion helps maintain K balance.

SeqA: The classic mechanism of renal K secretion is focused on the connecting tubule and cortical collecting duct, in which K is uptaken by basolateral Na-K-ATPase and is secreted into the lumen by apical ROMK (Kir1.1) and Ca-activated big conductance K channel.
SeqB: Kidney-related K removal commonly focuses on specific parts of sub-kidney units.

SeqA: Recently, genetic studies and animal models have indicated that inwardly rectifying K channel 4.1 (Kir4.1 or Kcnj10) in the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) may play a role in the regulation of K secretion in the aldosterone-sensitive distal nephron by targeting the NaCl cotransporter (NCC).

SeqA: We recently described a novel thiazide-sensitive electroneutral NaCl transport mechanism resulting from the parallel operation of the Cl-/HCO3- exchanger pendrin and the Na+-driven Cl-/2HCO3- exchanger (NDCBE) in ??-intercalated cells of the collecting duct.

SeqA: Although a role for pendrin in maintaining Na+ balance, intravascular volume, and BP is well supported, there is no in vivo evidence for the role of NDCBE in maintaining Na+ balance.
SeqB: One is called the Na+-driven Cl-/2HCO3- exchanger (NDCBE) that is a protein that exchanges Na+ (sodium) from outside the cell for Cl- (chloride) that is in the cell.

SeqB: There is no lab or test tube experiments that show evidence for the role of Na+-driven Cl-/2HCO3- exchanger (NDCBE) in maintaining a sodium balance.

SeqB: Notably, the increase in aldosterone (a hormone that regulates sodium and potassium levels) expected from the sodium-chloride loss was weakened in Ndcbe/Ncc double-knockout mice.

SeqB: SPAK-KO and kidney-specific OSR1 single knockout mice (mice without OSR1 only in the kidney) maintained potassium in the blood following restrictions of potassium in food, but DKO mice developed severe hypokalemia (low levels of potassium in the blood).
