SeqB: We divided 117 patients hospitalized with serious bedsores in our hospital (January 2019-December 2019) into the Ma Yinglong Musk Hemorrhoid Cream Group (MY Group), Pearl Powder Group (PP Group), and combination with Ma Yinglong Musk Hemorrhoid Cream and Pearl Powder Group (MP group), 39 patients in each group.

SeqA: There was no significant difference in the general data of patients in MY group, PP group, and MP group.
SeqB: Patients in the three groups generally were similar.

SeqA: By analyzing the differences in clinical efficacy, secondary effects, scar incidence, pain, and clinical indicators of patients in the MY group, PP group, and MP group, the effects of Mayinglong Shexiang Hemorrhoid Cream combined with pearl powder in the treatment of pain and complications in patients with severe pressure ulcers were explored.
SeqB: We looked at the effects of Mayinglong Shexiang Hemorrhoid Cream combined with pearl powder in the treatment of pain and side effects in patients with serious bedsores based on differences in how well a treatment works, side effects, scar occurrence, pain, and quality of care of patients in the MY, PP, and MP groups.

SeqA: Results:
SeqB: The MP group treatment worked better than the MY and PP groups.

SeqA: After treatment, compared with the MY group and the PP group, the MP group had a higher clinical efficacy than the MY group and the PP group.
SeqB: The MP group had better healing time and dressing change times than the MY group.

SeqA: Compared with MY group and PP group, the healing time, dressing change times, and dressing change time of MP group were better than MY group (P < .05).
SeqB: The MP group had a better score on a common scoring tool for pain and fewer side effects than the MY and PP groups.

SeqA: After treatment, the VAS score and incidence of secondary effects of the MP group was significantly lower than that of the MY group and PP group (P < .05).
SeqB: The MP group had less occurrence of scars and smaller scar area than the MY and PP groups.

SeqA: The incidence and area of scar formation in the MP group were lower than those in the MY group and the PP group (P < .05).
SeqB: A combination of Ma Yinglong Musk Hemorrhoid Cream and Pearl Powder worked better than either treatment by itself in treating severe bedsore patients, and can significantly reduce pain in the affected area and side effects.

SeqA: Pressure ulcer (PU) is a worldwide problem that is hard to heal because of its prolonged inflammatory response and impaired ECM deposition caused by local hypoxia and repeated ischemia/reperfusion.
SeqB: Bedsores are a worldwide problem that is hard to heal because it causes long-lasting inflammation (redness and swelling from fighting an infection) and harms the extracellular matrix (ECM; secreted by cells and surrounds cells in tissues) from not enough oxygen and blood flow.

SeqA: Our previous study discovered that the non-fouling zwitterionic sulfated poly (sulfobetaine methacrylate) (SBMA) hydrogel can improve PU healing with rapid ECM rebuilding.
SeqB: The study we did before found that non-fouling zwitterionic (inner salts to which proteins and bacteria cannot stick) sulfated poly (sulfobetaine methacrylate) (SBMA) hydrogel can improve bedsore healing and quickly rebuild ECM.

SeqA: However, the mechanism of the SBMA hydrogel in promoting ECM rebuilding is unclear.
SeqB: However, scientists are unsure how SBMA hydrogel rebuilds ECM.

SeqA: Therefore, in this work, the impact of the SBMA hydrogel on ECM reconstruction is comprehensively studied, and the underlying mechanism is intensively investigated in a rat PU model.
SeqB: In this study, we look at how SBMA hydrogel rebuilds ECM using a rat bedsore model.

SeqA: The in vivo data demonstrate that compared to the PEG hydrogel, the SBMA hydrogel enhances the ECM remolding by the upregulation of fibronectin and laminin expression as well as the inhibition of MMP-2.
SeqB: SMBA hydrogel helps remodel ECM better than PEG hydrogel, another bedsore treatment.

SeqA: Further investigation reveals that the decreased MMP-2 expression of zwitterionic SBMA hydrogel treatment is due to the activation of autophagy through the inhibited PI3K/Akt/mTOR signaling pathway and reduced inflammation.
SeqB: The relationship between autophagy (cleaning out of damaged cells) with ECM remodeling may influence the design of wound dressings with substances that interact with biological systems for long-term wound repair.

SeqA: Introduction: Treatment of decubitus ulcers is a grave medical problem.
SeqB: Treatment of bedsores is a serious medical problem.

SeqA: In many cases, it is difficult to cure a pressure ulcer, especially when it is deep and extensive, and prognosis is usually unfavourable.
SeqB: Often, a bedsore is hard to cure, especially when it is deep and covers a large area, and usually has a poor prognosis (plan for recovery).

SeqA: Treatment of decubitus ulcers requires new specialist dressings, which play an important role in the healing process.
SeqB: Treating bedsores requires specialized dressings, which play an important role in the healing process.

SeqA: Aim: To evaluate therapeutic efficacy of active specialist medical dressings in the treatment of decubitus.
SeqB: We aim to rate how well active specialized dressings, which promote healing by keeping the wound moist, work to treat bedsores.

SeqA: Material and methods: Research involved 40 patients - 18 (45%) women and 22 (55%) men, suffering from decubitus ulcers of different size and depth, localized in the sacral region, lasting from 1.5 to 30 months.
SeqB: We looked at 40 patients, 18 (45%) women and 22 (55%) men, with bedsores differing in size and depth, located near the bottom of the spine, lasting from 1.5 to 3.0 months.

SeqA: Patients were randomly assigned to two research groups (20 people each), were treated for 4 weeks with 2 different specialist dressings.
SeqB: We randomly assigned patients to two groups of 20 people each and treated them with two different specialist dressings for 4 weeks.

SeqA: ATRAUMAN Ag, which contains silver ions, was used in the first group, while paraffin gauze of BACTIGRAS type was used in the second group.
SeqB: We used ATRAUMAN ag, which contains silver ions, in the first group and paraffin (waxy) gauze of BACTIGRAS type in the second group.

SeqA: An assessment of pressure ulcers' healing progress was done with a planimetric method, which evaluates the wound surface area.
SeqB: We measured the progress of bedsore healing by measuring the wound's boundaries, which calculates the surface area.

SeqA: Results:
SeqB: Results showed average bedsore surface area significantly decreased in the first group by 60.2% and in the second group by 32.95%, suggesting dressings with silver ions worked better.

SeqA: The analysis results showed a significant statistical decrease in an average decubitus ulcer surface area in both research groups: in the first group by 60.2% (p = 0.001), and in the second group by 32.95% (p < 0.001), which speaks in favour of dressings with silver ions as having better therapeutic effectiveness.
SeqB: We conclude that specialist dressings significantly decrease bedsore surface area, and dressings with silver ions work better than those without.

SeqA: Introduction: Treatment of decubitus ulcers is a grave medical problem.
SeqB: Treating decubitus ulcers (bedsores) is a serious medical problem.

SeqA: In many cases, it is difficult to cure a pressure ulcer, especially when it is deep and extensive, and prognosis is usually unfavourable.
SeqB: In many cases, it is difficult to cure a pressure ulcer or bedsore, especially when it is deep and extensive.

SeqA: Treatment of decubitus ulcers requires new specialist dressings, which play an important role in the healing process.
SeqB: Recovery is usually poor.

SeqA: Aim: To evaluate therapeutic efficacy of active specialist medical dressings in the treatment of decubitus.
SeqB: Treating bedsores requires new specialized dressings (e.g., ointments, gauze), which are important for healing.

SeqA: Material and methods: Research involved 40 patients - 18 (45%) women and 22 (55%) men, suffering from decubitus ulcers of different size and depth, localized in the sacral region, lasting from 1.5 to 30 months.
SeqB: We aim to evaluate the success of active specialized medical dressings for treating bedsores.

SeqA: Patients were randomly assigned to two research groups (20 people each), were treated for 4 weeks with 2 different specialist dressings.
SeqB: Research included 40 patients - 18 (45% women) and 22 (55%) men, suffering from bedsores of various size and depth, in the lower back, lasting from 1.5 to 30 months.

SeqA: ATRAUMAN Ag, which contains silver ions, was used in the first group, while paraffin gauze of BACTIGRAS type was used in the second group.
SeqB: Patients were randomly split to two groups (20 people each) and treated for 4 weeks with either ATRAUMAN Ag, a dressing with silver, or gauze with paraffin (a waxy substance commonly used for coating and sealing candles and rubbers) from BACTIGRAS.

SeqA: An assessment of pressure ulcers' healing progress was done with a planimetric method, which evaluates the wound surface area.
SeqB: Measuring pressure ulcer healing was done by measuring the wound surface area.

SeqA: Results:
SeqB: The results showed a decrease in average bedsore area in both treatment groups: in the first group by 60.2% and in the second group by 32.95%, which speaks in favour of dressings with silver as better treatments.

SeqA: The analysis results showed a significant statistical decrease in an average decubitus ulcer surface area in both research groups: in the first group by 60.2% (p = 0.001), and in the second group by 32.95% (p < 0.001), which speaks in favour of dressings with silver ions as having better therapeutic effectiveness.
SeqB: Using specialized dressings leads to a decrease in bedsore area, depending on the dressing type and substances contained within it.

SeqA: Conclusions: Using specialist dressings results in a significant decrease in the decubitus ulcer surface area, depending on the type of dressing and active substances contained within, while silver ions support curative effectiveness of the dressing used.
SeqB: Silver supports the healing properties of the dressing used.

SeqA: Hypophosphatasia (HPP) is the inborn-error-of-metabolism that features low serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP) activity (hypophosphatasemia) caused by loss-of-function mutation(s) of the gene that encodes the tissue-nonspecific isoenzyme of ALP (TNSALP).
SeqB: Hypophosphatasia (HPP) is a genetic condition that blocks metabolic pathways.

SeqA: Autosomal recessive or autosomal dominant inheritance from among >300 TNSALP (ALPL) mutations largely explains HPP's remarkably broad-ranging severity.
SeqB: HPP features low serum (blood) alkaline phosphatase (ALP - a protein which indicates bone health) activity (hypophosphatasemia).

SeqA: TNSALP is a cell-surface homodimeric phosphohydrolase richly expressed in the skeleton, liver, kidney, and developing teeth.
SeqB: This is caused by mutation(s) of the gene that encodes the tissue-nonspecific isoenzyme (form) of ALP (TNSALP).

SeqA: In HPP, TNSALP substrates accumulate extracellularly.
SeqB: This mutation renders the gene unable to complete it function.

SeqA: Among them is inorganic pyrophosphate (PPi), a potent inhibitor of mineralization.
SeqB: Variations in the type of mutations largely explains HPP's remarkably broad-ranging severity.

SeqA: Superabundance of extracellular PPi explains the hard tissue complications of HPP that feature premature loss of deciduous teeth and often rickets or osteomalacia as well as calcific arthropathies in some affected adults.
SeqB: TNSALP is an enzyme expressed in the skeleton, liver, kidney, and developing teeth.

SeqA: In infants with severe HPP, blocked entry of minerals into the skeleton can cause hypercalcemia, and insufficient hydrolysis of pyridoxal 5'-phosphate (PLP), the major circulating form of vitamin B6, can cause pyridoxine-dependent seizures.
SeqB: In HPP, TNSALP substrates (proteins altered by TNSALP) accumulate outside of cells.

SeqA: Elevated circulating PLP is a sensitive and specific biochemical marker for HPP.
SeqB: One substrate is inorganic pyrophosphate (PPi), a potent inhibitor (blocker) of mineralization.

SeqA: Also, the TNSALP substrate phosphoethanolamine (PEA) is usually elevated in serum and urine in HPP, though less reliably for diagnosis.
SeqB: Superabundance of extracellular PPi explains the hard tissue complications of HPP.

SeqA: Pathognomonic radiographic changes occur in pediatric HPP when the skeletal disease is severe.
SeqB: These complications include premature loss of deciduous teeth, rickets or bone softening, and joint swelling in some affected adults.

SeqA: TNSALP mutation analysis is essential for recurrence risk assessment for HPP in future pregnancies and for prenatal diagnosis.
SeqB: In infants with severe HPP, blocked entry of minerals into the skeleton can cause hypercalcemia (high calcium levels).

SeqA: HPP was the final rickets/osteomalacia to have a medical treatment.
SeqB: Additionally, insufficient breakdown of pyridoxal 5'-phosphate (PLP), the major circulating form of vitamin B6, can cause seizures.

SeqA: Now, significant successes using asfotase alfa, a mineral-targeted recombinant TNSALP, are published concerning severely affected newborns, infants, and children.

SeqA: BACKGROUND Lipedema is a common condition that presents as excessive fat deposition in the extremities, initially sparing the trunk, ankles, and feet, and is found mainly in women, usually occurring after puberty or pregnancy.
SeqB: Lipedema is a common condition where there is too much fat in the arms and legs and is found mainly in women, usually occurring after puberty (when a child's body changes to become an adult) or pregnancy.

SeqA: Lipedema can progress to include lipo-lymphedema of the ankles and feet.
SeqB: Lipedema can progress to include lipo-lymphedema, which is a build up of fluid in addition to excess fat, in the ankles and feet.

SeqA: This report is of a 41-year old woman with Stage 3 lipedema and lipo-lymphedema with excessive fat of the lower body since puberty, with progression to swollen ankles and feet despite dietary caloric restriction.
SeqB: This report is of a 41-year old woman with Stage 3 lipedema and lipo-lymphedema with excessive fat of the lower body since puberty.

SeqA: CASE REPORT A 41-year-old woman noticed increased fat in her legs since age 12.
SeqB: The woman's condition has advanced to swollen ankles and feet despite being on a low calorie diet.

SeqA: Her weight and leg size increased until age 21, when she reached a maximum weight of 165 kg, and underwent a Roux-En-Y gastric bypass.
SeqB: The 41-year-old woman noticed increased fat in her legs since age 12.

SeqA: Over 12 months, she lost 74.8 kg.
SeqB: Her weight and leg size increased until age 21, when she reached a maximum weight of 364 pounds (165 kg), and had a procedure called gastric bypass that involves a doctor placing a small pouch in the stomach and food only goes into that pouch.

SeqA: Her trunk significantly reduced in weight, but her legs did not.
SeqB: Over 12 months, she lost 165 pounds (74.8 kg).

SeqA: Fifteen years later, during recovery from hysterectomy surgery, she became progressively weaker and swollen over her entire body.
SeqB: Her trunk (chest, stomach, and back) significantly reduced in weight, but her legs did not.

SeqA: Laboratory test results showed hypoalbuminemia (2.0 g/dL), lymphopenia, and hypolipoproteinemia.
SeqB: Fifteen years later, during recovery from surgery, she became continuously weaker and swollen over her entire body.

SeqA: She was diagnosed with protein and calorie malnutrition with marked gut edema requiring prolonged parenteral nutrition.
SeqB: Lab test results showed hypoalbuminemia (low levels of the albumin protein in the blood), making it harder to move substances in the body.

SeqA: After restoration of normal protein, her health returned and her pitting edema resolved, but her extremities remained enlarged.
SeqB: Tests also show low levels of white blood cells and low levels of fat lipids in the blood.

SeqA: She was subsequently diagnosed with lipedema.
SeqB: She was not eating enough protein and energy (through calories) to meet nutritional needs with edema (swelling) in the stomach, requiring that more nutrition be given through the vein.

SeqA: CONCLUSIONS This report demonstrates that early and correct diagnosis of lipedema is important, as women who believe the condition is due to obesity may suffer the consequences of calorie or protein-calorie deficiency in an attempt to lose weight.
SeqB: After restoring protein to normal levels, her health returned and her pitting edema due to excess fluid resolved, but her arms and legs remained enlarged.

SeqB: The group consisted of six boys and five girls that were between 3 months to 3 years of age.

SeqA: Eight patients were examined within 12 h of onset, three exhibited negative CRP values despite the duration of the insult over 12 h. Six patients were tentatively diagnosed as having a bacterial infection, but the other five were not.

SeqB: CRP levels were increased during the course of infection.

SeqA: Objective: To compare the accuracy of procalcitonin and C-reactive protein as diagnostic markers of bacterial infection in critically ill children at the onset of systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS).

SeqA: Design:
SeqB: Specifically, this study evaluated the use of these biomarkers in critically ill children at the start of systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS).

SeqA: Prospective cohort study.
SeqB: C-reactive protein is a type of protein found in the blood that increases during times of internal inflammation (redness and swelling from infection-fighting).

SeqA: Setting: Tertiary care, university-affiliated pediatric intensive care unit (PICU).
SeqB: This study evaluated patients who were alike in many ways but differed by specific characteristics.

SeqA: Patients: Consecutive patients with SIRS.
SeqB: This study was based in the tertiary care, university-affiliated pediatric intensive care unit (PICU) for child care.

SeqA: Interventions: From June to December 2002, all PICU patients were screened daily to include cases of SIRS.
SeqB: The study evaluated patients with SIRS.

SeqA: At inclusion (onset of SIRS), procalcitonin and C-reactive protein levels as well as an array of cultures were obtained.
SeqB: From June to December 2002, all PICU patients were screened daily to include cases of SIRS.

SeqA: Diagnosis of bacterial infection was made a posteriori by an adjudicating process (consensus of experts unaware of the results of procalcitonin and C-reactive protein).
SeqB: At inclusion (onset of SIRS), procalcitonin and C-reactive protein levels, along with several bacterial cultures (bacterial groups grown in a lab), were obtained.

SeqA: Baseline and daily data on severity of illness, organ dysfunction, and outcome were collected.
SeqB: Diagnosis of bacterial infection was made following examination of the cultures.

SeqA: Measurements and main results: Sixty-four patients were included in the study and were a posteriori divided into the following groups: bacterial SIRS (n = 25) and nonbacterial SIRS (n = 39).
SeqB: Baseline (before study) and daily data on severity of illness, organ dysfunction, and outcome were collected.

SeqA: Procalcitonin levels were significantly higher in patients with bacterial infection compared with patients without bacterial infection (p = .01).
SeqB: Sixty-four patients were included in the study.

SeqA: The area under the receiver operating characteristic curve for procalcitonin was greater than that for C-reactive protein (0.71 vs. 0.65, respectively).
SeqB: All patients were divided into the one of two groups: bacterial SIRS (25 patients) and nonbacterial SIRS (39 patients).

SeqA: A positive procalcitonin level (>or=2.5 ng/mL), when added to bedside clinical judgment, increased the likelihood of bacterial infection from 39% to 92%, while a negative C-reactive protein level (<40 mg/L) decreased the probability of bacterial infection from 39% to 2%.
SeqB: Procalcitonin levels were significantly higher in patients with bacterial infection compared with patients without bacterial infection.

SeqA: Conclusions: Procalcitonin is better than C-reactive protein for differentiating bacterial from nonbacterial SIRS in critically ill children, although the accuracy of both tests is moderate.
SeqB: Volume of procalcitonin was more predictive of bacterial infection than C-reactive protein.

SeqA: Diagnostic accuracy could be enhanced by combining these tests with bedside clinical judgment.
SeqB: A positive (detected) procalcitonin level increased the likelihood of bacterial infection.

SeqA: Fever after cardiac surgery in children may be due to bacterial infection or noninfectious origin like systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) secondary to bypass procedure.

SeqA: A series of consecutive children who underwent cardiac surgery with bypass were tested for serum levels of CRP at several points up to 5 days postoperatively and during febrile episodes (>38.0??C).

SeqA: Findings were compared among febrile patients with proven bacterial infection (FWI group; sepsis, pneumonia, urinary tract infection, deep wound infection), febrile patients without bacterial infection (FNI group), and patients without fever (NF group).
SeqB: C-reactive protein is a type of protein found in the blood that increases during times of internal inflammation (redness and swelling from infection-fighting).

SeqA: In all, 121 children were enrolled in the study, 31 in the FWI group, 42 in the FNI group, and 48 patients in the NF group.
SeqB: Children who underwent heart surgery with bypass (diverted blood flow) were tested for serum (blood) levels of CRP at several points up to 5 days after surgery and/or when they had a fever.

SeqA: Ages ranged from 4 days to 17.8 years (median 19.0, mean 46 ?? 56 months).
SeqB: Evidence was compared among three patient groups.

SeqA: There was no significant difference among the groups in mean CRP level before surgery, 1 hour, and 18 hours after.
SeqB: The groups include: patients with fever with proven bacterial infection (FWI group), febrile (near-fever) patients without bacterial infection (FNI group), and patients without fever (NF group).

SeqA: A highly significant interaction was found in the change in CRP over time by FWI group compared with FNI group (P < .001).
SeqB: In all, 121 children were enrolled in the study, 31 in the FWI group, 42 in the FNI group, and 48 patients in the NF group.

SeqA: Mean CRP velocity ([fCRP - 18hCRP]/[fever time (days) - 0.75 day]) was significantly higher in the infectious group (4.0 ?? 4.2 mg/dL per d) than in the fever-only group (0.60 ?? 1.6 mg/dL per d; P < .001).

SeqA: A CRP velocity of 4 mg/dL per d had a positive predictive value (PPV) of 85.7% for bacterial infection with 95.2% specificity.

SeqA: C-reactive protein (CRP) is a phylogenetically highly conserved plasma protein, with homologs in vertebrates and many invertebrates, that participates in the systemic response to inflammation.
SeqB: C-reactive protein (CRP) is a protein that has remained relatively unchanged from evolution.

SeqA: Its plasma concentration increases during inflammatory states, a characteristic that has long been employed for clinical purposes.
SeqB: CRP has similar forms in vertebrates and many invertebrates and participates in the systemic (full-body) response to inflammation (infection-fighting).

SeqA: CRP is a pattern recognition molecule, binding to specific molecular configurations that are typically exposed during cell death or found on the surfaces of pathogens.
SeqB: Its plasma (blood) concentration increases during inflammation.

SeqA: Its rapid increase in synthesis within hours after tissue injury or infection suggests that it contributes to host defense and that it is part of the innate immune response.
SeqB: This is a characteristic that has long been employed for clinical purposes.

SeqA: Recently, an association between minor CRP elevation and future major cardiovascular events has been recognized, leading to the recommendation by the Centers for Disease Control and the American Heart Association that patients at intermediate risk of coronary heart disease might benefit from measurement of CRP.
SeqB: CRP is a pattern recognition molecule.

SeqA: This review will largely focus on our current understanding of the structure of CRP, its ligands, the effector molecules with which it interacts, and its apparent functions.
SeqB: This means CRP binds to specific molecular configurations typically found during cell death or on the surfaces of pathogens (foreign organisms).

SeqA: Pancreatic islet-cell antibodies (I.C.Ab) were detected in 31 patients with organ-specific autoimmune disorders, 4 first-degree relatives of I.C.Ab-positive diabetics, and 1 apparently normal subject, none of whom had clinical evidence of diabetes.

SeqA: 10 of these 36 subjects were found to have diabetic glucose-tolerance tests (G.T.T.S), 4 had lag storage, and 22 had normal G.T.T.S.2 had latent diabetes, as evidenced by diabetic G.T.T.S during pregnancy and thyrotoxicosis

SeqA: The titres in some were shown to rise and fall over the years, while in others they remained remarkably constant.

SeqA: A monoclonal islet cell antibody, HISL-19, reactive with human, bovine, and porcine pancreatic islets has been used to identify and characterize a novel group of islet cell proteins (p120, p69, p67, and p56).

SeqA: Besides the islets, HISL-19-reactive antigenic determinants are also expressed on selected cell types, namely, gut endocrine cells, thyroid parafollicular cells (p120), anterior pituitary cells (p40 and p24), specific hypothalamic neuroendocrine cells, and a single layer of large pyramidal cells of the cerebral cortex, thus defining a new family of neuroendocrine molecules.
SeqB: HISL-19 is also reactive with other related tissues that can be grouped into a new family of neuroendocrine (cells like nerve cells that make hormones) molecules.

SeqA: It has been suggested that screening all patients with diabetes diagnosed in later life for islet cell antibodies (ICA) would help predict insulin dependence.
SeqB: Checking all people with diabetes detected later in life for islet cell antibodies (ICA; proteins made against insulin-producing cells) may help predict dependence on insulin.

SeqA: We have surveyed the case notes of 55 patients (22 male; ages 37-88 years) who were found to be ICA positive over a 9-year screening period to assess what contribution knowledge of ICA status made to their management.
SeqB: We read doctor notes of 55 patients (22 male; ages 37-88 years) who were found to be ICA positive (with ICA) over a 9-year checking period to determine what role ICA status made to their treatment.

SeqA: Forty-two patients had been put on insulin (half within 6 months of diagnosis and the rest after up to 6 years).
SeqB: Forty-two patients had been put on insulin (half within 6 months of diagnosis and half after up to 6 years).

SeqA: Of the 13 patients not on insulin, six were on diet alone and seven on oral hypoglycaemic agents after a median follow-up of 3 years.
SeqB: Of the 13 patients not on insulin, six were on health diet and seven were on oral (by mouth) medication after about 3 years.

SeqA: In 37 of the 42 patients, insulin treatment was started for clinical rather than immunological reasons (diabetic ketoacidosis, ketonuria, weight loss and/or severe symptoms).
SeqB: In 37 of the 42 patients, insulin treatment was started due to observable symptoms (high levels of blood acids called ketones, high levels of ketones in urine, weight loss, and/or serious symptoms) rather than issues related to the body's defense system.

SeqA: Five patients were started on insulin because of ICA status when there was no compelling reason on clinical grounds.
SeqB: Five patients were started on insulin due to ICA status where no observable symptoms existed.

SeqA: Knowledge that seven non-insulin-treated patients were ICA positive made doctors reluctant to discharge them from clinic.
SeqB: Doctors were hesitant to send home 7 non-insulin-treated, ICA-positive patients.

SeqA: The data suggest that routine ICA estimation in this age group is unnecessary, as the decision to treat with insulin is best made on clinical grounds, and ICA estimation can lead to unwarranted insulin treatment, or anxiety in patients and doctors who are aware of a positive result.
SeqB: The data suggest that regularly estimating ICA in this age group is not needed, as the decision to treat with insulin should be based on observable symptoms, and ICF estimation can cause unneeded insulin treatment, or anxiety in patients and doctors due to a positive result.

SeqA: Basal insulin secretion was compared in nine islet-cell antibody positive, non-diabetic first-degree relatives of children with Type 1 (insulin-dependent) diabetes mellitus and nine normal control subjects matched for age, sex and weight.
SeqB: We compared background insulin release in nine islet-cell antibody (protein made against insulin-producing cells) positive, non-diabetic parents or siblings of children with type 1 (insulin-dependent) diabetes and nine normal people matched for age, sex and weight.

SeqA: Acute insulin responses to a 25 g intravenous glucose tolerance test were similar in the two groups (243 (198-229) vs 329 (285-380) mU.l-1 x 10 min-1, mean (+/- SE), p = 0.25).
SeqB: Short-term insulin responses to an I.V. (injected) glucose tolerance test were similar in the two groups.

SeqA: Fasting plasma insulin was assayed in venous samples taken at one min intervals for 2 h. Time series analysis was used to demonstrate oscillatory patterns in plasma insulin.
SeqB: We measured blood insulin in people who had not had anything to eat for a period of time in blood samples taken every minute for 2 hours.

SeqA: Autocorrelation showed that regular oscillatory activity was generally absent in the islet-cell antibody-positive group, whereas a regular 13 min cycle was shown in control subjects (p less than 0.0001).
SeqB: We looked at blood insulin over time to see how it rises and falls.

SeqA: Fourier transformation did, however, show a 13 min spectral peak in the islet-cell antibody positive group, consistent with intermittent pulsatility.
SeqB: The islet-cell antibody-positive group (group with the antibody) did not have a regular pattern, but normal people had a 13-minute cycle.

SeqA: We conclude that overall oscillatory patterns of basal insulin secretion are altered in islet-cell antibody positive subjects even when the acute insulin response is within the normal range.
SeqB: The islet-cell antibody-positive group did have a peak every 13 minutes.

SeqA: Insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (IDDM) is associated with the formation of autoantibodies against different antigens in the islets of Langerhans, so-called islet cell antibodies (ICA).
SeqB: Type 1 diabetes is associated with the formation of self-made proteins against different toxins in the islets of Langerhans (a group of insulin-producing cells in the pancreas), known as islet cell antibodies (ICA).

SeqA: The expression of a major autoantigen, the beta-cell specific enzyme glutamic acid decarboxylase (GAD), is glucose-dependent in vitro and correlated to insulin release in vitro.
SeqB: The expression of a major self-made marker, glutamic acid decarboxylase (GAD; substance found only in insulin-producing cells), depends on glucose (sugar) levels and is related to insulin release when observed in a test tube.

SeqA: In this study the expression of islet autoantigens was examined in vivo and the relationship between beta-cell function and islet cell surface antibody (ICSA) reactivity was tested.
SeqB: We looked at expression of islet self-made markers in pancreatic cells and tested the relationship between beta-cell (insulin-producing cell) function and islet cell surface antibody (ICSA) reactivity.

SeqA: Rats were fed for 10 days with glipizide or diazoxide, in order to stimulate or inhibit insulin release, respectively.
SeqB: We fed rats glipizide or diazoxide (insulin-treating drugs) for 10 days to increase or decrease insulin release, respectively.

SeqA: Frozen sections of pancreata were incubated with ten ICA-positive IDDM sera and analyzed by indirect immunofluorescence.
SeqB: Sections of the pancreas were analyzed.

SeqA: Two sera with a "beta-cell restricted" staining, five with an "all-islet cell" staining and three with a "mixed" pattern were employed.
SeqB: We saw the highest measurements in rats given glipizide.

SeqA: In all three groups, the highest end-point titres were obtained when pancreata of rats treated with glipizide were used.
SeqB: We saw medium measurements in animals not given drugs, and the lowest measurements in rats given diazoxide.

SeqA: Intermediate titres were seen in control animals and the lowest titres were observed on pancreata from diazoxide-treated rats, regardless of the serum used.
SeqB: Opposite to these findings, we could not show a relationship between ICSA reactivity and islet cell activity.

SeqA: In contrast to these observations, no correlation between ICSA reactivity and islet cell activity could be demonstrated.
SeqB: Conflicting results concerning ICSA in previous reports and our failure to show an energy regulation of ICSA reactivity, indicate that ICSA is a phenomenon with a low degree of specific detection.

SeqA: Measurement of beta-cell function is an important marker of progression to diabetes in individuals at risk for the disease.
SeqB: Measurement of cells that make insulin is an important indicator of diabetes development in people at risk for diabetes.

SeqA: Although the peak incidence for the disease occurs before 17 years of age, normal values for insulin secretion were not available in this age group.
SeqB: Although the disease most often happens before 17 years of age, normal values for insulin release were not available for this age group.

SeqA: We performed a simplified intravenous glucose tolerance test in 167 normal children, and in 98 islet cell antibody (ICA)-negative and 12 ICA-positive siblings of diabetic patients.
SeqB: We did an I.V. (injected) glucose tolerance test in 167 normal children, and in 98 islet cell antibody (ICA; proteins made against insulin-producing cells)-negative (without ICA) and 12 ICA-positive (with ICA) siblings of diabetic patients.

SeqA: Their age range was 1-16 yr.
SeqB: The children ranged from 1-16 years of age.

SeqA: The first phase of insulin secretion, evaluated as the sum of plasma insulin concentrations at 1 and 3 min, increased with age and was significantly lower in ICA-negative siblings (86 +/- 6 microU/ml, P < 0.002) than in normal controls (115 +/- 6 microU/ml).
SeqB: The first part of insulin release, measured as the total blood insulin levels at 1 and 3 minutes, increased with age and was significantly lower in ICA-negative siblings than in normal children.

SeqA: This difference was not apparent before 8 yr of age.
SeqB: We did not see a difference in the first part of insulin release before 8 years of age.

SeqA: None of the ICA-negative siblings developed diabetes after an average of 4.5 yr.
SeqB: None of the ICA-negative siblings developed diabetes after an average of 4.5 years.

SeqA: ICA-positive siblings at first study had a first phase insulin response similar to that of ICA negative siblings, but significantly lower than that of the normal controls (74 +/- 13 microU/ml, P < 0.02).
SeqB: The first part of insulin response was similar in ICA-positive and ICA-negative siblings, but significantly lower than in normal children.

SeqA: The reason for the decreased insulin secretion in ICA-negative siblings is unknown, but could involve a defect in the growth of beta-cell mass or insulin secretion that could be part of the multifactorial pathogenesis of type 1 diabetes.
SeqB: We do not know the reason ICF-negative siblings had lower insulin release, but it could have to do with insulin-producing cells growing incorrectly or insulin release that could be part of the complicated development of type 1 diabetes.

SeqA: We studied the effect of severe reduction of beta-cell mass by 90% pancreatectomy on the immune tolerance to the endocrine pancreas.
SeqB: We studied the effect of drastically reducing beta-cell (insulin-producing cell) mass by removing 90% of the pancreas on immune tolerance (state of unresponsiveness of the body's defense) to the endocrine pancreas, which controls blood sugar levels.

SeqA: Four months after subtotal pancreatectomy all LEW.Han rats had developed mononuclear infiltration of islets and 9 of 14 rats were positive for islet-cell antibodies.
SeqB: Four months after removal of almost all of the pancreas, all rats had developed signs of long-term inflammation (infection-fighting) response of islets (clusters of cells that produce hormones) and 9 of 14 rats had islet-cell antibodies (proteins made against insulin-producing cells).

SeqA: Electron microscopy revealed lymphocytic invasion of endocrine tissue, lysis of beta cells and phagocytotic macrophages.
SeqB: Using microscopes, we saw immune white blood cells going into the part of the pancreas that produces substances (enzymes) that help with digestion, death of beta cells, and white blood cells that remove dying and dead cells.

SeqA: None of these changes were seen 2 weeks after 90% pancreatectomy or 4 months after 10% pancreatectomy.
SeqB: We saw none of these changes 2 weeks after removing 90% of the pancreas or 4 months after removing 10% of the pancreas.

SeqA: Weekly substitution of islet antigens in the form of a homogenate of 100 islets into 90% pancreatectomized LEW.Han rats almost completely prevented the development of insulitis and autoantibodies.
SeqB: Weekly substitution of islet antigens (substances that causes the body to defend itself) in rats with 90% of the pancreas removed prevented insulitis (disease of the pancreas caused by the infiltration of immune white blood cells) and self-made proteins.

SeqA: The dependence of insulitis on T cells was shown when 90% pancreatectomy in LEW.rnu rats (i.e., the congenic athymic nude strain), did not result in islet infiltration.
SeqB: Insulitis was shown to be dependent on T cells (part of the body's defense system).

SeqA: The exocrine tissue remained normal in all experimental groups.
SeqB: The tissue that produces substances (enzymes) that help with digestion did not change in any group.

SeqA: During the observation period insulitis was not associated with overt diabetes but was accompanied by substantial enlargement of islets and of beta-cell mass, as shown by morphometry.
SeqB: During the observation period, insulitis was not related to diabetes, but we saw a sizeable increase in the sizes of islets and beta-cell mass.

SeqA: Suppression of islet inflammation by injection of islet antigens abolished beta-cell regeneration, despite continuing metabolic stress in rats with 90% pancreatectomy.
SeqB: Decreasing islet inflammation by injecting islet antigens (fragments) stopped beta-cell regrowth, even though low energy continued in rats with 90% of the pancreas removed.

SeqA: The findings indicate induction of islet autoimmunity in response to 90% but not to 10% pancreatectomy.
SeqB: The results suggest removing 90% but not 10% of the pancreas causes the body to mistakenly destroy its islets.

SeqA: We conclude that severe reduction of the islet-antigen mass allows the development of T-cell-dependent islet autoimmunity which indicates a loss of immune tolerance.
SeqB: We conclude that drastically reducing the islet-antigen mass allows the body to mistakenly destroy its islets, which shows a loss of immune tolerance.

SeqA: In addition, the data suggest the existence of islet-antigen autoreactive immune cells in rats not genetically predisposed to autoimmune diabetes.
SeqB: Also, the results suggest islet-antigen autoreactive immune cells exist in rats not likely to develop autoimmune diabetes (diabetes from the body mistakenly destroying its own cells).

SeqA: Finally, we conclude that selective beta-cell regeneration occurs in association with insulitis.
SeqB: Finally, we conclude that some beta-cell regrowth happens with insulitis.

SeqA: Objective: Obese youth clinically diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) frequently have evidence of islet cell autoimmunity (proteins made against insulin-producing cells).
SeqB: Obese youth diagnosed with type 2 diabetes by a doctor often have islet cell autoimmunity (in which immune cells attack healthy cells).

SeqA: We investigated the clinical and biochemical differences, and therapeutic modalities among autoantibody positive (Ab+) vs. autoantibody negative (Ab-) youth at the time of diagnosis and over time in a multi-provider clinical setting.
SeqB: We looked at the observable and biochemical differences, and treatment types of self-made protein positive (Ab+) vs. self-made protein negative (Ab-) youth at diagnosis and over time at a medical facility.

SeqA: Study design: Chart review of 145 obese youth diagnosed with T2DM from January 2003 to July 2012.
SeqB: We reviewed medical charts of 145 obese youth diagnosed with type 2 diabetes from January 2003 to July 2012.

SeqA: Of these, 70 patients were Ab+ and 75 Ab-.
SeqB: Of these 145 youth, 70 patients were Ab+ and 75 Ab-.

SeqA: The two groups were compared with respect to clinical presentation, physical characteristics, laboratory data, and therapeutic modalities at diagnosis and during follow up to assess the changes in these parameters associated with disease progression.
SeqB: We compared the disease symptoms, physical qualities, lab findings, and treatment types of the two groups at diagnosis and during follow up to rate the changes in these things related to disease development.

SeqA: Results:
SeqB: At the doctor, Ab+ youth with a doctor's diagnosis of type 2 diabetes were younger, had higher rates of not enough carbohydrates to burn, higher hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c - which indicates average blood sugar levels) and blood sugar levels, and lower insulin and signs of insulin production compared with the Ab- group.

SeqA: At presentation, Ab+ youth with a clinical diagnosis of T2DM were younger, had higher rates of ketosis, higher hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) and glucose levels, and lower insulin and c-peptide concentrations compared with the Ab- group.
SeqB: The Ab- group had a higher body mass index (BMI) score adjusted for weight and gender and risk factors for heart disease and metabolic disorders at diagnosis and did not change over time.

SeqA: The Ab- group had a higher body mass index (BMI) z-score and cardiometabolic risk factors at diagnosis and such difference remained over time.
SeqB: Treatment type had no effect on BMI in either group.

SeqA: Univariate analysis revealed that treatment modality had no effect on BMI in either group.
SeqB: We found that: (i) length of diabetes affected BMI score adjusted for weight and gender and diastolic blood pressure, (ii) changes In BMI score adjusted for weight and gender affected systolic blood pressure and ALT (alanine transaminase; released into the blood when liver cells are damaged), and (iii) changes in HbA1c affected lipid profile (panel of blood tests used to find abnormalities in lipids, such as cholesterol and triglycerides) and risk factors for heart disease and metabolic disorders independent of antibody (infection-fighting protein) status.

SeqA: Generalized estimating equations for longitudinal data analysis revealed that (i) BMI z-score and diastolic blood pressure (DBP) were significantly affected by duration of diabetes; (ii) systolic blood pressure (SBP) and ALT were affected by changes in BMI z-score; and (iii) changes in HbA1c had an effect on lipid profile and cardiometabolic risk factors regardless of antibody status.
SeqB: Regardless of antibody status and treatment type, obese and diabetic youth do not become less obese over time, with higher BMI affecting blood pressure and ALT, and blood sugar levels affecting the lipid profile.

SeqA: Conclusions: Irrespective of antibody status and treatment modality, youth who present with obesity and diabetes, show no improvement in obesity status over time, with the deterioration in BMI z-score affecting blood pressure (BP) and ALT, but the lipid profile being mostly impacted by HbA1c and glycemic control.
SeqB: Controlling BMI and blood sugar levels are needed to lessen future large blood vessel problems regardless of antibody status.

SeqA: Islet cell antibodies (ICA) continue to serve as the basis of the principal serological test for definition of active autoimmunity of beta-cells.
SeqB: The main blood test to determine active attack of the insulin-producing beta-cells by the body is based on islet cell antibodies (ICA; proteins made against insulin-producing cells).

SeqA: Its disadvantages are the need for human pancreatic tissue and difficulty in obtaining quantitative results.
SeqB: The main ICA test has drawbacks like needing human tissue from the pancreas and difficulty in getting results in the form of a number.

SeqA: In the past decade biochemically-defined beta-cell toxins were described, leading to the development of sensitive and specific autoantibody assays, to predict insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (IDDM).
SeqB: Based on the description of beta-cell proteins in test tubes in the past 10 years, new measuring tools for self-made proteins were made with high accuracy for disease detection and no detection to predict type 1 diabetes.

SeqA: We examined the value of combined biochemically-based serological assays, such as autoantibodies to insulin (IAA), glutamic acid decarboxylase (GADA) and ICA512 (ICA512A) to replace the traditional ICA assay.
SeqB: We looked at whether combined blood tests in test tubes, such as self-made proteins to insulin (IAA), the enzyme glutamic acid decarboxylase (GADA), and ICA512 (ICA512A), could replace the main ICA test.

SeqA: Blood samples of 114 newly diagnosed IDDM patients, aged 12 +/- 5 yrs (range 2 months-29 years) were tested for ICA (indirect immunofluorescence), IAA, GADA and ICA512A (radiobinding assay).
SeqB: We tested blood samples of 114 newly diagnosed type 1 diabetes patients, aged 12 plus or minus 5 years (ranging from 2 months to 29 year) for ICA, IAA, GADA, and ICA512A.

SeqA: The latter 2 assays were performed using recombinant human [35S]-labeled antigen produced by in vitro transcription/translation.
SeqB: We found that more blood samples scored positive (detected the presence of the disease) for 1 or more of IAA, GAD, or ICA512 than for ICA and/or IAA.

SeqB: We conclude that testing for IAA, GAD and ICA512 together can replace the traditional ICA/IAA test to predict type 1 diabetes and is helpful to doctors in telling the different between type 1 and type 2 diabetes.

SeqA: Islet cell antibodies (ICA; proteins made against insulin-producing cells) are a marker of insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (IDDM).
SeqB: Islet cell antibodies (ICA) are an indicator of type 1 diabetes.

SeqA: ICA are detected in 60-80% of the patients with IDDM at the onset of the disease.
SeqB: ICA are found in 60-80% of patients with type 1 diabetes when symptoms first appear.

SeqA: The presence of ICA in patients with non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (NIDDM) indicates that the patients are likely to develop IDDM.
SeqB: Type 2 diabetics with ICA are likely to develop type 1 diabetes.

SeqA: However, as ICA are measured by the indirect immunofluorescent method, the reliability of the ICA assay is not high in some institutes.
SeqB: The current way to measure ICA is not always reliable.

SeqA: Use of the pancreas tissue having high antigenicity is recommended as one solution for a reliable assay.
SeqB: A reliable standardized test could use pancreas tissue, tissue from an organ that monitors blood sugar levels.

SeqA: Standardization of the ICA assay is under way with the use of an ICA positive standard sera as 80 JDF units.
SeqB: A standardized test to measure ICA is under way.

SeqA: Anti-glutamate decarboxylase (GAD) antibody assays using a radioimmunoassay (RIA) or enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) have recently been developed.
SeqB: Scientists have recently developed a standardized test to measure anti-glutamate decarboxylase (GAD) antibody, a rare protein.

SeqA: The significance of anti-GAD antibodies is comparable to that of ICA.
SeqB: Anti-GAD antibodies and ICA have similar meanings.

SeqA: Since the anti-GAD assay is reproducible and easy to perform, it should be used widely in parallel with the ICA assay.
SeqB: The standardized test to measure anti-GAD can be repeated and is easy to do, so it should be used widely at the same time as the test to measure ICA.

SeqA: Aim: To examine whether mild early time-restricted eating (eating dinner at 18:00 vs. at 21:00) improves 24-h blood glucose levels and postprandial lipid metabolism in healthy adults.
SeqB: The aim of this study is to examine whether mild early time-restricted eating (eating dinner at 6:00pm vs. at 9:00pm) improves 24 hour blood sugar levels and the breakdown of fats after meals in healthy adults.

SeqA: Methods: Twelve participants (2 males and 10 females) were included in the study.
SeqB: Twelve participants (2 males and 10 females) are included in the study.

SeqA: In this 3-day (until the morning of day 3) randomized crossover study, two different conditions were tested: eating a late dinner (at 21:00) or an early dinner (at 18:00).
SeqB: In this 3-day (until the morning of day 3) study, two different conditions are tested: eating a late dinner at 9:00pm (at 21:00) or an early dinner at 6:00pm (at 18:00).

SeqB: Measurements for metabolism are performed on the morning of day 3.

SeqB: The study is conducted over three days; day 1 is excluded from the analysis to adjust for the effects of the previous day's meal, and only data from the mornings of days 2 and 3 are used for the analysis.

SeqA: Results:
SeqB: Significant differences are observed in the average 24 hour blood sugar levels on day 2 between the two groups.

SeqA: Significant differences were observed in mean 24-h blood glucose levels on day 2 between the two groups (p = 0.034).
SeqB: There was a big decrease in the respiratory quotient, a measure of how nutrients are used and a measure oxygen absorbed in the body, 30 min and 60 min after breakfast on day 3 in the early dinner group compared with the late dinner group.

SeqB: Despite a difference of only 3 hours, eating dinner early at 6:00pm (at 18:00) has a positive effect on blood sugar levels and oxygen being added compared with eating dinner late 9:00pm (at 21:00).

SeqA: To date, nutritional studies have focused on the total intake of dietary fiber rather than intake timing.
SeqB: To date, nutritional studies have focused on the total amount of dietary fiber consumed rather than when the fiber was consumed.

SeqA: In this study, we examined the effect of the timing of daily Helianthus tuberosus ingestion on postprandial and 24 h glucose levels, as well as on intestinal microbiota in older adults.
SeqB: In this study, researchers examine the effect of the timing of daily ingestion of Jerusalem artichoke (sunroot, Helianthus tuberosus) on blood sugar levels after meals and at 24 hours, as well as on gut bacteria in older adults.

SeqA: In total, 37 healthy older adults (age = 74.9 ?? 0.8 years) were recruited.
SeqB: In total, 37 healthy older adults (age = 74.9 ?? 0.8 years) are recruited.

SeqA: The participants were randomly assigned to either a morning group (MG, n = 18) or an evening group (EG, n = 17).
SeqB: The participants are randomly assigned to either a morning group (18 participants) or an evening group (17 participants).

SeqB: Each group took the powder for 1 week.

SeqA: Objective: To determine the effect of morning exercise in the fasting condition vs afternoon exercise on blood glucose responses to resistance exercise (RE).

SeqA: Background: Although physical exercise (PE) is recommended for individuals with type 1 diabetes (DM1), participation in exercise is challenging because it increases the risk of severe hypoglycemia and the available therapeutic options to prevent it frequently result in hyperglycemia.

SeqB: The aim of this study is to compare the risk of hypoglycemia after morning or afternoon exercise sessions up to 36 hours after a workout.

SeqB: Most hypoglycemic events occurred 15-24 hours after the session.

SeqA: Aims: Individuals with Type 1 diabetes mellitus are susceptible to hypoglycaemia during and after continuous moderate-intensity exercise, but hyperglycaemia during intermittent high-intensity exercise.
SeqB: People with Type 1 diabetes are vulnerable to developing low blood sugar, also called hypoglycemia, during and after continuous moderate-level exercise, but they are also at risk of high blood sugar (hyperglycemia) during periodic high-intensity exercise.

SeqB: The combination of both moderate and high-intensity exercise may have an effect on blood sugar levels.

SeqA: The aims of this study were to compare the physiological responses and associated glycaemic changes to continuous moderate-intensity exercise vs. continuous moderate-intensity exercise + intermittent high-intensity exercise in athletes with Type 1 diabetes.
SeqB: The aims of this study are to compare the body's physical responses and blood sugar changes to continuous moderate-intensity exercise vs. continuous moderate-intensity exercise + periodic high-intensity exercise in athletes with Type 1 diabetes.

SeqA: Methods: Interstitial glucose levels were measured in a blinded fashion in 11 trained athletes with Type 1 diabetes during two sedentary days and during 2 days in which 45 min of afternoon continuous moderate-intensity exercise occurred either with or without intermittent high-intensity exercise.

SeqA: The total amount of work performed and the duration of exercise was identical between sessions.
SeqB: Samples are taken during two days when they were not active and during 2 days in which 45 minutes of afternoon continuous moderate-intensity exercise occurred either with or without periodic high-intensity exercise.

SeqA: Results: During exercise, heart rate, respiratory exchange ratio, oxygen utilization, ventilation and blood lactate levels were higher during continuous moderate-intensity + intermittent high-intensity exercise vs. continuous moderate-intensity exercise (all P < 0.05).
SeqB: The total amount of work performed and the duration of exercise is identical between sessions.

SeqA: Despite these marked cardiorespiratory differences between trials, there was no difference in the reduction of interstitial glucose or plasma glucose levels between the exercise trials.
SeqB: During exercise, heart rate, respiratory exchange ratio to determine how the body is getting energy, oxygen utilization, ventilation (breathing) and blood lactatic acid (waste build-up from exercise) levels are higher during continuous moderate-intensity + intermittent high-intensity exercise vs. continuous moderate-intensity exercise.

SeqA: Nocturnal glucose levels were higher in continuous moderate-intensity + intermittent high-intensity exercise and in sedentary vs. continuous moderate-intensity exercise (P < 0.05).
SeqB: Despite these noticeable heart-lung differences, there is no difference in the reduction of interstitial sugar or blood sugar levels between the exercise trials.

SeqA: Compared with continuous moderate-intensity exercise alone, continuous moderate-intensity + intermittent high-intensity exercise was associated with less post-exercise hypoglycaemia (5.2 vs. 1.5% of the time spent with glucose < 4.0 mmol/l) and more post-exercise hyperglycaemia (33.8 vs. 20.4% of time > 11.0 mmol/l).
SeqB: Nighttime sugar levels are higher in continuous moderate-intensity + periodic high-intensity exercise and in inactive vs. continuous moderate-intensity exercise.

SeqA: Conclusions:
SeqB: Compared with continuous moderate-intensity exercise alone, continuous moderate-intensity + periodic high-intensity exercise is associated with less hypoglycemia after exercise and more hyperglycemia after exercise.

SeqA: Although the decreases in glucose level during continuous moderate-intensity exercise and continuous moderate-intensity + intermittent high-intensity exercise are similar, the latter form of exercise protects against nocturnal hypoglycaemia in athletes with Type 1 diabetes.
SeqB: Although the decreases in sugar level during continuous moderate-intensity exercise and continuous moderate-intensity + periodic high-intensity exercise are similar, the latter form of exercise protects against nighttime hypoglycemia in athletes with Type 1 diabetes.

SeqA: The objective of this study was to evaluate whether first-degree relatives (FDRs) of patients with type 2 diabetes had abnormal circadian insulin secretion and, if so, whether this abnormality affected their glucose metabolism.
SeqB: Insulin secretion is the body's release of insulin, the hormone that helps control blood sugar and metabolism.

SeqA: Six African-American FDRs with normal glucose tolerance and 12 matched normal control subjects (who had no family history of diabetes) were exposed to 48 h of hyperglycemic clamping (approximately 12 mmol/l).
SeqB: The objective of this study is to evaluate whether first-degree relatives (a person's parent, sibling, or child) of patients with type 2 diabetes have abnormal 24 hour insulin secretion and, if so, whether this abnormality affected their glucose metabolism.

SeqA: Insulin secretion rates (ISRs) were determined by deconvolution of plasma C-peptide levels using individual C-peptide kinetic parameters.
SeqB: Six African-American first-degree relatives with normal blood sugar level and 12 normal control participants (who had no family history of diabetes) were exposed to 48 hours of hyperglycemic clamping, a technique to keep blood sugar levels stable.

SeqA: Detrending and smoothing of data (z-scores) and computation of autocorrelation functions were used to identify ISR cycles.
SeqB: Insulin secretion rates (ISRs) are determined by calculating plasma C-peptide levels, which are substances that signal if the body is creating insulin.

SeqA: During the initial hours after start of glucose infusions, ISRs were approximately 60% higher in FDRs than in control subjects (585 vs. 366 nmol/16 h, P < 0.05), while rates of glucose uptake were the same (5.6 mmol x kg(-1) x h(-1)), indicating that the FDRs were insulin resistant.
SeqB: During the initial hours after giving people infusions of sugar (glucose), insulin secretion rates are about 60% higher in first-degree relatives than in the comparison (control) subjects, while rates of sugar uptake are the same.

SeqA: Control subjects had well-defined circadian (24 h) cycles of ISR and plasma insulin that rose in the early morning, peaked in the afternoon, and declined during the night.
SeqB: This finding suggests that the first-degree relatives are insulin resistant, which is when the body doesn't respond well to the insulin hormone and can't use blood sugar for energy.

SeqA: In contrast, FDRs had several shorter ISR cycles of smaller amplitude that lacked true periodicity.
SeqB: Control subjects have well-defined 24 hour cycles of insulin secretion rates and plasma insulin that increase in the early morning, peak in the afternoon, and decline during the night.

SeqA: This suggested that the lack of a normal circadian ISR increase had made it impossible for the FDRs to maintain their compensatory insulin hypersecretion beyond 18 h of hyperglycemia.
SeqB: In contrast, first-degree relatives have several shorter insulin secretion rate cycles.

SeqA: As a result, ISR decreased to the level found in control subjects, and glucose uptake fell below the level of control subjects (61 vs. 117 micromol x kg(-1)
SeqB: This suggests that the lack of a normal increase in the 24 hour insulin secretion rate makes it impossible for the first-degree relatives to keep their insulin excess secretion beyond 18 hours of hyperglycemia (high blood sugar).
As a result, insulin secretion rate decreased to the level found in control subjects, and blood sugar uptake fell below the level of control subjects.

SeqA: In summary, we found that FDRs with normal glucose tolerance had defects in insulin action and secretion.
SeqB: In summary, researchers found that first-degree relatives with normal blood sugar levels had defects in insulin action and secretion.

SeqA: The newly recognized insulin secretory defect consisted of disruption of the normal circadian ISR cycle, which resulted in reduced insulin secretion (and glucose uptake) during the ascending part of the 24 h ISR cycle.
SeqB: The new insulin secretory defect includes disrupting the normal 24 hour insulin secretion rate cycle, which resulted in reduced insulin secretion (and blood sugar uptake) during the upward part of the 24 hour insulin secretion rate cycle.

SeqA: Time-restricted feeding (TRF) is a form of intermittent fasting that involves having a longer daily fasting period.
SeqB: Intermittent fasting is a type of eating schedule where a person doesn't eat any calories for a period of time.

SeqA: Preliminary studies report that TRF improves cardiometabolic health in rodents and humans.
SeqB: Time-restricted feeding is a form of intermittent fasting that involves having a longer daily fasting period.

SeqA: Here, we performed the first study to determine how TRF affects gene expression, circulating hormones, and diurnal patterns in cardiometabolic risk factors in humans.
SeqB: Early studies report that time-restricted feeding improves the health of the heart and metabolism in rodents and humans.

SeqA: Eleven overweight adults participated in a 4-day randomized crossover study where they ate between 8 am and 2 pm (early TRF (eTRF)) and between 8 am and 8 pm (control schedule).
SeqB: In this study, researchers perform the first study to determine how time-restricted feeding affects how information from genes are used, how circulating hormones that travel in blood and attach to cells can change the cell function, and how daily patterns in the heart and metabolism can be risk factors in humans.

SeqB: Eleven overweight adults participated in a 4-day study where they ate between 8 am and 2 pm (early time-restricted feeding) and between 8 am and 8 pm (control group for comparison).

SeqA: Relative to the control schedule, eTRF decreased mean 24-hour glucose levels by 4 ?? 1 mg/dl (p = 0.0003) and glycemic excursions by 12 ?? 3 mg/dl (p = 0.001).
SeqB: Participants have their sugar continuously monitored, and blood is drawn to assess risk factors to the heart and metabolism, hormones, and gene development in blood cells.

SeqA: In the morning before breakfast, eTRF increased ketones, cholesterol, and the expression of the stress response and aging gene SIRT1 and the autophagy gene LC3A (all p < 0.04), while in the evening, it tended to increase brain-derived neurotropic factor (BNDF; p = 0.10) and also increased the expression of MTOR (p = 0.007), a major nutrient-sensing protein that regulates cell growth.
SeqB: Relative to the comparison group's schedule, early time-restricted feeding decreased the average 24-hour sugar levels and changes in blood sugar.

SeqA: eTRF also altered the diurnal patterns in cortisol and the expression of several circadian clock genes (p < 0.05).
SeqB: In the morning before breakfast, early time-restricted feeding increased ketones (substances that the body makes if cells don't get enough blood sugar), cholesterol, and the activity of the stress response and aging gene SIRT1 and the gene LC3A that cleans out damaged cells.

SeqA: eTRF improves 24-hour glucose levels, alters lipid metabolism and circadian clock gene expression, and may also increase autophagy and have anti-aging effects in humans.
SeqB: While in the evening, time-restricted feeding tends to increase brain-derived neurotropic factor, which is a helpful protein in the spinal cord and brain, and also increases the expansion of the MTOR gene, a major nutrient-sensing protein that regulates cell growth.

SeqA: More than 2 million people in the United States have myalgic encephalomyelitis/chronic fatigue syndrome (ME/CFS).

SeqA: These favorable results were further supported by responder analysis.

SeqA: Conclusions: The results indicate that PS-DHA may improve cognitive performance in non-demented elderly with memory complaints.

SeqA: Membrane Lipid Replacement is the use of functional oral supplements containing cell membrane glycerolphospholipids and antioxidants to safely replace damaged membrane lipids that accumulate during aging and in various chronic and acute diseases.
SeqB: Membrane Lipid Replacement is a treatment that uses oral (by mouth) supplements to safely replace damaged membrane lipids (fatty substances on cell boundaries).

SeqA: Most if not all clinical conditions and aging are characterized by membrane phospholipid oxidative damage, resulting in loss of membrane and cellular function.
SeqB: Lipids are organic compounds such as fats, waxes, oils, and hormones.

SeqA: Clinical trials have shown the benefits of Membrane Lipid Replacement supplements in replenishing damaged membrane lipids and restoring mitochondrial function, resulting in reductions in fatigue in aged subjects and patients with a variety of clinical diagnoses.
SeqB: These damaged lipids accumulate during aging and various diseases.

SeqA: Recent observations have indicated that Membrane Lipid Replacement can be a useful natural supplement strategy in a variety of conditions: chronic fatigue, such as found in many diseases and disorders; fatiguing illnesses (fibromyalgia and chronic fatigue syndrome); chronic infections (Lyme disease and mycoplasmal infections); cardiovascular diseases; obesity, metabolic syndrome and diabetes; neurodegenerative diseases (Alzheimer's disease); neurobehavioral diseases (autism spectrum disorders); fertility diseases; chemical contamination (Gulf War illnesses); and cancers (breast, colorectal and other cancers).

SeqA: Membrane Lipid Replacement provides general membrane nutritional support during aging and illness to improve membrane function and overall health without risk of adverse effects.

SeqA: Background: Attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is the most commonly diagnosed behavioural disorder of childhood, affecting 3-5% of school-age children.
SeqB: Attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is the most commonly diagnosed behavioral disorder of childhood.

SeqA: The present study investigated whether the supplementation of soy-derived phosphatidylserine (PS), a naturally occurring phospholipid, improves ADHD symptoms in children.
SeqB: It affects 3-5% of school-age children.

SeqA: Methods: Thirty six children, aged 4-14 years, who had not previously received any drug treatment related to ADHD, received placebo (n = 17) or 200 mg day(-1) PS (n = 19) for 2 months in a randomised, double-blind manner.
SeqB: This study investigated if supplementation of soy-derived phosphatidylserine (PS), a naturally occurring phospholipid or the fatty part of a cell's boundaries, improves ADHD symptoms in children.

SeqA: Main outcome measures included: (i) ADHD symptoms based on DSM-IV-TR; (ii) short-term auditory memory and working memory using the Digit Span Test of the Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children; and (iii) mental performance to visual stimuli (GO/NO GO task).
SeqB: Thirty six children, aged 4-14 years, who had not previously received any drug treatment related to ADHD, were recruited.

SeqA: Results: PS supplementation resulted in significant improvements in: (i) ADHD (P < 0.01), AD (P < 0.01) and HD (P < 0.01); (ii) short-term auditory memory (P < 0.05); and (iii) inattention (differentiation and reverse differentiation, P < 0.05) and inattention and impulsivity (P < 0.05).
SeqB: 17 kids received placebos (sham treatment) for 2 months, and 19 kids received 200 mg/day PS for 2 months.

SeqA: No significant differences were observed in other measurements and in the placebo group.
SeqB: Several measurements were taken to determine effectiveness.

SeqA: PS was well-tolerated and showed no adverse effects.
SeqB: PS supplementation resulted in significant improvements in: ADHD, AD, and HD.

SeqA: Conclusions: PS significantly improved ADHD symptoms and short-term auditory memory in children.
SeqB: There was also improvement in short-term auditory memory, inattention, and impulsivity.

SeqA: PS supplementation might be a safe and natural nutritional strategy for improving mental performance in young children suffering from ADHD.
SeqB: No significant differences were observed in other measurements and in the placebo group.

SeqA: Background: Myalgic encephalomyelitis/chronic fatigue syndrome (ME/CFS) is characterized by unexplained persistent fatigue, commonly accompanied by cognitive dysfunction, sleeping disturbances, orthostatic intolerance, fever, lymphadenopathy, and irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).
SeqB: Background: Myalgic encephalomyelitis/chronic fatigue syndrome (ME/CFS) is characterized by unexplained persistent fatigue (long-lasting tiredness).

SeqA: The extent to which the gastrointestinal microbiome and peripheral inflammation are associated with ME/CFS remains unclear.
SeqB: ME/CFS is commonly accompanied by cognitive dysfunction, sleeping disturbances, orthostatic intolerance (inability to stand up quickly), fever, lymphadenopathy (swollen lymph nodes), and irritable bowel syndrome (IBS - colon disorder that leads to belly pain, gas, diarrhea, and constipation).

SeqA: We pursued rigorous clinical characterization, fecal bacterial metagenomics, and plasma immune molecule analyses in 50 ME/CFS patients and 50 healthy controls frequency-matched for age, sex, race/ethnicity, geographic site, and season of sampling.
SeqB: The extent to which the stomach microbiome (gut bacteria) and inflammation (redness and swelling from infection-fighting) are associated (linked) with ME/CFS is unknown.

SeqA: Results: Topological analysis revealed associations between IBS co-morbidity, body mass index, fecal bacterial composition, and bacterial metabolic pathways but not plasma immune molecules.
SeqB: This study evaluated 50 ME/CFS patients and 50 healthy controls.

SeqA: IBS co-morbidity was the strongest driving factor in the separation of topological networks based on bacterial profiles and metabolic pathways.
SeqB: Analysis revealed associations between IBS co-morbidity, body mass index, fecal (poop) bacterial composition, and bacterial metabolic pathways.

SeqA: Predictive selection models based on bacterial profiles supported findings from topological analyses indicating that ME/CFS subgroups, defined by IBS status, could be distinguished from control subjects with high predictive accuracy.
SeqB: No associated was found between ME/CFS status and plasma (blood) immune molecules.

SeqA: Bacterial taxa predictive of ME/CFS patients with IBS were distinct from taxa associated with ME/CFS patients without IBS.
SeqB: IBS co-morbidity (co-diagnosis) was the most strongly associated endpoint with ME/CFS status.

SeqA: Increased abundance of unclassified Alistipes and decreased Faecalibacterium emerged as the top biomarkers of ME/CFS with IBS; while increased unclassified Bacteroides abundance and decreased Bacteroides vulgatus were the top biomarkers of ME/CFS without IBS.
SeqB: ME/CFS subgroups, defined by IBS status, could be distinguished from control subjects with high predictive accuracy.

SeqA: Despite findings of differences in bacterial taxa and metabolic pathways defining ME/CFS subgroups, decreased metabolic pathways associated with unsaturated fatty acid biosynthesis and increased atrazine degradation pathways were independent of IBS co-morbidity.
SeqB: Bacterial taxa (bacterial groups) predictive of ME/CFS patients with IBS were distinct from taxa associated with ME/CFS patients without IBS.

SeqA: Increased vitamin B6 biosynthesis/salvage and pyrimidine ribonucleoside degradation were the top metabolic pathways in ME/CFS without IBS as well as in the total ME/CFS cohort.
SeqB: Two bacteria, Alistipes and Faecalibacterium, emerged as the top biomarkers of ME/CFS with IBS.

SeqA: In ME/CFS subgroups, symptom severity measures including pain, fatigue, and reduced motivation were correlated with the abundance of distinct bacterial taxa and metabolic pathways.
SeqB: Two bacteria, Bacteroides and Bacteroides vulgatus, were the top biomarkers of ME/CFS without IBS.

SeqA: Conclusions: Independent of IBS, ME/CFS is associated with dysbiosis and distinct bacterial metabolic disturbances that may influence disease severity.
SeqB: Decreased metabolic pathways associated with unsaturated fatty acid biosynthesis and increased atrazine (herbicide) degradation pathways were independent of IBS co-morbidity.

SeqA: However, our findings indicate that dysbiotic features that are uniquely ME/CFS-associated may be masked by disturbances arising from the high prevalence of IBS co-morbidity in ME/CFS.
SeqB: Increased vitamin B6 biosynthesis/salvage and pyrimidine ribonucleoside (DNA building blocks) degradation were the top metabolic pathways in ME/CFS without IBS.

SeqA: These insights may enable more accurate diagnosis and lead to insights that inform the development of specific therapeutic strategies in ME/CFS subgroups.
SeqB: These pathways were also top in the total ME/CFS cohort.

SeqA: Loss of function in mitochondria, the key organelle responsible for cellular energy production, can result in the excess fatigue and other symptoms that are common complaints in almost every chronic disease.
SeqB: Loss of function in mitochondria, the key organelle responsible for cellular energy production, can result in the excess fatigue and other symptoms commonly found in chronic diseases.

SeqA: At the molecular level, a reduction in mitochondrial function occurs as a result of the following changes: (1) a loss of maintenance of the electrical and chemical transmembrane potential of the inner mitochondrial membrane, (2) alterations in the function of the electron transport chain, or (3) a reduction in the transport of critical metabolites into mitochondria.
SeqB: A reduction in mitochondrial function occurs as a result of several changes.

SeqA: In turn, these changes result in a reduced efficiency of oxidative phosphorylation and a reduction in production of adenosine-5'-triphosphate (ATP).
SeqB: These include: maintenance loss of the transmembrane (trans-cell-boundary electrical) potential of the inner mitochondrial membrane, abnormal function of the electron transport chain, or reduced transport of critical metabolites (energy-regulating molecules) into mitochondria.

SeqA: Several components of this system require routine replacement, and this need can be facilitated with natural supplements.
SeqB: These changes result in a reduced efficiency of oxidative phosphorylation (energy creation) and reduced production of adenosine-5'-triphosphate (ATP - the main currency of energy in a cell).

SeqA: Clinical trials have shown the utility of using oral replacement supplements, such as L-carnitine, alpha-lipoic acid (??-lipoic acid [1,2-dithiolane-3-pentanoic acid]), coenzyme Q10 (CoQ10 [ubiquinone]), reduced nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NADH), membrane phospholipids, and other supplements.
SeqB: Several components of this system require routine replacement.

SeqA: Combinations of these supplements can reduce significantly the fatigue and other symptoms associated with chronic disease and can naturally restore mitochondrial function, even in long-term patients with intractable fatigue.
SeqB: This system can be assisted with natural supplements.

SeqA: Evidence is put forward to suggest that myalgic encephalomyelitis, also known as chronic fatigue syndrome, may be associated with persistent viral infection.
SeqB: Scientific evidence suggests that myalgic encephalomyelitis, also known as chronic fatigue syndrome or long-lasting tiredness, may be associated with persistent viral infection.

SeqA: In turn, such infections are likely to impair the ability of the body to biosynthesise n-3 and n-6 long-chain polyunsaturated fatty acids by inhibiting the delta-6 desaturation of the precursor essential fatty acids--namely, alpha-linolenic acid and linoleic acid.
SeqB: These infections may impair the body's ability to biosynthesize (create) fatty acids by inhibiting (blocking) the enzymatic reaction associated with essential fatty acids.

SeqA: This would, in turn, impair the proper functioning of cell membranes, including cell signalling, and have an adverse effect on the biosynthesis of eicosanoids from the long-chain polyunsaturated fatty acids dihomo-gamma-linolenic acid, arachidonic acid and eicosapentaenoic acid.
SeqB: This would, in turn, impair the proper functioning of cell membranes (cell boundaries), including cell signaling, and have an adverse effect on the biosynthesis of signaling molecules.

SeqA: These actions might offer an explanation for some of the symptoms and signs of myalgic encephalomyelitis.
SeqB: These actions might offer an explanation for some of the symptoms and signs of myalgic encephalomyelitis.

SeqA: A potential therapeutic avenue could be offered by bypassing the inhibition of the enzyme delta-6-desaturase by treatment with virgin cold-pressed non-raffinated evening primrose oil, which would supply gamma-linolenic acid and lipophilic pentacyclic triterpenes, and with eicosapentaenoic acid.
SeqB: A potential treatment could be found in virgin cold-pressed primrose oil.

SeqA: The gamma-linolenic acid can readily be converted into dihomo-gamma-linolenic acid and thence arachidonic acid, while triterpenes have important free radical scavenging, cyclo-oxygenase and neutrophil elastase inhibitory activities.
SeqB: The oil would supply gamma-linolenic acid and lipophilic pentacyclic triterpenes (specific fatty substances).

SeqA: Furthermore, both arachidonic acid and eicosapentaenoic acid are, at relatively low concentrations, directly virucidal.
SeqB: The resulting acid and triterpenes would be further converted into beneficial compounds.

SeqA: Abnormalities of Essential Fatty Acid (EFA) incorporation into phospholipid are found in chronic diseases.
SeqB: Abnormalities of Essential Fatty Acid (EFA) incorporation into phospholipid (fatty molecules that build a cell's wall) are found in chronic diseases.

SeqA: More recently changes in circulating EFA metabolites (EFAM) together with EFAM hypo-responsiveness of immune cells and EFAM production from cells have been found associated with disease.

SeqB: This study hypothesized that changes in EFAM ratio is the normal response to stressors.

SeqA: In time, many homeostatic system become deranged and held in that state by minor stressors.
SeqB: However, when stressors are excessive or prolonged, EFAM systems may become unresponsive.

SeqB: Many stable systems become deranged and held in that state by minor stressors.

SeqA: For the first time, we explain chronic immune system activation and hypo-responsive immune function in CFS; through EFAMs.
