SeqA: Dietary EFA modulation (DEFA) can alter ratios of both membrane EFAs and produced EFAMs, and if maintained can restore hypo-responsive function.
SeqB: This study explains chronic immune system activation and hypo-responsive immune function in CFS through EFAMs.

SeqB: Dietary EFA modulation (DEFA) can alter ratios of both membrane EFAs and produced EFAMs.

SeqA: Sixty-three adults with the diagnosis of the postviral fatigue syndrome were enrolled in a double-blind, placebo-controlled study of essential fatty acid therapy.
SeqB: Sixty-three adults diagnosed with postviral fatigue (tiredness) syndrome were enrolled in a study of essential fatty acid therapy.

SeqB: The participants were given one of two treatments: a formulated mixture or a placebo (sham treatment).

SeqA: In consultation with the patient the doctors assessed overall condition, fatigue, myalgia, dizziness, poor concentration and depression on a 3-point scale.

SeqA: The essential fatty acid composition of their red cell membrane phospholipids was analysed at the first and last visits.
SeqB: The treatments were administered as 8 x 500 mg capsules per day over a 3-month period.

SeqA: At 1 month, 74% of patients on active treatment and 23% of those on placebo assessed themselves as improved over the baseline, with the improvement being much greater in the former.
SeqB: Patients were evaluated before treatment, after one month, and after three months.

SeqA: At 3 months the corresponding figures were 85% and 17% (p less than 0.0001) since the placebo group had reverted towards the baseline state while those in the active group showed continued improvement.
SeqB: Doctors assessed overall condition, fatigue, muscle pain, dizziness, poor concentration, and depression.

SeqA: The essential fatty acid levels were abnormal at the baseline and corrected by active treatment.

SeqA: There were no adverse events.
SeqB: At 1 month, 74% of patients on active treatment and 23% of those on placebo assessed (measured) themselves as improved over the baseline.

SeqA: We conclude that essential fatty acids provide a rational, safe and effective treatment for patients with the post-viral fatigue syndrome.
SeqB: Improvement being much greater in the active treatment group.

SeqA: This is a comprehensive literature review of chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS).

SeqB: CFS is a multifaceted illness that has many symptoms and a wide array of clinical presentations.

SeqA: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) considers it a diagnosing of exclusion, stating that self-reported fatigue for at minimum of six months and four of the following symptoms are necessary for a proper diagnosis: memory problems, sore throat, post-exertion malaise, tender cervical or axillary lymph nodes, myalgia, multi-joint pain, headaches, and troubled sleep.

SeqA: Clinical characteristics: Pallister-Hall syndrome (referred to as PHS in this entry) is characterized by a spectrum of anomalies ranging from polydactyly, asymptomatic bifid epiglottis, and hypothalamic hamartoma at the mild end to laryngotracheal cleft with neonatal lethality at the severe end.
SeqB: Pallister-Hall syndrome (PHS) ranges from mild to severe cases.

SeqA: Individuals with mild PHS may be incorrectly diagnosed as having isolated postaxial polydactyly type A. Individuals with PHS can have pituitary insufficiency and may die as neonates from undiagnosed and untreated adrenal insufficiency.
SeqB: Mild cases include polydactyly, in which people have six fingers or toes, a harmless split in the epiglottis (a small leaf-shaped structure that prevents food and drink from entering the windpipe) and hypothalamic hamartoma, a noncancerous growth in the base of the brain that can cause seizures and other problems.

SeqA: Diagnosis/testing: The diagnosis of Pallister-Hall syndrome can be established in a proband with both hypothalamic hamartoma and mesoaxial polydactyly.
SeqB: The severe cases include laryngotracheal cleft, a defect in which the baby's airway and food passages are connected, which can lead to newborn's death if the food and saliva get into the lungs.

SeqA: Identification of a heterozygous pathogenic variant in GLI3 confirms the diagnosis.
SeqB: Mild PHS might be confused with babies having one or more extra finger or toe at birth, called postaxial polydactyly type A.

SeqA: Management: Treatment of manifestations: Urgent treatment for endocrine abnormalities, especially cortisol deficiency; management of epiglottic abnormalities depending on the abnormality and the extent of respiratory compromise.
SeqB: In people with PHS pituitary gland, located in the brain, might not produce enough hormones (substances that regulate growth, metabolism and other functions).

SeqA: Bifid epiglottis, the most common abnormality, typically does not need treatment.
SeqB: People with PHS may have adrenal insufficiency, a condition in which the adrenal glands do not produce enough hormones to control blood pressure, metabolism and the immune system.

SeqA: Standard treatment of anal atresia or stenosis; symptomatic treatment of seizures; elective repair of polydactyly; developmental intervention or special education for developmental delays.
SeqB: If these conditions are not recognized and treated in newborns, they may die.

SeqA: Prevention of secondary complications: Biopsy or resection of hypothalamic hamartoma may result in complications and lifelong need for hormone replacement; seizures may begin or worsen with use of stimulants for attention deficit disorder.
SeqB: Hypothalamic hamartoma (non-cancer growth in the brain) and extra fingers or toes may be caused by Pallister-Hall syndrome.

SeqA: Surveillance: During childhood, annual developmental assessment and annual medical evaluation to assess growth and monitor for signs of precocious puberty.
SeqB: Genetic testing confirms the patients have PHS.

SeqA: Genetic counseling: Pallister-Hall syndrome is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner.
SeqB: Urgent treatments are needed if the glands do not produce enough hormones, especially cortisol.

SeqA: Individuals with PHS may have an affected parent or may have the disorder as the result of a de novo pathogenic variant.
SeqB: The defect in the flap that covers the windpipe needs treatment if it can lead to problems with breathing.

SeqA: About 25% of individuals have a de novo pathogenic variant.
SeqB: Bifid epiglottis, the split in the flap that covers the windpipe, typically does not need treatment.

SeqA: Persons with a de novo pathogenic variant are generally more severely affected than those with a family history of PHS.
SeqB: Standard treatments are used for problems with anus, such as narrowing of the anal canal.

SeqA: The risk to offspring of an affected individual is 50%.
SeqB: Patients can choose to repair extra fingers.

SeqA: Prenatal testing for pregnancies at increased risk is possible if the pathogenic variant in the family is known.
SeqB: Seizures are treated as needed.

SeqA: The reliability of ultrasound examination for prenatal diagnosis is unknown.
SeqB: Special education and other support are provided for developmental delays.

SeqA: Polydactyly is a relatively common abnormality in infants.
SeqB: Extra fingers or toes are relatively common in newborns.

SeqA: However, it can be a marker of a wide variety of neurological and systemic abnormality.
SeqB: It can be a sign of different problems with the nervous and other systems.

SeqA: Hence, it is important for pediatrician and physician to have insight into the various association of this apparently innocuous anomaly.
SeqB: Doctors need to know about the conditions that cause extra fingers and toes.

SeqA: In this write-up, we report an extremely rare syndrome associated with polydactyly that is Pallister-Hall syndrome.
SeqB: Pallister-Hall syndrome is a rare condition associated with having extra fingers and toes.

SeqA: A 10-month-old male child born by lower segment cesarean section presented with global delay associated with microcephaly, frontal bossing, hypertelorism, flat nose, short philtrum, incomplete cleft in the upper lip and hard palate, polydactyly, and syndactyly.

SeqA: The child presented with repeated vomiting and crying episodes.
SeqB: The child vomited and cried repeatedly.

SeqA: The patient was investigated which revealed a hypothalamic hamartomas.
SeqB: An examination showed the child had hypothalamic hamartomas, a non-cancer growth of tissue in the brain.

SeqA: Pallister-Hall syndrome is a very rare autosomal dominant genetic disorder due to mutation in GLI3 gene in the short arm of chromosome 7 with variable penetrance and expressivity.
SeqB: Pallister-Hall syndrome is a rare disorder passed down by one of the parents.

SeqA: Pallister Hall syndrome is autosomal dominant disorder usually diagnosed in infants and children.
SeqB: Pallister Hall syndrome is passed down by one of the parents.

SeqA: Current diagnostic criteria include presence of hypothalamic hamartoma, post axial polydactyly and positive family history, but the disease has variable manifestations.
SeqB: It is usually diagnosed in infants and children.

SeqA: A 59 year old man developed seizures 4 years prior to our evaluation of him, at which time imaging showed a hypothalamic hamartoma.
SeqB: We diagnosed Pallister Hall syndrome in a family where both patients were adults.

SeqA: The seizures were controlled medically.
SeqB: A 59 year old man developed seizures 4 years before we examined him.

SeqA: He did well until he had visual changes after a traumatic head injury.

SeqA: There was no evidence of pituitary dysfunction except for large urine volume.

SeqA: In this neuroimaging study, we aimed to identify the specific anatomical features of trigeminal nerve root in patients with concomitant continuous pain.
SeqB: We studied patients with continuous pain.

SeqA: Methods: We enrolled 73 patients with a definitive diagnosis of classical and idiopathic trigeminal neuralgia and 40 healthy participants.
SeqB: We studied 73 patients with trigeminal neuralgia (nerve pain) and 40 healthy participants.

SeqA: The diagnosis of trigeminal neuralgia was independently confirmed by two clinicians.
SeqB: The diagnosis of trigeminal neuralgia was independently confirmed by two clinicians.

SeqA: Patients were grouped as patients with purely paroxysmal pain (45 patients) and patients also with concomitant continuous pain (28 patients).
SeqB: 45 patients had only Burts of pain and 28 patients had continuous pain along with the bursts.

SeqA: All participants underwent a structured clinical examination and a 3T MRI with sequences dedicated to the anatomical study of the trigeminal nerve root, including volumetric study.
SeqB: All patients had clinical examination and MRI.

SeqA: Images analysis was independently performed by two investigators, blinded to any clinical data.
SeqB: Two specialists studied the images without losing at the clinical data.

SeqA: Results:
SeqB: In most patients with continuous pain it started as burning, throbbing or aching sensation.

SeqA: In most patients with concomitant continuous pain, this type of pain, described as burning, throbbing or aching, manifested at the disease onset.
SeqB: The patients in the two groups and the frequency and location of the nerve damage signs in these patients were similar On the contrary, patients with both the bursts and continuous pain had more atrophy ((decrease in size) of the trigeminal nerve than the patients with bursts only.

SeqA: Demographic and clinical variables did not differ between the two groups of patients; the frequency of neurovascular compression and nerve dislocation were similar.
SeqB: Clinical examination of patients with trigeminal nerve pain and their medical images show that patients who experienced continuous pain along with pain bursts lost some nerve tissues.

SeqA: Conversely, trigeminal nerve root atrophy was more severe in patients with concomitant continuous pain than in those with purely paroxysmal pain (p = 0.006).
SeqB: This type of pain is related to wrong signaling in the nerve that lost tissues.

SeqA: Orofacial pain syndromes encompass several clinically defined and classified entities.
SeqB: Orofacial pain syndromes are diseases known to cause pain in the face and mouth.

SeqA: The focus here is on the role of clinical neurophysiologic and psychophysical tests in the diagnosis, differential diagnosis, and pathophysiological mechanisms of definite trigeminal neuropathic pain and other chronic orofacial pain conditions (excluding headache and temporomandibular disorders).
SeqB: We discuss clinical examinations of the neural system that help identifying trigeminal nerve pain and other chronic facial pain conditions, but not headaches and problems with TMJ.

SeqA: The International Classification of Headache Disorders 2018 classifies these facial pain disorders under the heading Painful cranial neuropathies and other facial pains.
SeqB: The International Classification of Headache Disorders 2018 classifies these facial pain disorders under the heading Painful cranial neuropathies and other facial pains.

SeqA: In addition to unambiguous painful posttraumatic or postherpetic trigeminal neuropathies, burning mouth syndrome, persistent idiopathic facial and dental pain, and trigeminal neuralgia have also been identified with neurophysiologic and quantitative sensory testing to involve the nervous system.
SeqB: Clinical examinations of the nervous system help identifying painful conditions of the trigeminal nerve, which carries sensation from the face to the brain.

SeqA: Despite normal clinical examination, these all include clusters of patients with evidence for either peripheral or central nervous system pathology compatible with the subclinical end of a continuum of trigeminal neuropathic pain conditions.
SeqB: These conditions may start after an injury (posttraumatic trigeminal neuropathy) or herpes infection (postherpetic trigeminal neuropathy).

SeqA: Useful tests in the diagnostic process include electroneuromyography with specific needle, neurography techniques for the inferior alveolar and infraorbital nerves, brain stem reflex recordings (blink reflex with stimulation of the supraorbital, infraorbital, mental, and lingual nerves; jaw jerk; masseter silent period), evoked potential recordings, and quantitative sensory testing.
SeqB: Other related conditions are burning mouth syndrome (a burning, scalding, or tingling feeling in the mouth) and persistent idiopathic facial and dental pain, which is described as continuing pain in the face and teeth of unknown cause.

SeqA: Habituation of the blink reflex and evoked potential responses to repeated stimuli evaluate top-down inhibition, and navigated transcranial magnetic stimulation allows the mapping of reorganization within the motor cortex in chronic neuropathic pain.
SeqB: Even patients who appear normal on clinical examination have damage to their nervous system that can cause trigeminal nerve pain.

SeqA: With systematic use of neurophysiologic and quantitative sensory testing, many of the current ambiguities in the diagnosis, classification, and understanding of chronic orofacial syndromes can be clarified for clinical practice and future research.
SeqB: Diagnostic tests include recording electrical signals in the muscles (electroneuromyography), MRI of the nerves around the eyes, blink reflexes and jaw jerk when different nerves are stimulated, recording electrical signals after the nerves are stimulated, and tests for pain sensation.

SeqA: Background:
SeqB: The three vaccines against coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) work well and fewer vaccinated people get sick.

SeqA: Although the three vaccines against coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) that have received emergency use authorization in the United States are highly effective, breakthrough infections are occurring.
SeqB: Breakthrough infections still sometimes happen, which means vaccinated people may get sick.

SeqA: Data are needed on the serial use of homologous boosters (same as the primary vaccine) and heterologous boosters (different from the primary vaccine) in fully vaccinated recipients.
SeqB: We need data on the use of the same booster and boosters that are different from the primary vaccine in fully vaccinated people.

SeqA: Methods: In this phase 1-2, open-label clinical trial conducted at 10 sites in the United States, adults who had completed a Covid-19 vaccine regimen at least 12 weeks earlier and had no reported history of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) infection received a booster injection with one of three vaccines: mRNA-1273 (Moderna) at a dose of 100 ??g, Ad26.COV2.S (Johnson & Johnson-Janssen) at a dose of 5??1010 virus particles, or BNT162b2 (Pfizer-BioNTech) at a dose of 30 ??g.
SeqB: In this clinical trial, fully vaccinated adults with no reported history of COVID-19 infection got a booster injection at least 12 weeks after the primary vaccination.

SeqA: The primary end points were safety, reactogenicity, and humoral immunogenicity on trial days 15 and 29.
SeqB: They got one of the three vaccines: Moderna, Johnson & Johnson-Janssen, or Pfizer.

SeqA: Results: Of the 458 participants who were enrolled in the trial, 154 received mRNA-1273, 150 received Ad26.COV2.S, and 153 received BNT162b2 as booster vaccines; 1 participant did not receive the assigned vaccine.
SeqB: On trial days 15 and 29 they were checked for booster safety, signs of the body??s response to the vaccine, and ability to build up protection against the COVID-19 virus.

SeqA: Reactogenicity was similar to that reported for the primary series.
SeqB: 458 people participated in the trial.

SeqA: More than half the recipients reported having injection-site pain, malaise, headache, or myalgia.
SeqB: 154 got Moderna, 150 got Johnson & Johnson, and 153 got Pfizer.

SeqA: For all combinations, antibody neutralizing titers against a SARS-CoV-2 D614 G pseudovirus increased by a factor of 4 to 73, and binding titers increased by a factor of 5 to 55.
SeqB: Signs of the body??s response to the booster were similar to the primary vaccine.

SeqA: Homologous boosters increased neutralizing antibody titers by a factor of 4 to 20, whereas heterologous boosters increased titers by a factor of 6 to 73.
SeqB: More than half had injection-site pain, general discomfort, headache, or muscle aches.

SeqA: Spike-specific T-cell responses increased in all but the homologous Ad26.COV2.S-boosted subgroup.
SeqB: All boosters increased the body's ability to protect itself against the SARS-CoV-2 virus from 4-fold to over 70-fold.

SeqA: CD8+ T-cell levels were more durable in the Ad26.COV2.S-primed recipients, and heterologous boosting with the Ad26.COV2.S vaccine substantially increased spike-specific CD8+ T cells in the mRNA vaccine recipients.
SeqB: The numbers of the antibodies that protect against COVID-19 increased from 5-fold to over 50-fold.

SeqA: Conclusions: Homologous and heterologous booster vaccines had an acceptable safety profile and were immunogenic in adults who had completed a primary Covid-19 vaccine regimen at least 12 weeks earlier.
SeqB: Using the same vaccine for the boosters increased the protection up to 20-fold, but using a different vaccine increased the protection more.

SeqA: Background: The humoral immune response after primary immunisation with a SARS-CoV-2 vector vaccine (AstraZeneca AZD1222, ChAdOx1 nCoV-19, Vaxzevria) followed by an mRNA vaccine boost (Pfizer/BioNTech, BNT162b2; Moderna, m-1273) was examined and compared with the antibody response after homologous vaccination schemes (AZD1222/AZD1222 or BNT162b2/BNT162b2).
SeqB: We studied how the immune system responds to Pfizer or Moderna booster after AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccination.

SeqA: Methods: Sera from 59 vaccinees were tested for anti-SARS-CoV-2 immunoglobulin G (IgG) and virus-neutralising antibodies (VNA) with three IgG assays based on (parts of) the SARS-CoV-2 spike (S)-protein as antigen, an IgG immunoblot (additionally contains the SARS-CoV-2 nucleoprotein (NP) as an antigen), a surrogate neutralisation test (sVNT), and a Vero-cell-based virus-neutralisation test (cVNT) with the B.1.1.7 variant of concern (VOC; alpha) as antigen.
SeqB: We compared these cross-vaccine boosters to using the same boosters as the original vaccine: AstraZeneca or Pfizer.

SeqA: Investigation was done before and after heterologous (n = 30 and 42) or homologous booster vaccination (AZD1222/AZD1222, n = 8/9; BNT162b2/BNT162b2, n = 8/8).
SeqB: We tested the blood of 59 vaccinated people for its ability to neutralize the SARS-CoV-2 virus and for the chemicals the body produced to fight the virus.

SeqA: After the second immunisation, a subgroup of 26 age- and gender-matched sera (AZD1222/mRNA, n = 9; AZD1222/AZD1222, n = 9; BNT162b2/BNT162b2, n = 8) was also tested for VNA against VOC B.1.617.2 (delta) in the cVNT.
SeqB: The blood was tested before and after the booster vaccine was given.

SeqA: The strength of IgG binding to separate SARS-CoV-2 antigens was measured by avidity.
SeqB: After the first vaccine, chemicals against the parts of the virus that damage human cells ranged from 55-95% for AstraZeneca to 100% for Pfizer.

SeqA: Results:
SeqB: After the boosters, the blood developed highly effective chemicals that block the parts of the virus that damage human cells.

SeqA: After the first vaccination, the prevalence of IgG directed against the (trimeric) SARS-CoV-2 S-protein and its receptor binding domain (RBD) varied from 55-95% (AZD1222) to 100% (BNT162b2), depending on the vaccine regimen and the SARS-CoV-2 antigen used.
SeqB: Vaccination with different boosters caused the blood to produce more anti-COVID-19 chemicals that boosting with the same AstraZeneca vaccine.

SeqA: The booster vaccination resulted in 100% seroconversion and the occurrence of highly avid IgG, which is directed against the S-protein subunit 1 and the RBD, as well as VNA against VOC B.1.1.7, while anti-NP IgGs were not detected.
SeqB: Boosting with different vaccines strongly protects against COVID-19 at about the same level as boosting with the same original Pfizer vaccine.

SeqA: The results of the three anti-SARS-CoV-2 IgG tests showed an excellent correlation to the VNA titres against this VOC.
SeqB: All vaccines caused the blood to develop strong protection 2 weeks after the second vaccine dose.

SeqA: The agreement of cVNT and sVNT results was good.
SeqB: The protection against the delta variant of COVID-19 was not as strong in the 26 people in whom it was measured.

SeqA: Rationale for review: Heterologous prime-boost doses of COVID-19 vaccines ('mix-and-match' approach) are being studied to test for the effectiveness of Oxford (AZD1222), Pfizer (BNT162b2), Moderna (mRNA-1273) and Novavax (NVX-CoV2373) vaccines for COVID in 'Com-Cov2 trial' in UK, and that of Oxford and Pfizer vaccines in 'CombivacS trial' in Spain.
SeqB: ??Mix-and-match?? boosters against COVID-19 are being studied in UK and Spain using Oxford, Pfizer, Moderna and Novavax vaccines.

SeqA: Later, other heterologous combinatios of CoronaVac (DB15806), Janssen (JNJ-78436735), CanSino (AD5-nCOV), and other were also being trialed to explore their effectiveness.
SeqB: Other combinations of CoronaVac, Janssen, and CanSino are also being tested.

SeqA: Previously, such a strategy was deployed for HIV, Ebola virus, malaria, tuberculosis, influenza, and hepatitis B to develop the artificial acquired active immunity.
SeqB: The ??mix-and-match?? strategy has been used before to develop body protection against other diseases.

SeqA: The present review explores the science behind such an approach for candidate COVID-19 vaccines developed using eleven different platforms approved by the World Health Organization.
SeqB: We will try to understand why this approach might work for COVID-19.

SeqA: Key findings: The candidate vaccines' pharmaceutical parameters (e.g. platforms, number needed to vaccinate and intervals, adjuvanted status, excipients and preservatives added, efficacy and effectiveness, vaccine adverse events, and boosters), and clinical aspects must be analysed for the mix-and-match approach.
SeqB: To study the mix-and-match approach, we look at how the different vaccines work, the chemicals in the vaccines and their side effects.

SeqA: Heterologous prime-boost trials showed safety, effectiveness, higher systemic reactogenicity, well tolerability with improved immunogenicity, and flexibility profiles for future vaccinations, especially during acute and global shortages, compared to the homologous counterparts.
SeqB: The mix-and-match strategy is safe, improves body protection and allows to deal with vaccine shortages.

SeqA: Background: Given the importance of flexible use of different COVID-19 vaccines within the same schedule to facilitate rapid deployment, we studied mixed priming schedules incorporating an adenoviral-vectored vaccine (ChAdOx1 nCoV-19 [ChAd], AstraZeneca), two mRNA vaccines (BNT162b2
SeqB: It is important to have flexibility in using different COVID-19 vaccines for additional doses.

SeqB: We also studied safety of the vaccines.

SeqA: Safety analyses were done for all participants who received a dose of study vaccine.
SeqB: 1072 people participated in the study 9.4 weeks after getting the first vaccine.

SeqA: The trial is registered with ISRCTN, number 27841311.
SeqB: 540 people got the first dose of AstraZeneca and 532 got Pfizer.

SeqA: There were 15 serious adverse events, none considered related to immunisation.

SeqA: Background: While Coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) vaccines are highly effective, breakthrough infections are occurring.
SeqB: Coronavirus disease 2019 vaccines protect against Covid-19 well, but some vaccinated people may get sick, which is called breakthrough infections.

SeqA: Booster vaccinations have recently received emergency use authorization (EUA) for certain populations but are restricted to homologous mRNA vaccines.
SeqB: Boosters with the same Pfizer or Moderna vaccines are approved as an emergency measure for some people.

SeqA: We evaluated homologous and heterologous booster vaccination in persons who had received an EUA Covid-19 vaccine regimen.
SeqB: We evaluated boosters with the same and different vaccines in people who got the emergency Covid-19 vaccination.

SeqA: Methods: In this phase 1/2 open-label clinical trial conducted at ten U.S. sites, adults who received one of three EUA Covid-19 vaccines at least 12 weeks prior to enrollment and had no reported history of SARS-CoV-2 infection received a booster injection with one of three vaccines (Moderna mRNA-1273 100-??g, Janssen Ad26.COV2.S 5??10 10 virus particles, or Pfizer-BioNTech BNT162b2 30-??g; nine combinations).
SeqB: In this clinical trial, adults in ten U.S. locations got Moderna, Janssen or Pfizer boosters at least 12 weeks after getting the first vaccine.

SeqA: The primary outcomes were safety, reactogenicity, and humoral immunogenicity on study days 15 and 29.
SeqB: We evaluated the vaccine safety and protection against COVID-19 on study days 15 and 29.

SeqA: Results: 458 individuals were enrolled: 154 received mRNA-1273, 150 received Ad26.CoV2.S, and 153 received BNT162b2 booster vaccines.
SeqB: Out of 458 people, 154 got Moderna, 150 got Janssen and 153 got Pfizer boosters.

SeqA: Reactogenicity was similar to that reported for the primary series.
SeqB: Adverse reactions to the booster were similar to those reported for the first vaccine.

SeqA: Injection site pain, malaise, headache, and myalgia occurred in more than half the participants.
SeqB: More than half of the participants had pain at the injection site, overall weakness, headache, and muscle pains.

SeqA: Booster vaccines increased the neutralizing activity against a D614G pseudovirus (4.2-76-fold) and binding antibody titers (4.6-56-fold) for all combinations; homologous boost increased neutralizing antibody titers 4.2-20-fold whereas heterologous boost increased titers 6.2-76-fold.
SeqB: Boosters with the same and different vaccines increased protection against the virus.

SeqA: Day 15 neutralizing and binding antibody titers varied by 28.7-fold and 20.9-fold, respectively, across the nine prime-boost combinations.
SeqB: The increase in protection after a different booster was higher.

SeqA: Conclusion: Homologous and heterologous booster vaccinations were well-tolerated and immunogenic in adults who completed a primary Covid-19 vaccine regimen at least 12 weeks earlier.
SeqB: Boosters with the same and different vaccines were well-tolerated and increased protection against COVID-19 in adults who had the first vaccine at least 12 weeks earlier.

SeqA: Background: Use of heterologous prime-boost COVID-19 vaccine schedules could facilitate mass COVID-19 immunisation.
SeqB: Boosters that are not of the same type as the first COVID-19 vaccine can make global COVID-19 immunization easier.

SeqA: However, we have previously reported that heterologous schedules incorporating an adenoviral vectored vaccine (ChAdOx1 nCoV-19, AstraZeneca; hereafter referred to as ChAd) and an mRNA vaccine (BNT162b2, Pfizer-BioNTech; hereafter referred to as BNT) at a 4-week interval are more reactogenic than homologous schedules.
SeqB: However, we know that getting AstraZeneca and Pfizer 4 weeks apart causes more side effects than getting the same vaccine.

SeqA: Here, we report the safety and immunogenicity of heterologous schedules with the ChAd and BNT vaccines.
SeqB: We report the safety and protective strength of different ways to combine AstraZeneca and Pfizer vaccines.

SeqA: Methods: Com-COV is a participant-blinded, randomised, non-inferiority trial evaluating vaccine safety, reactogenicity, and immunogenicity.
SeqB: Healthy adults aged 50 years and older that did not have COVID-19 participated in a clinical trial.

SeqA: Adults aged 50 years and older with no or well controlled comorbidities and no previous SARS-CoV-2 infection by laboratory confirmation were eligible and were recruited at eight sites across the UK.
SeqB: Most participants got two doses of AstraZeneca or Pfizer or a combination of Pfizer/AstraZeneca or AstraZeneca/Pfizer 28 or 84 days apart.

SeqA: The majority of eligible participants were enrolled into the general cohort (28-day or 84-day prime-boost intervals), who were randomly assigned (1:1:1:1:1:1:1:1) to receive ChAd/ChAd, ChAd/BNT, BNT/BNT, or BNT/ChAd, administered at either 28-day or 84-day prime-boost intervals.
SeqB: 100 of the participants that had the vaccines 28 days apart was checked for the protective chemicals in the blood more often.

SeqA: A small subset of eligible participants (n=100) were enrolled into an immunology cohort, who had additional blood tests to evaluate immune responses; these participants were randomly assigned (1:1:1:1) to the four schedules (28-day interval only).
SeqB: Participants did not know which vaccines they got.

SeqA: Participants were masked to the vaccine received but not to the prime-boost interval.
SeqB: 28 days after boost, chemicals that fight the SARS-CoV-2 virus were measured in patients' blood.

SeqA: The primary endpoint was the geometric mean ratio (GMR) of serum SARS-CoV-2 anti-spike IgG concentration (measured by ELISA) at 28 days after boost, when comparing ChAd/BNT with ChAd/ChAd, and BNT/ChAd with BNT/BNT.
SeqB: Different-vaccine boosters were considered to be as good as the same-vaccine if the increase in the protective chemicals after the booster was the same or higher for the different vaccines.

SeqA: The heterologous schedules were considered non-inferior to the approved homologous schedules if the lower limit of the one-sided 97??5% CI of the GMR of these comparisons was greater than 0??63.
SeqB: Protection against COVID-19 was measured in all participants.

SeqA: The primary analysis was done in the per-protocol population, who were seronegative at baseline.
SeqB: Safety of the vaccine was measured among participants that had at least one dose of the vaccine.

SeqA: Safety analyses were done among participants receiving at least one dose of a study vaccine.
SeqB: For 463 participants with 28 days between the first vaccine and the booster, the results are reported here.

SeqA: The trial is registered with ISRCTN, 69254139.
SeqB: The participants were 54 to 65 years old.

SeqA: Findings: Between Feb 11 and Feb 26, 2021, 830 participants were enrolled and randomised, including 463 participants with a 28-day prime-boost interval, for whom results are reported here.
SeqB: About half (212) were women and a quarter (117) were from ethnic minorities.

SeqA: The mean age of participants was 57??8 years (SD 4??7), with 212 (46%) female participants and 117 (25%) from ethnic minorities.
SeqB: 28 days after the booster, in people who got boosted with Pfizer after AstraZeneca, protection against the SARS-CoV-2 virus was not worse than in those who got the same AstraZeneca booster.

SeqA: At day 28 post boost, the geometric mean concentration of SARS-CoV-2 anti-spike IgG in ChAd/BNT recipients (12 906 ELU/mL) was non-inferior to that in ChAd/ChAd recipients (1392 ELU/mL), with a GMR of 9??2 (one-sided 97??5% CI 7??5 to ???).
SeqB: Boosting with AstraZeneca after Pfizer was not as good as getting the second dose of the same Pfizer vaccine.

SeqA: In participants primed with BNT, we did not show non-inferiority of the heterologous schedule (BNT/ChAd, 7133 ELU/mL) against the homologous schedule (BNT/BNT, 14 080 ELU/mL), with a GMR of 0??51 (one-sided 97??5% CI 0??43 to ???).
SeqB: Four people had serious health problems during the trial.

SeqA: Four serious adverse events occurred across all groups, none of which were considered to be related to immunisation.
SeqB: The problems were not related to getting the vaccines.

SeqA: Interpretation:
SeqB: Although getting AstraZeneca after Pfizer was not as good as getting only Pfizer or Pfizer after AstraZeneca, there were still more protective chemicals against SARS-CoV-2 in the blood compared to getting only AstraZeneca.

SeqA: Despite the BNT/ChAd regimen not meeting non-inferiority criteria, the SARS-CoV-2 anti-spike IgG concentrations of both heterologous schedules were higher than that of a licensed vaccine schedule (ChAd/ChAd) with proven efficacy against COVID-19 disease and hospitalisation.
SeqB: Getting only AstraZeneca is known to protect against COVID-19 and hospitalization.

SeqA: Along with the higher immunogenicity of ChAd/BNT compared with ChAD/ChAd, these data support flexibility in the use of heterologous prime-boost vaccination using ChAd and BNT COVID-19 vaccines.
SeqB: This trial supports using boosters that are not the same as the first COVID-19 vaccine.

SeqA: Reports of waning antibody levels and breakthrough infections among vaccinated individuals1 have prompted the recommendation for vaccine boosters to prevent SARS-CoV-2 infections.
SeqB: Boosters to prevent SARS-CoV-2 infections in those who had the first vaccines are needed because the amount of body substances that protect against the virus goes down and people get COVID-19, which is called breakthrough infections.

SeqA: Despite more than 80% of the population in Singapore having received 2 doses of a COVID-19 vaccine, cases surged in September 2021 with the relaxation of social distancing and quarantine measures.
SeqB: Although 80 out of 100 people in Singapore had 2 doses of a COVID-19 vaccine, COVID-19 surged in September 2021 as the social distancing and quarantine rules were relaxed.

SeqA: In response, adults 60 years and older who completed their primary vaccination series at least 6 months prior were invited to receive a booster injection and given a choice of either 30-??g BNT162b2 (Pfizer-BioNTech) or 50-??g mRNA-1273 (Moderna).
SeqB: Adults 60 years and older who got the first vaccine at least 6 months before were invited to get a booster of Pfizer or Moderna.

SeqA: We estimated SARS-CoV-2 infections and disease severity with the receipt of a booster and by type of booster.
SeqB: We estimated SARS-CoV-2 infections and disease severity after getting a booster and by type of booster.

SeqA: Methods: This study was carried out under the Infectious Diseases Act for policy decision-making and exempted from ethical review and informed consent by the Singapore Ministry of Health.
SeqB: Rates and severity of SARS-CoV-2 infections between September 15 and October 31, 2021, among those eligible to receive vaccine boosters were studied.

SeqA: Rates and severity of SARS-CoV-2 infections between September 15 and October 31, 2021, among those eligible to receive vaccine boosters between September 15 and October 15, 2021, were analyzed based on official data reported to the Singapore Ministry of Health.
SeqB: COVID-19 patients were found through testing of those with symptoms and high-risk workers and close contacts without symptoms.

SeqA: Cases were identified through testing of symptomatic individuals and nonsymptomatic high-risk workers and close contacts.
SeqB: We measured infections confirmed by tests and severe disease (requiring oxygen support, intensive care admission, or death due to COVID-19).

SeqA: Outcomes included polymerase chain reaction??confirmed infections and severe disease (requiring oxygen supplementation, intensive care admission, or death due to COVID-19).
SeqB: People who got the boosters 12 days before were included in the booster group, and non-booster group otherwise.

SeqA: Individuals were classified under the booster group 12 days after receiving a vaccine booster and under the nonbooster group otherwise to account for time required for antibody levels to rise.
SeqB: Depending on the day of observation, a person could be in either group.

SeqA: Person-days at risk were reported because individuals could contribute observations to both the nonbooster and booster groups.
SeqB: We estimated getting infected and severe disease between booster and non-booster groups that got the first vaccination with Pfizer or Moderna.

SeqA: Using a Poisson regression, we estimated the incidence rate ratio (IRR) of confirmed infections and severe disease between booster and nonbooster groups by type of vaccine received for the primary series (BNT162b2 or mRNA-1273).
SeqB: We accounted for the patients' sex, race, housing type, age, and the date of second vaccine that may be related to the strength of protection.

SeqA: Results:
SeqB: Patients who lost their sense pf smell had a higher chance to test positive for COVID-19.

SeqA: In total, 374 patients in 14 primary care centers received CovPCR and were included in this analysis.

SeqA: The median age was 44.0 (IQR: 31.0-59.0) and a fraction of 10.7% (n = 40) tested positive for COVID-19.

SeqA: Antigen-detecting rapid diagnostic tests (Ag-RDTs) can complement molecular diagnostics for COVID-19.

SeqA: The recommended temperature for storage of SARS-CoV-2 Ag-RDTs ranges between 2-30 ??C.

SeqA: In the global South, mean temperatures can exceed 30 ??C.

SeqA: In the global North, Ag-RDTs are often used in external testing facilities at low ambient temperatures.

SeqB: After 3 weeks of storage at high temperature (37 C), eight of the 11 rapid tests were ten-fold less accurate.

SeqB: Two out of six rapid tests had false positive results at low temperatures (2-4 degrees C).

SeqA: Background: COVID-19 is an ongoing public health pandemic regardless of the countless efforts made by various actors.

SeqA: To investigate endogenous interference factors of the detection results of novel severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) IgM/IgG. Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) was used to detect SARS-CoV-2 IgM/IgG in sera of 200 patients without COVID-19 infection, including rheumatoid factor (RF) positive group, antinuclear antibody (ANA) positive group, pregnant women group, and normal senior group, with 50 in each group and 100 normal controls.

SeqA: At the start of the COVID-19 pandemic, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) designed, manufactured, and distributed the CDC 2019-Novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV) Real-Time RT-PCR Diagnostic Panel for SARS-CoV-2 detection.
SeqB: At the start of the COVID-19 pandemic, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) designed, provides rapid test for detecting SARS-CoV-2 virus that causes the disease.

SeqA: The diagnostic panel targeted three viral nucleocapsid gene loci (N1, N2, and N3 primers and probes) to maximize sensitivity and to provide redundancy for virus detection if mutations occurred.
SeqB: The tests target different parts of the virus in case some parts of the virus change (mutate).

SeqA: After the first distribution of the diagnostic panel, state public health laboratories reported fluorescent signal in the absence of viral template (false-positive reactivity) for the N3 component and to a lesser extent for N1.
SeqB: Parts of the test that target two specific parts of the virus may show false positive results -- identify people that do not have the virus as having it.

SeqA: This report describes the findings of an internal investigation conducted by the CDC to identify the cause(s) of the N1 and N3 false-positive reactivity.
SeqB: We report the results of the CDC analysis of the false positive tests..

SeqA: For N1, results demonstrate that contamination with a synthetic template, that occurred while the "bulk" manufactured materials were located in a research lab for quality assessment, was the cause of false reactivity in the first lot.
SeqB: One part of the test that targeted one part of the virus was tainted with the material similar to that part when the test was produced, which caused false positive results.

SeqA: Base pairing between the 3' end of the N3 probe and the 3' end of the N3 reverse primer led to amplification of duplex and larger molecules resulting in false reactivity in the N3 assay component.
SeqB: In another component of the test, some chemicals interacted with each other and caused false positive results.

SeqA: We conclude that flaws in both assay design and handling of the "bulk" material, caused the problems with the first lot of the 2019-nCoV Real-Time RT-PCR Diagnostic Panel.

SeqA: In addition, within this study, we found that the age of the examined diagnostic panel reagents increases the frequency of false positive results for N3.
SeqB: We found that the tests that were stored longer gave more false positive results.

SeqA: We discuss these findings in the context of improvements to quality control, quality assurance, and assay validation practices that have since been improved at the CDC.
SeqB: After our study, CDC improved quality control and procedures for checking accuracy of the tests.

SeqA: The aim was to determine the accuracy of anterior nasal swab in rapid antigen (Ag) tests in a low SARS-CoV-2 prevalence and massive screened community.

SeqB: For 32 of these, the rapid nasal test was also positive.

SeqB: We did not have any false positive tests.

SeqA: The lower sensitivity is a challenge especially if Ag testing is not repeated frequently allowing this scalable test to be a robust supplement to RT-PCR testing in an ambitious public SARS-CoV-2 screening.
SeqB: Overlooking more than half of the patients with the disease is a problem.

SeqA: Antigen-based rapid diagnostics tests (Ag-RDTs) are useful tools for severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) detection.
SeqB: Rapid diagnostics tests are useful for detecting COVID-19 virus.

SeqB: Misleading demos of the rapid test on social media showed it can find COVID-19 virus in the tap water and food.

SeqA: To offer a scientific rebuttal to pandemic misinformation and disinformation, this study explored the impact of using the Panbio SARS-CoV-2 assay with conditions falling outside manufacturer recommendations.

SeqA: Using Panbio, various water and food products, laboratory buffers, and SARS-CoV-2-negative clinical specimens were tested with and without manufacturer buffer.

SeqB: We also studied how different temperatures and humidity change test results.

SeqA: Direct sample testing (without the kit buffer) resulted in false-positive signals resembling those obtained with SARS-CoV-2 positive controls tested under proper conditions.
SeqB: Doing the test wrong caused false positive results saying there is COVID-19 virus in the materials that did not have it.

SeqA: The likely explanation of these artifacts is nonspecific interactions between the SARS-CoV-2-specific conjugated and capture antibodies, as proteinase K treatment abrogated this phenomenon, and thermal shift assays showed pH-induced conformational changes under conditions promoting artifact formation.
SeqB: False results may happen because the parts of the test change if the test is done wrong.

SeqA: Omitting, altering, and reverse engineering the kit buffer all supported the importance of maintaining buffering capacity, ionic strength, and pH for accurate kit function.
SeqB: The test changed less in extremes of temperature and humidity.

SeqA: Interestingly, the Panbio assay could tolerate some extremes of temperature and humidity outside manufacturer claims.
SeqB: Our study supports strictly following the test instructions to reduce false positive results of COVID-19 rapid test.

SeqA: Our data support strict adherence to manufacturer instructions to avoid false-positive SARS-CoV-2 Ag-RDT reactions, otherwise resulting in anxiety, overuse of public health resources, and dissemination of misinformation.
SeqB: False positive results increase anxiety, overuse of public health resources, and spread of rumors.

SeqA: IMPORTANCE:
SeqB: The Panbio rapid COVID-19 test that we studied is used in over 120 countries worldwide.

SeqA: With the Panbio severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) antigen test being deployed in over 120 countries worldwide, understanding conditions required for its ideal performance is critical.
SeqB: It is very important to understand how to get accurate test results.

SeqA: Recently on social media, this kit was shown to generate false positives when manufacturer recommendations were not followed.
SeqB: Recently on social media, this kit was shown to generate false positives when manufacturer recommendations were not followed.

SeqA: While erroneous results from improper use of a test may not be surprising to some health care professionals, understanding why false positives occur can help reduce the propagation of misinformation and provide a scientific rebuttal for these aberrant findings.
SeqB: Health professionals know that not doing the tests right causes errors in the results.

SeqA: This study demonstrated that the kit buffer's pH, ionic strength, and buffering capacity were critical components to ensure proper kit function and avoid generation of false-positive results.
SeqB: Knowing what causes the errors will help them explain the errors and stop rumors.

SeqB: Many different parts of the test need to work properly to avoid mistakes.

SeqA: Following the manufacturer instructions is critical for accurate test results.

SeqA: Positive retests of COVID-19 represent a public health concern because of the increased risk of transmission.

SeqA: Sickle cell disease (SCD) is a hematologic disorder with complex pathophysiology that includes chronic hemolysis, vaso-occlusion and inflammation.

SeqA: Background: Early ambulation with physical therapy (PT) following total knee arthroplasty (TKA) has demonstrated benefits in the literature.

SeqA: Methods: We retrospectively identified 2 cohorts of primary TKA patients from July 2016 to December 2017: PT0 (n = 295) received PT on the day of surgery, and PT1 (n = 392) received PT on postoperative day (POD) 1.
SeqB: To do this, we looked at 2 past groups of knee replacement patients from July 2016 to December 2017.

SeqA: Outcomes studied included number of feet walked on POD0-3, visual analog scale pain scores, morphine equivalents (ME) consumed, length of stay, and discharge disposition.
SeqB: The first group had 295 patients and had PT on the day of surgery.

SeqA: Analysis was conducted using the Student t-test and Fisher exact test.
SeqB: The second group had 392 patients and received PT on the day after surgery.

SeqA: Results:
SeqB: The outcomes we looked at included the number of feet walked in the first 3 days after surgery, patient reported pain scores, amount of morphine or similar drugs used, length of stay, and where the patient was sent on discharge.

SeqA: In comparison to the PT1 group, the PT0 group walked significantly more steps on POD1 (347.6 vs 167.4 ft, P < .0001), POD2 (342.1 vs 203.5 ft, P < .0001), and POD3 (190.3 vs 128.9 ft, P = .00028).
SeqB: In comparison to the second group (which had PT the day of after surgery), the first group (which had PT the day of the surgery) walked significantly more steps on the first 3 days after surgery.

SeqA: There was no difference between the 2 groups for visual analog scale.
SeqB: The first group walked, on average, 348 feet the first day after, while the second group walked 167 feet.

SeqA: The PT0 group also consumed significantly fewer total ME when compared to the PT1 group (149.0 vs 200.3 mg, P = .0002).
SeqB: The second day, the first group walked 342 feet while the second group walked 203.

SeqA: The PT0 group had a significantly shorter length of stay when compared to the PT1 group (2.7 vs 3.2 days, P = .00075).
SeqB: The third day after surgery, the first group walked 190 feet while the second group walked 129 feet.

SeqA: More patients were discharged home in the PT0 group (81.7% vs 54.8%, P < .0001).
SeqB: There was no difference between the 2 groups for pain reported.

SeqA: Conclusion: We observed that initiation of PT on POD0 led to better PT performance, reduced ME during hospitalization, and more patients discharged home.
SeqB: The first group (which had PT the day of the surgery) also used significantly less morphine or similar drugs when compared to the second group (which had PT the day after surgery).

SeqA: Total knee arthroplasty (TKA) is the gold standard treatment for end-stage knee osteoarthritis.

SeqB: There is a potential positive influence of rehab after surgery and a lack of established standards for prescribing exercise paradigms after knee replacement.

SeqA: Optimal outpatient physical therapy protocols should include: strengthening and intensive functional exercises given through land-based or aquatic programs, the intensity of which is increased based on patient progress.

SeqB: This study involved two groups who randomly got either the standard care or the experimental care.

SeqB: It was done in community physical therapy centers and a university hospital research department.

SeqA: Setting: Community physical therapy centers and University hospital research department.
SeqB: The study included 41 adults under 75 with arthritis in one knee and who were scheduled for knee replacement surgery.

SeqA: Results:
SeqB: We looked at these 7 days after the operation, 10 weeks after, and 12 months after.

SeqA: Strength differences persisted up to 12-months follow-up.

SeqA: The difference in muscle strength was maintained at 12-month follow-up.

SeqA: Results:
SeqB: The treatments that were compared were: PT exercise without care; home and outpatient care; pool and gym-based care; walking skills and more general PT; and general PT exercise with and without additional balance exercises or a stationary bike.

SeqA: Pyridoxal-5'-phosphate (PLP), the bioactive form of vitamin B6, reportedly functions as a prosthetic group for >4% of classified enzymatic activities of the cell.

SeqA: Background: a large number of studies have linked vitamin B6 to inflammation and cardiovascular disease in the general population.

SeqA: Methods: we measured plasma pyridoxal 5'-phosphate (PLP), as an indicator of vitamin B6 status, at baseline in a population-based prospective cohort of 6249 participants of the Prevention of Renal and Vascular End-stage Disease (PREVEND) study who were free of cardiovascular disease.

SeqA: As indicators of low-grade systemic inflammation, we measured high-sensitivity C-reactive protein and GlycA; Results: median plasma PLP was 37.2 (interquartile range, 25.1-57.0) nmol/L.
SeqB: Levels of PLP in blood can show how much vitamin B6 is present in the body.

SeqA: During median follow-up for 8.3 (interquartile range, 7.8-8.9) years, 409 non-fatal and fatal cardiovascular events (composite outcome) occurred.
SeqB: Low-level widespread inflammation in the body was measured by blood levels of high-sensitivity C-reactive protein (hsCRP) and GlyA.

SeqA: In the overall cohort, log transformed plasma PLP was associated with the composite outcome, independent of adjustment for age, sex, smoking, alcohol consumption, body mass index (BMI), estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR), total cholesterol:high-density lipoprotein (HDL)-cholesterol ratio, and blood pressure (adjusted hazard ratio per increment of log plasma PLP, 0.66; 95% confidence interval (CI), 0.47-0.93).

SeqA: However, adjustment for high-sensitivity C-reactive protein and GlycA increased the hazard ratio by 9% and 12% respectively, to non-significant hazard ratios of 0.72 (95% confidence interval, 0.51-1.01) and 0.74 (95% confidence interval, 0.53-1.05).

SeqA: The association of plasma PLP with cardiovascular risk was modified by gender (adjusted Pinteraction = 0.04).
SeqB: During this time, 409 cardiovascular diseases events occurred, some were fatal.

SeqA: When stratified according to gender, in women the prospective association with cardiovascular outcome was independent of age, smoking, alcohol consumption, high-sensitivity C-reactive protein, and GlycA (adjusted hazard ratio, 0.50, 95% confidence interval, 0.27-0.94), while it was not in men (adjusted hazard, 0.99, 95% confidence interval, 0.65-1.51).

SeqA: Conclusions: in this population-based cohort, plasma PLP was associated with cardiovascular outcome, but this association was confounded by traditional risk factors and parameters of inflammation.

SeqA: Results:
SeqB: In 23 studies including 1439 patients having TKR, using local anaesthetic reduced pain at 24 hours at rest and at 48 hours during activity, compared with patients receiving no local anesthetic, or placebo (sham treatment so patients were not biased).

SeqA: In 13 studies including 909 patients undergoing THR, patients receiving local anaesthetic infiltration experienced a greater reduction in pain at 24 hours at rest by standardised mean difference (SMD) -0.61 (95% CI -1.05, -0.16; p = 0.008) and by SMD -0.43 (95% CI -0.78 -0.09; p = 0.014) at 48 hours during activity.
SeqB: In studies where more local anaesthetic was used after closing the wound, there was evidence of a bigger reduction.

SeqA: In TKR, diverse multi-modal regimens were reported.
SeqB: There was no evidence of pain control on top of what was provided by femoral nerve block, a type of local anesthetic applied directly to a large nerve in the thigh.

SeqA: In 23 studies including 1439 patients undergoing TKR, local anaesthetic infiltration reduced pain on average by SMD -0.40 (95% CI -0.58, -0.22; p < 0.001) at 24 hours at rest and by SMD -0.27 (95% CI -0.50, -0.05; p = 0.018) at 48 hours during activity, compared with patients receiving no infiltration or placebo.
SeqB: Patients that got local anaesthetic spent, on average, an estimated 0.83 fewer days in hospital after THR and 0.87 fewer days in hospital after TKR.

SeqA: There was evidence of a larger reduction in studies delivering additional local anaesthetic after wound closure.
SeqB: They also had took fewer opioids, walked earlier, and vomited less.

SeqA: There was no evidence of pain control additional to that provided by femoral nerve block.

SeqA: Patients receiving local anaesthetic infiltration spent on average an estimated 0.83 (95% CI 1.54, 0.12; p = 0.022) and 0.87 (95% CI 1.62, 0.11; p = 0.025) fewer days in hospital after THR and TKR respectively, had reduced opioid consumption, earlier mobilisation, and lower incidence of vomiting.

SeqA: Few studies reported long-term outcomes.

SeqA: Conclusions: Local anaesthetic infiltration is effective in reducing short-term pain and hospital stay in patients receiving THR and TKR.

SeqA: There are multiple available agents and modalities for controlling pain perioperatively during total joint arthroplasty to improve the patient experience, and their unique mechanisms and applications should be considered for use preoperatively, intraoperatively, and postoperatively, keeping in mind that each has differing efficacy and side-effect profiles.

SeqA: With regard to intraoperative anesthetic choice and pain control, spinal anesthesia appears to have fewer systemic risks than general anesthesia, and periarticular injections of local anesthetic agents, regardless of technique, and with or without the addition of sympathetic modulators, opioids, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) or corticosteroids, have been shown to improve pain scores postoperatively and to overall carry a low risk profile.
SeqB: Doctors should also keep in mind that each has different efficacy and side-effects.

SeqA: Multimodal pain management can decrease opioid usage, improve pain scores, increase patient satisfaction, and enhance early recovery.
SeqB: However, it is not clear what the recommended timing and type of treatment are.

SeqA: The ideal preoperative, intraoperative, and postoperative pain medication regimen remains unclear, and an individualized approach to perioperative pain management is recommended.

SeqA: Despite this, good results are demonstrated with the existing variations in pain management protocols in the literature.

SeqB: Sickle Cell Disease (SCD) was the first human genetic disorder caused by a mutation in a single gene to be described at the chemical level.

SeqB: SCD occurs when a mutation of the Beta-hemoglobin gene causes the amino acid, glutamic acid, to be replaced by valine in the beta chain of the hemoglobin protein.

SeqA: The clinical manifestations of SCD arise from the tendency of sickle hemoglobin (known as HbS or ??2??S2) to polymerize at reduced oxygen tensions and deform red cells into the characteristic rigid sickle cell shape.
SeqB: The signs and symptoms in SCD occur because these sickle hemoglobin (HbS) proteins tend to join together where oxygen levels are lower in the body.

SeqA: Such inflexible red cells cannot pass through the microcirculation efficiently, and this results in anemia (due to destruction of the red cells) and intermittent vasoocclusion causing tissue damage and pain.
SeqB: This causes the red blood cells to change into the typical abnormal rigid sickle cell shape.

SeqA: Although all patients with homozygous SCD have exactly the same molecular defect, there is considerable clinical variation, ranging from death in early childhood to a normal life span with few complications.
SeqB: These rigid red blood cells cannot pass through the smallest blood vessels well.

SeqA: Genetic modifiers of SCD include ??-thalassemia, and it has been known for many years that patients with increased levels of fetal Hb (HbF or ??2??2) often tend to have a relatively mild clinical course because HbF reduces the tendency of HbS to polymerise within the red cell.
SeqB: This causes the vessels to be blocked, resulting in tissue damage and pain.

SeqA: Increased HbF may result from rare deletions within the ??-globin gene cluster or from point mutations in the promoters of the fetal ??-globin genes (hereditary persistence of fetal hemoglobin, HPFH), but additional loci are known to increase HbF levels in adult life.
SeqB: These sickle red blood cells are also destroyed, which causes anemia.

SeqA: Identifying such loci has been a painstaking task, but a combination of genome-wide analysis within a large kindred and within twin pairs has identified two quantitative trait loci (QTL) with major influences on fetal hemoglobin levels in adults.
SeqB: Patients with the same genetic defect in SCD can have many different outcomes, ranging from death in early childhood to a normal life span with few problems.

SeqA: A significant proportion of the variation in HbF levels and the frequency of painful crises in patients with SCD is accounted for by five common single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) at these loci.
SeqB: Alpha-Thalassemia is a genetic disease that can change the outcome of patients with SCD.

SeqA: Sickle cell disease (SCD) is a debilitating monogenic blood disorder with a highly variable phenotype characterized by severe pain crises, acute clinical events, and early mortality.
SeqB: Sickle Cell Disease (SCD) is a disabling genetic blood disorder caused by a single mutation.

SeqA: Interindividual variation in fetal hemoglobin (HbF) expression is a known and potentially heritable modifier of SCD severity.
SeqB: SCD can have various outcomes,but it can result in severe pain crises, acute symptoms, and early death.

SeqA: High HbF levels are correlated with reduced morbidity and mortality.
SeqB: The severity of the problems that occur in SCD can vary depending on the amount of fetal hemoglobin (HbF) in the blood.

SeqA: Common single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) at the BCL11A and HBS1L-MYB loci have been implicated previously in HbF level variation in nonanemic European populations.
SeqB: High HbF levels are associated with decreased problems and death in patients with SCD.

SeqA: We recently demonstrated an association between a BCL11A SNP and HbF levels in one SCD cohort [Uda M, et al. (2008) Proc Natl Acad Sci USA 105:1620-1625].
SeqB: Common single mutations in two genes, BCL11A and HBS1L-MYB, are thought to cause the changes in HbF levels seen in European populations without anemia.

SeqA: Here, we genotyped additional BCL11A SNPs, HBS1L-MYB SNPs, and an SNP upstream of (G)gamma-globin (HBG2; the XmnI polymorphism), in two independent SCD cohorts: the African American Cooperative Study of Sickle Cell Disease (CSSCD) and an SCD cohort from Brazil.

SeqA: We studied the effect of these SNPs on HbF levels and on a measure of SCD-related morbidity (pain crisis rate).
SeqB: In this paper, researchers found more single mutations in the BCL11A, HBS1L-MYB, and HBC2 genes in two other groups of patients (a study in African Americans SCD patients and a study of SCD patients from Brazil).

SeqA: We strongly replicated the association between these SNPs and HbF level variation (in the CSSCD, P values range from 0.04 to 2 x 10(-42)).
SeqB: We studied the effect of these single gene mutations on HbF levels and the number of pain crises in SCD.

SeqA: Together, common SNPs at the BCL11A, HBS1L-MYB, and beta-globin (HBB) loci account for >20% of the variation in HbF levels in SCD patients.
SeqB: We showed a strong connection between the single mutations in these genes and different HbF levels.

SeqA: We also have shown that HbF-associated SNPs associate with pain crisis rate in SCD patients.
SeqB: Common single mutations in the BCL11A, HBS1L-MYB, beta-globin (HBB) genes explain >20% of the different HbF levels in SCD patients.

SeqA: These results provide a clear example of inherited common sequence variants modifying the severity of a monogenic disease.
SeqB: These mutations, associated with HbF levels, are also associated with the number of pain crises in SCD patients.

SeqA: Sickle cell anemia (SCA) is a disease characterized by abnormal red blood cell rheology.

SeqA: Fetal hemoglobin (HbF) ameliorates clinical severity of sickle cell anemia (SCA).

SeqA: Background: Our objective was to investigate the combined and differential effects of alpha-thalassemia -3.7 kb deletion and HbF-promoting quantitative trait loci (HbF-QTL) in Senegalese hydroxyurea (HU)-free children and young adults with sickle cell anemia (SCA).

SeqA: Procedure: Steady-state biological parameters and vaso-occlusive crises (VOC) requiring emergency admission were recorded over a 2-year period in 301 children with SCA.
SeqB: Steady biological signs and crises from blood vessel blockages (vaso-occlusive crises-VOC) requiring emergency admission were recorded over a 2-year period in 301 children with Sickle Cell Anemia (SCA).

SeqA: The age of the first hospitalized VOC was also recorded.
SeqB: The age of the first hospitalized VOC was also recorded.

SeqA: These data were correlated with the alpha-globin and HbF-QTL genotypes.
SeqB: These facts were compared to patients who had alpha-globin and HbF-QTL genes.

SeqA: For the latter, three different genetic loci were studied (XmnI, rs7482144; BCL11A, rs1427407; and the HBS1L-MYB region, rs28384513) and a composite score was calculated, ranging from zero (none of these three polymorphisms) to six (all three polymorphisms at the homozygous state).
SeqB: Three different gene regions on the HbF-QTL gene were studied in detail.

SeqA: Results: A positive clinical impact of the HbF-QTL score on VOC rate, HbF, leucocytes, and C-reactive protein levels was observed only for patients without alpha-thalassemia deletion.
SeqB: A score was given to patients from zero to six depending on the different changes (mutations) at the 3 gene regions.

SeqB: A higher HbF-QTL score resulted in better signs of SCA disease outcome only for patients without the alpha-thalassemia mutation.

SeqA: The age of the first hospitalized VOC was delayed for patients with one or two alpha-thalassemia deletions and at least two HbF-QTL.

SeqA: Conclusion: Alpha-thalassemia -3.7 kb deletion and HbF-QTL are modulating factors of SCA clinical severity that interact with each other.
SeqB: The age of the first hospitalization for VOC was older in patients with the alpha-thalassemia mutation and at least 2 HbF-QTL gene region mutations.

SeqA: Introduction: Fetal hemoglobin (HbF) is the major modifier for sickle cell disease (SCD) severity.
SeqB: Fetal hemoglobin (HbF) is an important protein that affects the severity of Sickle Cell Disease (SCD).

SeqA: HbF is modulated mainly by three major quantitative trait loci (QTL) on chromosomes 2, 6, and 11.
SeqB: HbF is changed mainly by three important quantitative trail loci (QTL-special sections of DNA) on chromosomes 2, 6, and 11.

SeqA: Methods: Five SNPs in the three QTLs (HBG2, rs7482144; BCL11A, rs1427407 and rs10189857; and HBS1L-MYB intergenic region, rs28384513 and rs9399137) were investigated by multiplex PCR and reverse hybridization, and their roles in HbF and clinical phenotype variability in Iraqi Kurds with SCD were assessed.
SeqB: Five single mutations in the three QTLs were studied.

SeqA: Results:
SeqB: The roles of these mutations in HbF were studied.

SeqA: HBG2 rs7482144 with minor allele frequency (MAF) of 0.133 was the most significant contributor to HbF variability, contributing 18.1%, followed by rs1427407 (MAF of 0.266) and rs9399137 (MAF of 0.137) at 14.3% and 8.8%, respectively.
SeqB: The research evaluated how these mutations affected the variety of characteristics seen in Iraqui Kurds with Sickle Cell Disease (SCD).

SeqA: The other two SNPs were not significant contributors.
SeqB: Three minor single mutations of the HBG2 gene resulted in the most important changes in HbF. The other two single mutations did not contribute significantly.

SeqA: Furthermore, when the cumulative numbers of minor alleles in the three contributing SNPs were assessed, HbF% and hemoglobin concentration increased with increasing number of minor alleles (P < 0.0005 and 0.001, respectively), while serum lactic dehydrogenase, reticulocytes, leukocytes, transfusion, and pain frequencies decreased (P = 0.003, 0.004, <0.0005, <0.0005, and 0.017, respectively).
SeqB: An increase in the number of these minor single mutations resulted in an increase in the amount of HbF and hemoglobin.

SeqA: Conclusions: It was demonstrated that SNPs in all three major HbF QTLs contribute significantly to HbF and clinical variability in Iraqi Kurds with SCD and that the cumulative number of minor alleles at contributing SNPs may serve as a better predictor of such variability in this population.
SeqB: This also resulted in a decrease in blood lactic dehydrogenase (an enzyme from tissue damage), white blood cells, transfusions, and occurences of pain.

SeqA: Sickle cell anemia (SCA), albeit monogenic, has heterogeneous phenotypic expression, mainly related to the level of hemoglobin F (HbF).

SeqA: Purpose: Osteoarthritis of the knee is a common disease, often associated with a Baker's cyst.
SeqB: Knee osteoarthritis is a common disease, often occuring with Baker's cyst (a fluid-filled pocket behind the knee).

SeqA: Besides osteoarthritis, also other joint pathologies of the knee can be causative for a Baker's cyst.
SeqB: Besides osteoarthritis, other knee joint diseases can lead to an uncomfortable fuild-filled swelling behind the knee.

SeqA: Radiotherapy is known to be an effective treatment for osteoarthritis, with an anti-inflammatory effect.
SeqB: Radiation therapy treats osteoarthritis, with an anti-inflammatory effect.

SeqA: As the excessive production of synovia usually is associated with intraarticular inflammation, our hypothesis was that radiotherapy might positively influence the synovial production and reduce the volume of a Baker's cyst.

SeqA: Materials and methods: We performed a prospective trial, including 20 knees receiving radiotherapy for knee arthritis.
SeqB: Our trial includes 29 knees receiving radiation therapy for knee arthritis.

SeqA: Besides documentation of NRS (numeric rating scale), WOMAC (Western Ontario and McMaster Universities Osteoarthritis Index) score and Knee Society Score, the volume of the Baker's cyst was calculated for a short- (6 to 12 weeks) and long-term (9 to 12 months) follow-up.
SeqB: Besides knee pain and function measurements, the size of the cust was measured for a short- (6 to 12 weeks) and long-term (9 to 12 months) follow-up.

SeqA: Ultrasonic volumetry was performed using an ultrasound device with a high-resolution multifrequency linear probe (6-9 MHz).
SeqB: Low-dose radiation therapy improves measurements for knee arthritis.

SeqA: Results: Low-dose radiotherapy improved NRS, WOMAC score and Knee Society Score significantly.
SeqB: The size of the fluid-filled swelling behind the knees decreased.

SeqA: The mean volume of Baker's cyst decreased from 22.3 ml to 10.7 respectively 3.1 ml during follow-up.
SeqB: 75% of patients in the short-term and 79% of patients in the long-term achieved a decrease in size of over 25% relative to baseline scores.

SeqA: A decrease in volume of more than 25% compared to the baseline could be achieved for 75% of the patients in the short-term and 79% of the patients in the long-term follow up.
SeqB: Radiation therapy of knee osteoarthritis decreases the size of a Baker's cyst.

SeqA: Conclusion: Radiotherapy of knee osteoarthritis is an effective treatment that decreases the volume of a Baker's cyst.
SeqB: Most patients respond to the treatment.

SeqA: Purpose: Osteoarthritis of the knee is a common disease, often associated with a Baker's cyst.
SeqB: Osteoarthritis of the knee is a common disease, often associated with Baker's cyst, which is an abnormal enlargement of the bursa (a protective fluid-filled sac) behind the knee Other knee joint injuries or disorders can also cause Baker's cyst Radiotherapy is an effective treatment for osteoarthritis because it targets inflammation Inflammation increases the amount of fluid, or synovia, in the knee.

SeqA: Besides osteoarthritis, also other joint pathologies of the knee can be causative for a Baker's cyst.

SeqA: Popliteal cyst is a common peri-knee cyst, also known as a Baker's cyst.
SeqB: Popliteal cyst, also known as Baker's cyst, occurs in the knee region.

SeqB: Popliteal cysts are caused by increased pressure on the knee joint which results in the abnormal enlargement of a bursa (protective fluid-filled sac) behind the knee to form a cyst.

SeqA: There are various treatments, including conservative treatment, traditional surgical resection and arthroscopic surgery.
SeqB: In recent years, treatment of popliteal cysts has shifted from traditional surgical removal of the cysts to arthroscopic treatment of intra-articular lesions and the treatment of joint-cyst communication, with good results.

SeqA: In recent years, the focus of the treatment of popliteal cysts has gradually shifted from the simple removal of cysts to arthroscopic treatment of intra-articular lesions and the treatment of joint-cyst communication, and achieved a good effect.

SeqA: Asthma is the most common chronic disease of childhood and, in the latter part of the 20th century, reached epidemic proportions.

SeqA: Asthma is generally believed to result from gene-environment interactions.
SeqB: Asthma is generally believed to result from gene-environment interactions, which is when two different genes respond to something in the environment in different ways.

SeqA: There is consensus that a 'window of opportunity' exists during pregnancy and early in life when environmental factors may influence its development.
SeqB: There is agreement that there are certain times during pregnancy and early in a child's life when environmental factors (such as food, pollutants, temperature) may shape asthma's development.

SeqA: We review multiple environmental, biologic and sociologic factors that may be important in the development of asthma.
SeqB: Researchers reviewed multiple environmental, biologic (such as brain chemistry, genes, nutrition, gender, and hormone levels) and sociologic (such as education and socioeconomic) factors that may be important in the development of asthma.

SeqA: Meta-analyses of studies have demonstrated that multifaceted interventions are required in order to develop asthma prevention.
SeqB: Other studies show that multiple steps and actions are required to prevent asthma.

SeqA: Multifaceted allergen reduction studies have shown clinical benefits.
SeqB: Studies that focus on reducing or avoiding allergens (any substance that causes an allergic reaction) are beneficial.

SeqA: Asthma represents a dysfunctional interaction with our genes and the environment to which they are exposed, especially in fetal and early infant life.
SeqB: Asthma represents an error in how our genes and the environment interact, especially during pregnancy and early infant life.

SeqA: The increasing prevalence of asthma also may be an indication of increased population risk for the development of other chronic non-communicable autoimmune diseases.

SeqA: Purpose of review: The prevalence of asthma is increasing in many parts of the world, particularly in developed countries.

SeqA: Recent findings: Several environmental exposures in infancy or early childhood are associated with reduced prevalence of asthma, but the mechanisms leading to these associations remain unknown.
SeqB: The present review focuses on recent literature on asthma prevention in childhood.

SeqA: Recent studies have demonstrated limited success in the prevention of asthma or asthma symptoms with the use of asthma medications, once the therapy is discontinued.

SeqA: Immunotherapy offers another strategy for asthma prevention, and groups treated with this intervention have demonstrated reduced atopy and asthma.
SeqB: Recent studies also show limited success in preventing asthma or asthma symptoms when asthma medications are used and then those medicines are stopped.

SeqA: Several multi-interventional trials have demonstrated a reduced asthma symptom burden but have not demonstrated significant differences in objective measures such as lung function or bronchial hyper-responsiveness between intervention groups.
SeqB: Immunotherapy (treatment that activates or alters the immune system to treat a disease) is another way to prevent asthma.

SeqA: Summary: The most promising asthma prevention strategies to date have been those that use a multi-interventional approach employing both dietary and environmental manipulations.
SeqB: Several studies that use multiple treatment (drugs, therapy, or other steps to improve health) methods showed reduced symptoms of asthma, but these studies did not see any major differences in other measures, such as how well the lungs carried air.

SeqA: More research is needed to assess the long-term follow-up of multi-interventional trials and to evaluate novel intervention strategies in the primary or secondary prevention of asthma in childhood.
SeqB: In summary, the most promising way to prevent asthma is to use more than one treatment that include changing environmental exposures and diet.

SeqA: Asthma, which typically begins in childhood and is the most common chronic disease of childhood, has reached epidemic proportions.

SeqA: This review considers biologic and sociologic factors in the development of allergy and asthma.

SeqA: Purpose of review: This article presents recent findings and perspectives on the relationship between early-life respiratory infections and asthma inception, and discusses emerging concepts on strategies that target these infectious agents for asthma prevention.

SeqB: The article also discusses new strategies to prevent asthma by stopping these infections.

SeqA: These viruses may have different mechanistic roles in the pathogenesis of asthma.
SeqB: Viruses that occur in early life, especially respiratory syncytial virus (a contagious virus that infects the lungs and airway tubes) and human rhinovirus (the common cold), usually occur before asthma starts.

SeqA: The airway microbiome and virus-bacteria interactions in early life have emerged as additional determinants of childhood asthma.
SeqB: These viruses may have different roles in how asthma develops.

SeqA: Innovative strategies for the prevention of these early-life infections, or for attenuation of acute infection severity, are being investigated and may identify effective strategies for the primary and secondary prevention of childhood asthma.

SeqA: Summary: Early-life infections are major determinants of asthma development.
SeqB: New strategies for preventing these infections that occur early in life, or for weakening the symptoms of infections, are being investigated and may help prevent childhood asthma.
