SeqA: All medications in the class can cause serotonin syndrome when combined with MAOIs.
SeqB: Besides depression, duloxetine also treats nerve damage from diabetes and full-body muscle pain.

SeqA: This chapter covers antidepressants that fall into the class of serotonin (5-HT) and norepinephrine (NE) reuptake inhibitors.
SeqB: This chapter talks about the antidepressant drugs that are called serotonin (5-HT) and norepinephrine (NE) reuptake inhibitors.

SeqA: That is, they bind to the 5-HT and NE transporters with varying levels of potency and binding affinity ratios.
SeqB: Duloxetine is a strong version of the 5-HT and NE reuptake inhibitor type.

SeqA: Duloxetine is a more potent 5-HT and NE reuptake inhibitor with a more balanced profile of binding at about 10:1 for 5HT and NE transporter binding.
SeqB: The way that duloxetine works means that doctors will have to watch you closely and may have to adjust your dose if you are taking certain types of other drugs.

SeqA: It is also a moderate inhibitor of CYP2D6, so that modest dose reductions and careful monitoring will be needed when prescribing duloxetine in combination with drugs that are preferentially metabolized by CYP2D6.
SeqB: Duloxetine's side effects include upset stomach, dry mouth, dizzy spells, constipation, high blood pressure, and loss of sleep and energy.

SeqA: The most common side effects identified in clinical trials are nausea, dry mouth, dizziness, constipation, insomnia, asthenia, and hypertension, consistent with its mechanisms of action.
SeqB: Studies show that duloxetine treats depression just as well as other drugs.

SeqA: Clinical trials to date have demonstrated rates of response and remission in patients with major depression that are comparable to other marketed antidepressants reviewed in this book.
SeqB: In addition to treating depression, duloxetine may be given to you to treat pain such as pain caused by diabetes and other body pains.

SeqA: In addition to approval for MDD, duloxetine is approved for diabetic peripheral neuropathic pain, fibromyalgia, and musculoskeletal pain.
SeqB: Drugs in the 5-HT and NE reuptake inhibitor class can make you very sick if taken with drugs that are in the MAOI class of antidepressants.

SeqA: Background: In antidepressant trials for pediatric patients with depression or anxiety disorders, the risk of suicidal events and other severe psychiatric adverse events such as aggression and agitation is increased with antidepressants relative to placebo.
SeqB: Studies of antidepressants in minors with depression or anxiety have shown a higher risk of suicide attempts and other severe mental issues, such as aggression and agitation, when taking antidepressants.

SeqA: Objective: To examine whether largely mentally healthy adolescents treated for a non-psychiatric condition are also at increased risk of suicidality and other severe psychiatric disorders.
SeqB: Our objective was to see if healthy adolescents being treated for a non-mental condition also have a higher risk of suicide attempts and severe mental issues.

SeqA: Methods: This is a re-analysis of a placebo-controlled duloxetine trial for juvenile fibromyalgia based on the main journal article and additional data published in the online supplementary material and on ClinicalTrials.gov.
SeqB: We took a second look at the results from a published trial of duloxetine (Cymbalta) for treating fibromyalgia (a chronic pain disorder).

SeqA: Both serious adverse events related to psychiatric disorders and adverse events leading to treatment discontinuation were defined as severe treatment-emergent psychiatric adverse events.
SeqB: We used results both from the published article and from supplemental results online and from ClinicalTrials.gov.

SeqA: Results:
SeqB: We found that a significant portion of the adolescents on duloxetine had suicidal tendencies and other serious mental side effects.

SeqA: We found that a significant portion of adolescents had treatment-emergent suicidal ideation and behaviour as well as other severe psychiatric adverse events with duloxetine, but no such events were recorded on placebo.
SeqB: None of these problems were seen in the participants that weren't taking duloxetine.

SeqA: The incidence of severe treatment-emergent psychiatric adverse events was statistically significantly higher with duloxetine as compared to placebo.
SeqB: We concluded that antidepressants may put adolescents at risk of suicidal tendencies and other serious mental problems, even if they are not being treated for depression or anxiety.

SeqA: Background: In antidepressant trials for pediatric patients with depression or anxiety disorders, the risk of suicidal events and other severe psychiatric adverse events such as aggression and agitation is increased with antidepressants relative to placebo.
SeqB: Children with depression or anxiety have a higher risk of suicide and aggressive and anxious behavior when taking antidepressants.

SeqA: Objective: To examine whether largely mentally healthy adolescents treated for a non-psychiatric condition are also at increased risk of suicidality and other severe psychiatric disorders.
SeqB: This study wants to find out if healthy teens have a higher risk of suicide and other bad thoughts when taking antidepressants for reasons other than depression.

SeqA: Methods: This is a re-analysis of a placebo-controlled duloxetine trial for juvenile fibromyalgia based on the main journal article and additional data published in the online supplementary material and on ClinicalTrials.gov.
SeqB: This study looks at data from another study where teens with chronic pain known as fibromyalgia were treated with an antidepressant called duloxetine.

SeqA: Both serious adverse events related to psychiatric disorders and adverse events leading to treatment discontinuation were defined as severe treatment-emergent psychiatric adverse events.
SeqB: The study defined severe side effects as suicidal and other bad thoughts and anything that stopped the patient from taking the drug.

SeqA: Results:
SeqB: The study found that a large number of teens in the study had suicidal thoughts and other side effects when treated with duloxetine.

SeqA: We found that a significant portion of adolescents had treatment-emergent suicidal ideation and behaviour as well as other severe psychiatric adverse events with duloxetine, but no such events were recorded on placebo.
SeqB: Teens that were not taking the drug did not have these side effects.

SeqA: The incidence of severe treatment-emergent psychiatric adverse events was statistically significantly higher with duloxetine as compared to placebo.
SeqB: Many more instances of severe side effects occurred for teens taking duloxetine as opposed to those not taking the drug.

SeqA: Conclusions: Antidepressants may put adolescents at risk of suicidality and other severe psychiatric disorders even when the treatment indication is not depression or anxiety.
SeqB: Teens may be at risk of suicide and other bad thoughts when taking the drug duloxetine even if the drug is not being used to treat depression or anxiety.

SeqA: Purpose: Several studies have previously reported the association between dry eye and depression along with the treatment of depression.
SeqB: Dry eye, depression, and treatent of depression may be linked.

SeqA: The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of different antidepressant drugs on tear parameters in patients with major depressive disorder.
SeqB: This study investigates how different antidepressant drugs affects eye tears in patients with depression.

SeqA: Methods: We recruited 132 patients who were using different antidepressants and 58 healthy controls.
SeqB: We included 132 patients using different antidepressants and 58 healthy people.

SeqA: Venlafaxine, duloxetine, escitalopram, and sertraline were used by 34, 28, 36, and 34 patients, respectively.
SeqB: Different antidepressants were used by groups of size 34, 28, 36, and 34.

SeqA: The participants filled out and completed the Beck Depression Scale.
SeqB: Participants filled out a questionnaire to measure depression.

SeqA: We recorded Schirmer test, tear breakup time (TBUT) and corneal staining values of the participants.
SeqB: We recorded different eye and tear measurements.

SeqA: The Ocular Surface Disease Index was completed by the participants.
SeqB: Participants completed an eye measurement test.

SeqA: In addition, we evaluated the tear meniscus parameters by using anterior segment optical coherence tomography.
SeqB: We also measured other parameters of the tear.

SeqA: Results: All conventional dry eye tests and tear meniscus parameters were significantly lesser in the depression group than in the control group (Schirmer test, 11.41 ?? 6.73 mm and 22.53 ?? 4.98 mm; TBUT, 5.29 ?? 2.92 seconds and 13.38 ?? 1.72; Corneal staining, tear meniscus area, 0.026 ?? 0.012 mm2 and 0.11 ?? 0.025 mm2; tear meniscus depth, 182.75 ?? 78.79 ??m and 257.48 ?? 90.1 ??m; tear meniscus height, 290.3 ?? 133.63 ??m and 459.78 ?? 180.26 ??m, in patients and controls, respectively).
SeqB: The depression group had smaller dry eye and tear volume than the healthy group.

SeqA: The tear parameters of the duloxetine group were lowest among the drug groups and Schirmer test, and TBUT of the venlafaxine group was statistically significantly different from the duloxetine group (P = 0.028 and P = 0.017, respectively).
SeqB: The tear measurements of the antidepressant duloxetine group was lowest among the drug groups and notably different than the antidepressant venlafaxine group.

SeqA: Ocular Surface Disease Index score of the depression group was significantly higher than the control group (31.12 ?? 21.15 and 17.43 ?? 11.75 in depression and control group, respectively.).
SeqB: Dry eye of the depression group was worse than that of the healthy group.

SeqA: Conclusions: We found that the usage of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors and serotonin noradrenaline reuptake inhibitors affects the ocular surface by a mechanism other than the anticholinergic system.
SeqB: We found that using antidepressants that block removal of the chemical messengers serotonin and noradrenaline affect the eye surface.

SeqA: Besides serotonin blockage, the noradrenaline blockade of serotonin noradrenaline reuptake inhibitors may increase the dry eye findings on the ocular surface.
SeqB: Besides blocking removal of serotonin, blockage of noradrenaline by these antidepressants may increase dry eye.

SeqA: Purpose: Several studies have previously reported the association between dry eye and depression along with the treatment of depression.
SeqB: Studies show that there is a link between depression treatment and dry eyes.

SeqA: The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of different antidepressant drugs on tear parameters in patients with major depressive disorder.
SeqB: This study looks at the tears of depressed people when given different types of drugs that treat depression.

SeqA: Methods: We recruited 132 patients who were using different antidepressants and 58 healthy controls.
SeqB: This study includes 132 people taking antidepressant drugs and 58 people not taking antidepressant drugs for comparison.

SeqA: Venlafaxine, duloxetine, escitalopram, and sertraline were used by 34, 28, 36, and 34 patients, respectively.
SeqB: Patients were taking the antidepressant drugs called venlafaxine, duloxetine, escitalopram, and sertraline.

SeqA: The participants filled out and completed the Beck Depression Scale.
SeqB: Patients filled our a form to measure their level of depression.

SeqA: We recorded Schirmer test, tear breakup time (TBUT) and corneal staining values of the participants.
SeqB: The researchers looked at the eyes and tears of the patients.

SeqA: The Ocular Surface Disease Index was completed by the participants.
SeqB: Patients filled out a form to measure the dryness of their eyes.

SeqA: In addition, we evaluated the tear meniscus parameters by using anterior segment optical coherence tomography.
SeqB: Those people taking antidepressant drugs had drier eyes than those that were not taking antidepressant drugs.

SeqA: Results: All conventional dry eye tests and tear meniscus parameters were significantly lesser in the depression group than in the control group (Schirmer test, 11.41 ?? 6.73 mm and 22.53 ?? 4.98 mm; TBUT, 5.29 ?? 2.92 seconds and 13.38 ?? 1.72; Corneal staining, tear meniscus area, 0.026 ?? 0.012 mm2 and 0.11 ?? 0.025 mm2; tear meniscus depth, 182.75 ?? 78.79 ??m and 257.48 ?? 90.1 ??m; tear meniscus height, 290.3 ?? 133.63 ??m and 459.78 ?? 180.26 ??m, in patients and controls, respectively).
SeqB: The people taking duloxetine had the driest eyes.

SeqA: The tear parameters of the duloxetine group were lowest among the drug groups and Schirmer test, and TBUT of the venlafaxine group was statistically significantly different from the duloxetine group (P = 0.028 and P = 0.017, respectively).
SeqB: The people taking antidepressant drugs scored much higher on a test to measure dry eyes.

SeqA: Ocular Surface Disease Index score of the depression group was significantly higher than the control group (31.12 ?? 21.15 and 17.43 ?? 11.75 in depression and control group, respectively.).
SeqB: This study finds that certain classes of antidepressant drugs affects the eye ducts but does not because the drugs affect the nerves.

SeqA: Conclusions: We found that the usage of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors and serotonin noradrenaline reuptake inhibitors affects the ocular surface by a mechanism other than the anticholinergic system.
SeqB: Using antidepressants from the drug class called serotonin noradrenaline reuptake inhibitors may lead to dry eyes.

SeqA: Duloxetine is a medication used to manage major depressive disorder (MDD), generalized anxiety disorder (GAD), fibromyalgia, diabetic peripheral neuropathy, and chronic musculoskeletal pain.
SeqB: Duloxetine is a medication used to treat depression, anxiety, fibromyalgia, diabete nerve damage, and chronic pains in the body.

SeqA: Off-label uses for duloxetine include chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy and stress urinary incontinence.
SeqB: Duloxetine may also be used to treat nerve pain caused by chemotherapy and loss of bladder control caused by physical activity.

SeqA: It is in the Serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) class of medications.
SeqB: Duloxetine is in the Serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) class of medications.

SeqA: This activity describes the indications, mechanism of action, and contraindications for duloxetine as a valuable agent in treating multiple health conditions.
SeqB: Duloxetine is valuable because it treats many different health problems.

SeqA: This activity will highlight the mechanism of action, adverse event profile, and other key factors (e.g., off-label uses, dosing, pharmacodynamics, pharmacokinetics, monitoring, relevant drug-drug interactions) pertinent for members of the interprofessional team in the treatment of patients with major depressive disorder (MDD), generalized anxiety disorder (GAD), fibromyalgia, diabetic peripheral neuropathy, chronic musculoskeletal pain, and related conditions.
SeqB: This article describes the uses of the antidepressant, how it works, and medications that should not be used while taking it.

SeqA: Duloxetine, a potent reuptake inhibitor of serotonin (5-HT) and norepinephrine, is effective for the treatment of major depressive disorder, diabetic neuropathic pain, stress urinary incontinence, generalized anxiety disorder and fibromyalgia.
SeqB: Duloxetine blocks two chemical messengers from working, called serotonin (5-HT) and norepinephrine.

SeqA: Duloxetine achieves a maximum plasma concentration (C(max)) of approximately 47 ng/mL (40 mg twice-daily dosing) to 110 ng/mL (80 mg twice-daily dosing) approximately 6 hours after dosing.
SeqB: Duloxetine is given to treat things such as depression, diabetic nerve pain, leaky bladder, anxiety, and other chronic pain.

SeqA: The elimination half-life of duloxetine is approximately 10-12 hours and the volume of distribution is approximately 1640 L.
SeqB: The goal of this paper is to look at other studies on duloxetine to see if the drug can be used with other drugs.

SeqA: The goal of this paper is to provide a review of the literature on intrinsic and extrinsic factors that may impact the pharmacokinetics of duloxetine with a focus on concomitant medications and their clinical implications.
SeqB: Things that affect the way that duloxetine works are your sex, age, ethnicity, whether you smoke or not, the condition of your kidney and liver, and your genetics.

SeqA: Patient demographic characteristics found to influence the pharmacokinetics of duloxetine include sex, smoking status, age, ethnicity, cytochrome P450 (CYP) 2D6 genotype, hepatic function and renal function.
SeqB: A doctor will only have warnings against using duloxetine if your liver or kidneys are not in good condition.

SeqA: Of these, only impaired hepatic function or severely impaired renal function warrant specific warnings or dose recommendations.
SeqB: Studies show that activated charcoal, used to treat certain poisons, makes duloxetine less effective.

SeqA: Pharmacokinetic results from drug interaction studies show that activated charcoal decreases duloxetine exposure, and that CYP1A2 inhibition increases duloxetine exposure to a clinically significant degree.
SeqB: Taking drugs that affect a certain enzyme with duloxetine could make you sick.

SeqA: Specifically, following oral administration in the presence of fluvoxamine, the area under the plasma concentration-time curve and C(max) of duloxetine significantly increased by 460% (90% CI 359, 584) and 141% (90% CI 93, 200), respectively.
SeqB: Taking the drug fluvoxamine, used to treat depression and OCD, with duloxetine could make you sick.

SeqA: In addition, smoking is associated with a 30% decrease in duloxetine concentration.
SeqB: Smoking makes duloxetine less effective.

SeqA: The exposure of duloxetine with CYP2D6 inhibitors or in CYP2D6 poor metabolizers is increased to a lesser extent than that observed with CYP1A2 inhibition and does not require a dose adjustment.
SeqB: Certain drugs and genetics could affect duloxetine, but not enough to affect how much dulxoetine you would take.

SeqA: In addition, duloxetine increases the exposure of drugs that are metabolized by CYP2D6, but not CYP1A2.
SeqB: There are certain drugs that should not be taken with duloxetine because they can make you sick when taking them normally.

SeqA: Pharmacodynamic study results indicate that duloxetine may enhance the effects of benzodiazepines, but not alcohol or warfarin.
SeqB: Studies show that duloxetine may make tranquilizers like valium and xanax stronger, but does not seem to affect alcohol or the blood thinner warfarin.

SeqA: An increase in gastric pH produced by histamine H(2)-receptor antagonists or antacids did not impact the absorption of duloxetine.
SeqB: Antacids and other stomach acid blockers do not affect duloxetine.

SeqA: While duloxetine is generally well tolerated, it is important to be knowledgeable about the potential for pharmacokinetic interactions between duloxetine and drugs that inhibit CYP1A2 or drugs that are metabolized by CYP2D6 enzymes.
SeqB: It is important that your doctors know what drugs you are taking in order to make sure you do not get sick from taking duloxetine.

SeqA: Atraumatic trismus can be one of the presentations of medication-induced acute dystonia, particularly by antipsychotics and less commonly antidepressants.
SeqB: A stiff jaw is a possible side effect of taking certain medications, such as antidepressant drugs or drugs called antipsychotics.

SeqA: A case of an unusual emergency presentation of atraumatic trismus on initiation of duloxetine is reported.
SeqB: Here is an example of someone who visited the ER with a severely stiff jaw after taking the drug duloxetine.

SeqA: The patient was a 40-year-old woman experiencing sudden difficulty in mouth opening and speaking due to a stiffened jaw after taking 5 days of duloxetine prescribed for her fibromyalgia-related chest pain.
SeqB: The patient was a 40-year-old woman who was having trouble with opening her mouth and speaking five days after starting the drug duloxetine.

SeqA: Assessment of vital signs is prudent to ensure there is no laryngeal involvement.
SeqB: The woman's doctors found no other problems that might cause her jaw stiffness.

SeqA: Other physical examinations and her recent investigations were unremarkable.
SeqB: She was treated for muscle spasms with an IV and pills.

SeqA: She was treated for acute dystonia and intravenous procyclidine was given together with oral diazepam.
SeqB: The woman improved right away and was told to stop taking duloxetine.

SeqA: Her symptoms improved immediately and her duloxetine was suggested to be stopped.
SeqB: This is the first time the authors have heard of jaw stiffness being caused by the drug duloxetine.

SeqA: To our knowledge, this is the first case of isolated trismus induced by duloxetine.
SeqB: Doctors should be aware of the risk of jaw stiffness since it could lead to very serious problems.

SeqA: We present a case of hypertensive urgency in a diabetic patient with painful diabetic neuropathy on duloxetine treatment.
SeqB: This paper is about a patient with pain caused by diabetes who went to the doctor with very serious high blood pressure.

SeqA: The patient's blood pressure was high after taking 1-day dose of duloxetine and the patient was diagnosed with hypertensive urgency.
SeqB: The patient's blood pressure was high after taking a 1-day dose of the antidepressant duloxetine (a drug that also treats diabetic nerve pain).

SeqA: The patient was treated with labetalol, leading to reduction in blood pressure.
SeqB: The patient was diagnosed with a high blood pressure emergency.

SeqA: The patient's medication was switched to telmisartan and metoprolol, which leads to resolution of increased blood pressure.
SeqB: The patient was given labetalol, a drug that lowers blood pressure.

SeqA: This case report is a possible case of hypertensive urgency after the initiation of duloxetine managed with antihypertensives and resolves with the discontinuation of the duloxetine.
SeqB: The patient was switched to the drugs telmisartan and metoprolol, which treat high blood pressure.

SeqA: Background: Antidepressants-induced movement disorders are rare and imperfectly known adverse drug reactions.
SeqB: A rare side effect of taking antidepressant drugs is uncontrollable movement, also called movement disorders.

SeqA: The risk may differ between different antidepressants and antidepressants' classes.
SeqB: There may be different side effects depending on what antidepressant drugs you take.

SeqA: The objective of this study was to assess the putative association of each antidepressant and antidepressants' classes with movement disorders.
SeqB: This study tried to figure out which antidepressant drugs caused which movement disorder side effects.

SeqA: Methods: Using VigiBase??, the WHO Pharmacovigilance database, disproportionality of movement disorders' reporting was assessed among adverse drug reactions related to any antidepressant, from January 1967 to February 2017, through a case/non-case design.
SeqB: This study looked at reports of antidepressant use from 1967 to 2017 using a computer database.

SeqA: The association between nine subtypes of movement disorders (akathisia, bruxism, dystonia, myoclonus, parkinsonism, restless legs syndrome, tardive dyskinesia, tics, tremor) and antidepressants was estimated through the calculation first of crude Reporting Odds Ratio (ROR), then adjusted ROR on four potential confounding factors: age, sex, drugs described as able to induce movement disorders, and drugs used to treat movement disorders.
SeqB: This study used statistics to see if the links between the different antidepressants and movement disorders.

SeqA: Results: Out of the 14,270,446 reports included in VigiBase??, 1,027,405 (7.2%) contained at least one antidepressant, among whom 29,253 (2.8%) reported movement disorders.
SeqB: There were over 14 million reports in the database.

SeqA: The female/male sex ratio was 2.15 and the mean age 50.9 ?? 18.0 years.
SeqB: One million of those contained a report of antidepressant use.

SeqA: We found a significant increased ROR for antidepressants in general for all subtypes of movement disorders, with the highest association with bruxism (ROR 10.37, 95% CI 9.62-11.17) and the lowest with tics (ROR 1.49, 95% CI 1.38-1.60).
SeqB: Almost 30 thousand of the antidepressant reports contained a movement disorder side effect.

SeqA: When comparing each of the classes of antidepressants with the others, a significant association was observed for all subtypes of movement disorders except restless legs syndrome with serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SRIs) only.
SeqB: The patients in the reports ranged from 32-68 years old and contained twice as many women as men.

SeqA: Among antidepressants, mirtazapine, vortioxetine, amoxapine, phenelzine, tryptophan and fluvoxamine were associated with the highest level to movement disorders and citalopram, paroxetine, duloxetine and mirtazapine were the most frequently associated with movement disorders.
SeqB: All movement disorders were linked to antidepressant use.

SeqA: An association was also found with eight other antidepressants.
SeqB: Jaw clenching was seen the most often, and involuntary movement called tics were the least seen.

SeqA: Conclusions: A potential harmful association was found between movement disorders and use of the antidepressants mirtazapine, vortioxetine, amoxapine, phenelzine, tryptophan, fluvoxamine, citalopram, paroxetine, duloxetine, bupropion, clomipramine, escitalopram, fluoxetine, mianserin, sertraline, venlafaxine and vilazodone.
SeqB: The anitdepressant drug class called serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SRIs) were most often linked to movement disorders except for restless leg syndrome.

SeqA: Clinicians should beware of these adverse effects and monitor early warning signs carefully.
SeqB: The antidepressants linked to the strongest movement disorders, like Parkinson's or Huntington's disease, were mirtazapine, vortioxetine, amoxapine, phenelzine, tryptophan, and fluvoxamine.

SeqA: However, this observational study must be interpreted as an exploratory analysis, and these results should be refined by future epidemiological studies.
SeqB: The antidepressants with the most movement disorder side effects were citalopram, paroxetine, duloxetine, and mirtazapine.

SeqA: The European Society for Clinical Microbiology and Infectious Diseases established the Sore Throat Guideline Group to write an updated guideline to diagnose and treat patients with acute sore throat.
SeqB: A European scientific organization made a Sore Throat Guideline Group to write a new guideline to diagnose and treat people with short-term sore throat.

SeqA: In diagnosis, Centor clinical scoring system or rapid antigen test can be helpful in targeting antibiotic use.
SeqB: A common sore throat scoring survey or a rapid strep test involving a quick throat swab to find bacterial fragments can be useful in deciding which antibiotic to use.

SeqA: The Centor scoring system can help to identify those patients who have higher likelihood of group A streptococcal infection.
SeqB: The sore throat scoring survey can help identify people who are more likely to have group A strep, caused by group A strep bacteria.

SeqA: In patients with high likelihood of streptococcal infections (e.g. 3-4 Centor criteria) physicians can consider the use of rapid antigen test (RAT).
SeqB: Doctors might use a rapid strep test in people who are highly likely to have strep throat based on the sore throat scoring survey.

SeqA: If RAT is performed, throat culture is not necessary after a negative RAT for the diagnosis of group A streptococci.
SeqB: If the rapid strep test shows no strep infection, a throat swab to find, grow, and test bacteria in the throat that make you sick is not needed.

SeqA: To treat sore throat, either ibuprofen or paracetamol are recommended for relief of acute sore throat symptoms.
SeqB: Advil or Tylenol can help short-term sore throat symptoms.

SeqA: Zinc gluconate is not recommended to be used in sore throat.
SeqB: Zinc gluconate should not be used in sore throat.

SeqA: There is inconsistent evidence of herbal treatments and acupuncture as treatments for sore throat.
SeqB: It is unclear whether herbal treatments and acupuncture can help sore throat.

SeqA: Antibiotics should not be used in patients with less severe presentation of sore throat, e.g. 0-2 Centor criteria to relieve symptoms.
SeqB: People with less serious sore throat (low throat scoring survey score, for example) should not use antibiotics to help sore throat.

SeqA: Modest benefits of antibiotics, which have been observed in patients with 3-4 Centor criteria, have to be weighed against side effects, the effect of antibiotics on microbiota, increased antibacterial resistance, medicalisation and costs.
SeqB: Moderate benefits of antibiotics, seen in people with higher throat survey scores, have to be compared to side effects, effects on small organisms that live in or on the human body, the ability of bacteria to defeat the antibiotics designed to kill them, people more likely to seek medical care for future illness and costs.

SeqA: The prevention of suppurative complications is not a specific indication for antibiotic therapy in sore throat.
SeqB: Preventing pus formation is not a reason for using antibiotics to help sore throat.

SeqA: If antibiotics are indicated, penicillin V, twice or three times daily for 10 days is recommended.
SeqB: If using antibiotics, taking penicillin V two to three times a day for 10 days is suggested.

SeqA: At the present, there is no evidence enough that indicates shorter treatment length.
SeqB: Currently, taking antibiotics for fewer than 10 days is not recommended.

SeqA: The European Society for Clinical Microbiology and Infectious Diseases established the Sore Throat Guideline Group to write an updated guideline to diagnose and treat patients with acute sore throat.
SeqB: A European society created a group to update guidelines to identify and treat patients with sore throat.

SeqA: In diagnosis, Centor clinical scoring system or rapid antigen test can be helpful in targeting antibiotic use.
SeqB: Centor clinical scoring system or rapid antigen, or foreign protein, testing can help target antibiotics (antibacterial medication).

SeqA: The Centor scoring system can help to identify those patients who have higher likelihood of group A streptococcal infection.
SeqB: The Centor scoring system can help identify those with higher risk of group A streptococcal or strep bacterial infection.

SeqA: In patients with high likelihood of streptococcal infections (e.g. 3-4 Centor criteria) physicians can consider the use of rapid antigen test (RAT).
SeqB: In patientis with high risk of streptoccal bacterial infections, physicians may use rapid antigen, or foreign protein, testing (RAT).

SeqA: If RAT is performed, throat culture is not necessary after a negative RAT for the diagnosis of group A streptococci.
SeqB: If rapid antigen testing is used, testing isolated throat cells are not needed for identifying group A strep bacterial infection if no antigens are detected.

SeqA: To treat sore throat, either ibuprofen or paracetamol are recommended for relief of acute sore throat symptoms.
SeqB: Either ibuprofen or paracetamol, common pain relievers, can help relieve immediate sore throat symptoms.

SeqA: Zinc gluconate is not recommended to be used in sore throat.
SeqB: Zinc gluconate, a dietary supplement, is not recommeded with a sore throat.

SeqA: There is inconsistent evidence of herbal treatments and acupuncture as treatments for sore throat.
SeqB: There is inconsistent evidence that herbal treatments or acupuncture treats sore throat.

SeqA: Antibiotics should not be used in patients with less severe presentation of sore throat, e.g. 0-2 Centor criteria to relieve symptoms.
SeqB: Patients with less severe sore throats should not use antibiotics to relieve symptoms.

SeqA: Modest benefits of antibiotics, which have been observed in patients with 3-4 Centor criteria, have to be weighed against side effects, the effect of antibiotics on microbiota, increased antibacterial resistance, medicalisation and costs.
SeqB: Limited benefits of antibiotics, seen in patients with severe sore throat, have to be weighed against antibiotic side effects, its effects on bacteria, medicalisation and costs.

SeqA: The prevention of suppurative complications is not a specific indication for antibiotic therapy in sore throat.
SeqB: Preventing pus is not a sign for antibacterial medication in sore throat.

SeqA: If antibiotics are indicated, penicillin V, twice or three times daily for 10 days is recommended.
SeqB: If using antibiotics, penicillin V, two or three times daily for 10 days is recommended.

SeqA: At the present, there is no evidence enough that indicates shorter treatment length.
SeqB: Currently, there is not enough evidence for shorter treatment length.

SeqA: In patients with symptoms and signs suggestive of streptococcal pharyngitis a specific diagnosis should be determined by performing a throat culture or a rapid antigen-detection test with a throat culture if the rapid antigen-detection test is negative, at least in children.
SeqB: Doctors should give patients who are believed to have strep throat a throat culture (a test using a throat swab to find, grow, and test bacteria in the throat that make you sick) or a rapid strep test (a test using a throat swab to find fragments of bacteria in the throat that make you sick) followed by a throat culture if the rapid strep test finds no strep-related bacteria, at least in children.

SeqA: Penicillin is the preferred treatment, and a first-generation cephalosporin is an acceptable alternative unless there is a history of immediate hypersensitivity to a beta-lactam antibiotic.
SeqB: Penicillin is prescribed most commonly.

SeqA: Group A beta-hemolytic streptococcal (GABHS) infection causes 15% to 30% of sore throats in children and 5% to 15% in adults, and is more common in the late winter and early spring.
SeqB: Group A strep infection, caused by group A strep bacteria, causes 15% to 30% of sore throats in children and 5% to 15% in adults, and is more common in the late winter and early spring.

SeqA: The strongest independent predictors of GABHS pharyngitis are patient age of five to 15 years, absence of cough, tender anterior cervical adenopathy, tonsillar exudates, and fever.

SeqA: Objective: To compare azithromycin (AZT) and benzathine penicillin (BP) in the treatment of recurrent tonsillitis in children.

SeqB: 284 of 350 children with reoccurring inflamed tonsils caused by strep bacteria participated in the study.

SeqA: The rest of the children, 122, were divided randomly into two equal main groups.
SeqB: 162 children had surgery to treat reoccurring inflamed tonsils.

SeqA: Group A children received a single intramuscular BP (600,000 IU for children???27kg and 1,200,000IU for ???27kg) every two weeks for six months.
SeqB: We divided the rest of the children, 122, into two groups.

SeqA: Group B children received single oral AZT (250mg for children???25kg and 500mg for ???25kg) once weekly for six months.
SeqB: Group A children got a single BP injection (600,000 international units for children weighing 27 kg or less and 1,200,000 international units for children over 27 kg) once a week for six months.

SeqA: Results: Both groups showed marked significant reduction in recurrent tonsillitis that is comparable to results of tonsillectomy.
SeqB: Group B children got a single dose of AZT by mouth (250 mg for children weighing 25 kg or less and 500 mg for children over 25 kg).

SeqA: There were no statistical differences between group A and B regarding the recurrence of infections and drug safety after six-month follow-up.
SeqB: Once a week for six months.

SeqA: Group B showed better compliance.
SeqB: Both groups had results similar to getting surgery to remove the tonsils.

SeqA: Conclusion: AZT proved to be good alternative to BP in the management of recurrent tonsillitis with results similar to those obtained after tonsillectomy.

SeqA: Background: Diagnosing group A streptococcus (Strep A) throat infection by clinical examination is difficult, and misdiagnosis may lead to inappropriate antibiotic use.
SeqB: Diagnosing group A strep throat (Strep A) by a physical exam is difficult, and diagnosing it incorrectly may lead to use of the wrong antibiotic.

SeqA: Most patients with sore throat seek symptom relief rather than antibiotics, therefore, therapies that relieve symptoms should be recommended to patients.
SeqB: Doctors should suggest treatments that improve symptoms to people with sore throat because most do not want antibiotics.

SeqA: We report two clinical trials on the efficacy and safety of flurbiprofen 8.75 mg lozenge in patients with and without streptococcal sore throat.
SeqB: We looked at two studies on how well flurbiprofen 8.75 mg lozenge works and how safe it is in people with and without strep throat.

SeqA: Methods: The studies enrolled adults with moderate-to-severe throat symptoms (sore throat pain, difficulty swallowing and swollen throat) and a diagnosis of pharyngitis.
SeqB: We studied adults with moderate-to-severe throat symptoms (sore throat pain, difficulty swallowing and swollen throat) and a diagnosis of strep throat.

SeqA: The practitioner assessed the likelihood of Strep A infection based on historical and clinical findings.
SeqB: The doctor determined how likely it was that people have Strep A infection based on the history of the patient and a physical exam.

SeqA: Patients were randomised to flurbiprofen 8.75 mg or placebo lozenges under double-blind conditions and reported the three throat symptoms at baseline and at regular intervals over 24 h. Results: A total of 402 patients received study medication (n = 203 flurbiprofen, n = 199 placebo).
SeqB: We gave people either flurbiprofen 8.75 mg lozenges or sugar lozenges and they reported three throat symptoms (sore throat pain, difficulty swallowing and swollen throat) at the beginning of the study and regularly over 24 h. We gave 203 people flurbiprofen 8.75 mg and 199 people sugar lozenges, for a total of 402 people.

SeqA: Throat culture identified Strep A in 10.0% of patients and group C streptococcus (Strep C) in a further 14.0%.
SeqB: A throat swab to find, grow, and test bacteria in the throat found Strep A in 10% of people and group C strep (Strep C) in 14% of people.

SeqA: The practitioners' assessments correctly diagnosed Strep A in 11/40 cases (sensitivity 27.5%, and specificity 79.7%).
SeqB: The doctors correctly diagnosed Strep A in 11 of 40 cases.

SeqA: A single flurbiprofen lozenge provided significantly greater relief than placebo for all three throat symptoms, lasting 3-4 h for patients with and without Strep A/C. Multiple doses of flurbiprofen lozenges over 24 h also led to symptom relief, although not statistically significant in the Strep A/C group.
SeqB: People had greater symptom relief with one flurbiprofen lozenge than one sugar lozenge for three throat symptoms (sore throat pain, difficulty swallowing and swollen throat), lasting 3-4 h for people with and without Strep A or C. People with Strep A or C may have some symptom relief with more than one flurbiprofen lozenge over 24 h. There were no serious side effects.

SeqA: There were no serious adverse events.
SeqB: We conclude that the studies emphasize the difficulty of identifying Strep A based on signs and symptoms.

SeqA: Conclusions: The results highlight the challenge of identifying Strep A based on clinical features.
SeqB: With the growing problem of bacteria able to defeat the antibiotics designed to kill them, treatments that are not antibiotics should be considered.

SeqA: With the growing problem of antibiotic resistance, non-antibiotic treatments should be considered.
SeqB: As shown here, flurbiprofen 8.75 mg lozenges work, giving immediate and long-lasting symptom relief in people with and without Strep A or C infection.

SeqA: We conducted a meta-analysis of 9 randomized controlled trials (involving 2113 patients) comparing cephalosporins with penicillin for treatment of group A beta -hemolytic streptococcal (GABHS) tonsillopharyngitis in adults.
SeqB: We analyzed results from 9 studies (2113 people total) comparing cephalosporins (antibacterial antibiotics) and penicillin (another antibiotic) for treatment of group A strep throat and tonsil infection in adults.

SeqA: The summary odds ratio (OR) for bacteriologic cure rate significantly favored cephalosporins, compared with penicillin (OR,1.83; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.37-2.44); the bacteriologic failure rate was nearly 2 times higher for penicillin therapy than it was for cephalosporin therapy (P=.00004).
SeqB: Results favored cephalosporins over penicillin.

SeqA: The summary OR for clinical cure rate was 2.29 (95% CI, 1.61-3.28), significantly favoring cephalosporins (P<.00001).
SeqB: Results favored cephalosporins.

SeqA: Sensitivity analyses for bacterial cure significantly favored cephalosporins over penicillin in trials that were double-blinded and of high quality, trials that had a well-defined clinical status, trials that performed GABHS serotyping, trials that eliminated carriers from analysis, and trials that had a test-of-cure culture performed 3-14 days after treatment.
SeqB: Results favored cephalosporins over penicillin.

SeqA: This meta-analysis indicates that the likelihood of bacteriologic and clinical failure in the treatment of GABHS tonsillopharyngitis is 2 times higher for oral penicillin than for oral cephalosporins.
SeqB: This analysis shows using penicillin to treat group A strep throat and tonsil infection is twice as likely to result in the bacteria and infection coming back as using cephalosporins.

SeqA: The normal sleep-wake cycle is characterized by diurnal variations in blood pressure, heart rate, and cardiac events.

SeqB: Sleep apnea is a sleep disorder where breathing repeatedly stops and starts.

SeqA: Associations exist between sleep-disordered breathing (which encompasses both OSA and CSA) and heart failure, atrial fibrillation, stroke, coronary artery disease, and cardiovascular mortality.
SeqB: Sleep apnea disrupts the normal patterns between sleep and how the heart functions, and the physical changes vary for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), caused by airflow blockage, and central sleep apnea (CSA), when breathing regularly stops while sleeping because the brain doesn't tell the muscles to take in air.

SeqA: Treatment options include positive airway pressure as well as adaptive servo-ventilation and phrenic nerve stimulation for CSA.
SeqB: There are associations between sleep-disordered breathing, including OSA and CSA, and heart failure, atrial fibrillation (a fluttery and irregular heartbeat that can lead to blood clots) and other heart problems.

SeqA: Treatment improves blood pressure, quality of life, and sleepiness, the last particularly in those at risk for cardiovascular disease.
SeqB: Treatment options include positive airway pressure (a machine used to pump air under pressure into the airway of the lungs), adaptive servo-ventilation (a device that tracks and adjusts its pressure to match the breathing pattern of a person with sleep apnea), and phrenic nerve stimulation (treatment that sends electrical stimulation to the patient's phrenic nerve to contract the diaphragm and produce breathing).

SeqA: Results from clinical trials are not definitive in terms of hard cardiovascular outcomes.
SeqB: Treatment improves blood pressure, quality of life, and sleepiness.

SeqA: The normal sleep-wake cycle is characterized by diurnal variations in blood pressure, heart rate, and cardiac events.
SeqB: The normal sleep-wake cycle has daily changes in blood pressure, heart rate, and heart-related events.

SeqA: Sleep apnea disrupts the normal sleep-heart interaction, and the pathophysiology varies for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and central sleep apnea (CSA).
SeqB: Sleep apnea (a disorder in which breathing is regularly interrupted during sleep) alters the sleep-heart interaction.

SeqA: Associations exist between sleep-disordered breathing (which encompasses both OSA and CSA) and heart failure, atrial fibrillation, stroke, coronary artery disease, and cardiovascular mortality.
SeqB: The disease-related physical effects vary for obstructive and central sleep apnea, sleep apnea by throat blockage and brain dysfunction, respectively.

SeqA: Objective: Nighttime onset of atrial fibrillation (AF) is sometimes associated with obstructive sleep apnea accompanied by a characteristic heart rate (HR) pattern known as cyclical variation of HR.
SeqB: Nighttime onset of atrial fibrillation (a fluttery and irregular heartbeat that can lead to blood clots or stroke) is sometimes associated with obstructive sleep apnea (where muscles in the throat relax, the airway is narrowed or closed, and breathing is momentarily cut off) along with a specific heart rate pattern called cyclical variation.

SeqA: The aim of this study was to evaluate whether cyclical variation of HR is prevalent in patients with nocturnal AF.
SeqB: This study determines whether cyclical variation of heart rate is common in patients with nighttime atrial fibrillation (AF).

SeqA: Methods: The subjects consisted of 34 patients (68??12 years) with paroxysmal AF, including 14 patients with daytime AF and 20 patients with nighttime AF.
SeqB: There are 34 patients in the study with paroxysmal AF (when the heart rate returns to normal within 7 days on its own or with treatment), including 14 patients with daytime AF and 20 patients with nighttime AF.

SeqA: Holter electrocardiogram (ECGs) were examined for the presence of cyclical variation in HR and to quantify the HR variability within the 40-minute period preceding each AF episode using a fast Fourier transform (FFT) methods.
SeqB: The presence of cyclical variation in heart rate is examined, and the heart rate differences are measured and counted 40 minutes before each AF episode.

SeqA: Results: Cyclical variation in HR was observed in 12 of 20 (60%) nighttime episodes and in only two of 14 (14%) daytime episodes.
SeqB: Cyclical variation in heart rate is found in 12 of 20 (60%) nighttime episodes and only in two of 14 (14%) daytime episodes.

SeqA: The prevalence of cyclical variation in HR was significantly greater in the nighttime AF episodes than in the daytime AF episodes (Chi=5.34, p<0.05).
SeqB: Cyclical variation in heart rate was much greater in the nighttime AF than in daytime AF episodes.

SeqA: The mean frequency of cyclical variation in HR was 0.015??0.003 Hz.
SeqB: The high presence of cyclical variation in heart rate found before nighttime atrial fibrillation episodes suggests that sleep apnea may play a role in the onset of nighttime atrial fibrillation.

SeqA: Background: For patients presenting with atrial fibrillation of only a few weeks duration, the use of transesophageal echocardiography offers the opportunity to markedly abbreviate the duration of atrial fibrillation before cardioversion.
SeqB: Atrial fibrillation is a fluttery and irregular heartbeat that can lead to blood clots or stroke.

SeqA: We sought to determine if the shorter duration of atrial fibrillation allowed by a transesophageal echocardiography strategy had an impact on the recurrence of atrial fibrillation and prevalence of sinus rhythm during the first year following cardioversion.
SeqB: For patients that had atrial fibrillation for only a few weeks, using a test that produces pictures of the heart called transesophageal echocardiography is an opportunity to shorten the duration of atrial fibrillation before cardioversion, a procedure used to return an irregular or very fast heartbeat to a normal rhythm.

SeqA: Methods: Transesophageal echocardiography was attempted in 539 patients (292 men, 247 women; 71.6 +/- 13.0 years.)
SeqB: Researchers aimed to find out if the shorter time period of atrial fibrillation from using transesophageal echocardiography impacts how often atrial fibrillation returns and the frequency of sinus rhythm in the first year after cardioversion.

SeqA: with atrial fibrillation > or =2 days (66.1% <3 weeks) or of unknown duration before elective cardioversion of atrial fibrillation.
SeqB: Sinus rhythm is the pattern of your heartbeat based on the sinus node of your heart which sends out electrical pulses.

SeqA: Therapeutic anticoagulation at the time of transesophageal echocardiography was present in 94.6% of patients, and 73.4% of subjects were discharged on warfarin.
SeqB: Transesophageal echocardiography is used in 539 patients who had atrial fibrillation for two or more days (more than half had atrial fibrillation for less than 3 weeks) or for an unknown duration before non-emergency cardioversion of atrial fibrillation.

SeqA: Results:
SeqB: Blood thinners at the time of the transesophageal echocardiography were used in almost all patients, and 73.4% were discharged on warfarin, a blood thinner to prevent blood clots.

SeqA: Atrial thrombi were identified in 70 (13.1%) patients.
SeqB: Heart-related blood clots were found in 70 (13.1%) patients.

SeqA: Successful cardioversion in 413 patients without evidence of atrial thrombi was associated with clinical thromboembolism in 1 patient (0.24%, 95% confidence interval: 0.0--0.8%).
SeqB: Among patients who successfully had the cardioversion procedure, 1 patient had clinical thromboembolism, a blood clot in the vein.

SeqA: In patients with atrial fibrillation <3 weeks at the time of cardioversion (a duration incompatible with conventional therapy of 3 to 4 weeks of warfarin before cardioversion), the 1-year atrial fibrillation recurrence rate was lower (41.1% vs. 57.9%, P <0.01), and the prevalence of sinus rhythm at 1 year was increased (65.8% vs. 51.3%, P <0.03).
SeqB: In the patients who had atrial fibrillation for less than 3 weeks at the time of cardioversion, the return of atrial fibrillation in the first year was lower, and the frequency of sinus rhythm at 1 year increased.

SeqA: No other clinical or echocardiographic index was associated with recurrence of atrial fibrillation or sinus rhythm at 1 year.
SeqB: No other clincal or heart evaluations are associated with returning atrial fibrillation or sinus rhythm at 1 year.

SeqA: Conclusions: Early cardioversion facilitated by transesophageal echocardiography has a favorable safety profile and provides the associated benefit of reduced recurrence of atrial fibrillation for patients in whom the duration of atrial fibrillation is <3 weeks.
SeqB: Having the cardioversion procedure earlier by using the transesophageal echocardiography is shown to be a safe method and is associated with reducing the return of atrial fibrillation in patients who have had the heart condition for less than 3 weeks.

SeqA: Circadian variation in atrial fibrillation (AF) frequency is explored in this paper by employing recent advances in signal processing.
SeqB: Circadian variation (a part of the natural, internal process that regulates the sleep??wake cycle) in atrial fibrillation (a fluttery and irregular heartbeat that can lead to blood clots or stroke) frequency is explored in this paper by using recent advances in signal processing, which monitors the heart's electrical activity.

SeqA: Once the AF frequency has been estimated and tracked by a hidden Markov model approach, the resulting trend is analyzed for the purpose of detecting and characterizing the presence of circadian variation.
SeqB: When the atrial fibrillation frequency is estimated and tracked by signal processing tools, the information is further reviewed to detect and describe the presence of circadian variation.

SeqA: With cosinor analysis, the results show that the short-term variations in the AF frequency exceed the variation that may be attributed to circadian.
SeqB: The results show that the short-term variations in the atrial fibrillation frequency are greater than the variation that may be attributed to circadian.

SeqA: Using the autocorrelation method, circadian variation was found in 13 of 18 ambulatory ECG recordings (Holter) acquired from patients with long-standing persistent AF.
SeqB: Circadian variation is found in 13 of 18 patients with long-standing and persistent (last longer than 7 days) atrial fibrillation.

SeqA: Using the ensemble correlation method, the highest AF frequency usually occurred during the afternoon, whereas the lowest usually occurred during late night.
SeqB: The highest atrial fibrillation frequency usually occurred during the afternoon, whereas the lowest usually occurred during late night.

SeqA: It is concluded that circadian variation is present in most patients with long-standing persistent AF though the short-term variation in the AF frequency is considerable and should be taken into account.
SeqB: Circadian variation is present in most patients with long-standing persistent atrial fibrillation, though the short-term variation in the AF frequency is great and should be taken into account.

SeqA: Circadian variation in atrial fibrillation (AF) frequency is explored in this paper by employing recent advances in signal processing.
SeqB: Sleep-wake changes in the frequency of atrial fibrillation (irregular or rapid heart beat) (AF) is explored by using new advances in signal processing.

SeqA: Once the AF frequency has been estimated and tracked by a hidden Markov model approach, the resulting trend is analyzed for the purpose of detecting and characterizing the presence of circadian variation.
SeqB: Once the frequency of the irregular heart beat is estimated and tracked by a mathematical technique, the result is measured to detect and characterize sleep-wake changes.

SeqA: With cosinor analysis, the results show that the short-term variations in the AF frequency exceed the variation that may be attributed to circadian.
SeqB: With mathematical analysis, the results show that short-term changes in the frequency of the irregular heart beat surpass the changes owing to sleep-wake patterns.

SeqA: Using the autocorrelation method, circadian variation was found in 13 of 18 ambulatory ECG recordings (Holter) acquired from patients with long-standing persistent AF.
SeqB: With mathematical analysis, sleep-wake changes were found in 13 of 18 ambulatory heart-beat recordings from those with long-lasting frequencies of irregular heart beats.

SeqA: Using the ensemble correlation method, the highest AF frequency usually occurred during the afternoon, whereas the lowest usually occurred during late night.
SeqB: With mathematical analysis, the highest frequency of an irregular heart beat usually came in the afternoon, while the lowest usually came at late night.

SeqA: It is concluded that circadian variation is present in most patients with long-standing persistent AF though the short-term variation in the AF frequency is considerable and should be taken into account.
SeqB: Thus, sleep-wake changes occur in most with long-lasting AF frequency.

SeqA: Background: Dronedarone is a new multichannel blocker for atrial fibrillation (AF) previously demonstrated to have both rhythm and rate control properties in paroxysmal and persistent AF.
SeqB: Dronedarone is a new drug that can treat atrial fibrillation (a fluttery and irregular heartbeat that can lead to blood clots or stroke) or AF and is found to help control the heart rhythm and heart rate in patients with paroxysmal (when the heart rate returns to normal within 7 days on its own or with treatment) or with persistent (greater than 7 days) atrial fibrillation.

SeqA: The Efficacy and safety of dRonedArone for The cOntrol of ventricular rate during atrial fibrillation (ERATO) trial assessed the efficacy of dronedarone in the control of ventricular rate in patients with permanent AF, when added to standard therapy.
SeqB: A clinical trial called the Efficacy and safety of dRonedArone for The cOntrol of ventricular rate during atrial fibrillation (ERATO) reviewed how well dronedarone worked to control the ventricular rate (heart rate) in patients with permanent AF, when added to other treatments.

SeqA: Methods: In this randomized, double-blind, multinational trial, dronedarone, 400 mg twice a day (n = 85), or matching placebo (n = 89) was administered for 6 months to adult patients with permanent AF, in addition to standard therapy.
SeqB: In this clinical trial of patients with permanent AF, 85 patients receive the dronedarone drug, and 85 receive a placebo (an inactive substance that looks like the treatment drug) for 6 months.

SeqA: The primary end point was the change in mean ventricular rate between baseline and day 14, as assessed by 24-hour Holter.
SeqB: A key measure is the average change in ventricular rate between the start of the trial and day 14 of the trial.

SeqA: Ventricular rate was also assessed during submaximal and maximal exercise.
SeqB: Ventricular rate is also evaluated during submaximal exercise (any physical activity with increased intensity in which heart rate does not go above 85) and maximal exercise (physical activity increased to come close to fatigue).

SeqA: Results:
SeqB: Dronedarone significantly decreased the average 24-hour ventricular rate.

SeqA: Dronedarone significantly decreased mean 24-hour ventricular rate.
SeqB: When compared to the placebo group, the average effect of dronedarone on day 14 was a reduction of 11.7 beats per minute.

SeqA: Compared with placebo, the mean treatment effect at day 14 was a reduction of 11.7 beats per minute (beat/min; P < .0001).
SeqB: Similar reductions continued throughout the 6-month trial.

SeqA: Comparable reductions were sustained throughout the 6-month trial.
SeqB: There was a reduction in heart beats per minute during maximal exercise when compared to the placebo group.

SeqA: During maximal exercise and compared to placebo, there was a mean reduction of 24.5 beat/min (P < .0001), without any reduction in exercise tolerance as measured by maximal exercise duration.
SeqB: The effects of dronedarone were an addition to the effects of other drugs that control heart rate.

SeqA: The effects of dronedarone were additive to those of other rate-control agents, including beta-blockers, calcium antagonists, and digoxin.
SeqB: Dronedarone was well tolerated with few side effects.

SeqA: Dronedarone was well tolerated, with no organ toxicities or proarrhythmia.
SeqB: In addition to its previously demonstrated effects on heart rhythm and rate in short-term and long-term AF, dronedarone improves ventricular rate control in patients with permanent AF.

SeqA: Conclusion:
SeqB: Dronedarone was well tolerated with no evidence of damage to organs or worsening of heart condition in this short-term study.

SeqA: Introduction:
SeqB: Sleep apnea-hypopnea syndrome (SAHS) (a sleep disorder of recurring episodes of partial or complete upper airway collapse during sleep) is one of the causes of atrial fibrillation (AF) (a fluttery and irregular heartbeat that can lead to blood clots or stroke).

SeqA: Sleep apnea-hypopnea syndrome (SAHS) is one of the extracardiac reasons of atrial fibrillation (AF), and the prevalence of AF is high in SAHS-diagnosed patients.
SeqB: The occurrence of AF is high in SAHS-diagnosed patients.

SeqA: Nocturnal hypoxemia is associated with AF, pulmonary hypertension, and nocturnal death.
SeqB: Nocturnal hypoxemia (a temporary drop in oxygen while sleeping) is associated with AF, pulmonary hypertension (high blood pressure affecting the arteries in the lungs and heart), and nocturnal death (death in sleep caused by sudden cardiac death).

SeqA: The rate of AF recurrence is high in untreated SAHS-diagnosed patients after cardioversion (CV).
SeqB: The frequency of AF recurring is high in people with untreated SAHS after cardioversion, a procedure used to return an irregular or very fast heartbeat to a normal rhythm.

SeqA: In this study, we present a patient whose SAHS was diagnosed with an apnea test performed in the intensive care unit (ICU) and who did not develop recurrent AF after the administration of standard AF treatment and bi-level positive airway pressure (BiPAP).
SeqB: This study summarizes the case of a patient with SAHS diagnosed by an apnea test (monitoring of breathing and oxygen) and who did not develop recurring (chronic) atrial fibrillation after receiving standard treatment and the bi-level positive airway pressure (BiPAP), a ventilator used to maintain a consistent breathing pattern (often used at night).

SeqA: Case presentation: A 57-year-old male hypertensive Caucasian patient who was on medical treatment for 1.5 months for non-organic AF was admitted to the ICU because of high-ventricular response AF (170 per minute), and sinus rhythm was maintained during the CV that was performed two times every second day.
SeqB: A 57-year old male patient who was on treatment for 1.5 months for AF was admitted to the hospital because of a high, irregular heart beat.

SeqA: The results of the apnea test performed in the ICU on the same night after the second CV were as follows: apnea-hypopnea index (AHI) of 71 per hour, minimum peripheral oxygen saturation (SpO2) of 67%, and desaturation period (SpO2 of less than 90%) of 28 minutes.
SeqB: The sinus rhythm (the pattern of your heartbeat based on the sinus node of your heart which sends out electrical pulses) was steady during the cardioversion procedure.

SeqA: The patient was discharged with medical treatment and nocturnal BiPAP treatment.
SeqB: Heart and oxygen tests were performed in the hospital after the second cardioversion.

SeqA: The results of the apnea test performed under BiPAP on the sixth month were as follows: AHI of 1 per hour, desaturation period of 1 minute, and minimum SpO2 of 87%.
SeqB: The patient was sent home with medical treatment and a nocturnal BiPAP.

SeqA: No recurrent AF developed in the patient, and his medical treatment was reduced within 6 months.
SeqB: No recurring atrial fibrillation developed in the patient, and his medical treatment was reduced within 6 months.

SeqA: After gastric bypass surgery on the 12th month, nocturnal hypoxia and AF did not re-occur.
SeqB: After gastric bypass surgery on the 12th month, nocturnal hypoxia and atrial fibrillation did not re-occur.

SeqA: Thus, BiPAP and medical treatments were ended.
SeqB: Because they did not recur, the BiPAP and medical treatments were ended.

SeqA: Conclusions: SAHS can be diagnosed by performing an apnea test in the ICU.
SeqB: In conclusion, SAHS can be diagnosed by performing an apnea test in the hospital.

SeqA: SAHS should be investigated in patients developing recurrent AF after CV.
SeqB: SAHS should be investigated in patients developing recurring atrial fibrillation after a cardioversion procedure.

SeqA: Recovery of nocturnal hypoxia may increase the success rate of standard AF treatment.
SeqB: Recovery of nocturnal hypoxia may increase the success of standard atrial fibrillation treatment.

SeqA: Background: Sleep-disordered breathing (SDB) and atrial fibrillation (AF) are associated.

SeqB: At six months there was no change in AHI, sleepiness during the day, sleep time, rapid eye movement (REM) sleep, and other tests that measure sleep and breathing patterns.

SeqB: AHI fell from 29.8 ?? 26.6/h to 22.2 ?? 20.4/h. In conclusion, sleep-disordered breathing is very common in patients with persistent atrial fibrillation.

SeqA: Obstructive sleep apnea syndrome (OSA) is associated with different types of cardiac arrhythmias.

SeqA: The original studies, concentrated mostly on nocturnal brady- and tachyarrhythmias.

SeqA: Background: Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (AF) can be caused by gain-of-function mutations in genes, encoding the cardiac potassium channel subunits KCNJ2, KCNE1, and KCNH2 that mediate the repolarizing potassium currents Ik1, Iks, and Ikr, respectively.
SeqB: Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (AF) (an irregular heart rate that returns to normal within 7 days on its own or with treatment) can be caused by mutations in genes.

SeqA: Methods: Linkage analysis, whole-exome sequencing, and Xenopus oocyte electrophysiology studies were used in this study.
SeqB: Genetic linkage analysis to trace diseases in families using genes, whole-exome sequencing to find a genetic cause of a disease, and models to study biological processes of cells were used in this study.

SeqA: Results: Through genetic studies, we showed that autosomal dominant early-onset nocturnal paroxysmal AF is caused by p.S447R mutation in KCND2, encoding the pore-forming (??) subunit of the Kv4.2 cardiac potassium channel.
SeqB: Through these genetic studies, researchers show that one genetic trait or mutation that is passed down from parent to child causing nighttime paroxysmal atrial fibrillation is caused by a mutation in the KCND2 gene.

SeqA: Kv4.2, along with Kv4.3, contributes to the cardiac fast transient outward K+ current, Ito.
SeqB: Kv4.2 and Kv4.3 are potassium channels that release potassium from cells and contribute to the heart-related, temporary, fast, outward potassium (K+) current, Ito.

SeqA: Ito underlies the early phase of repolarization in the cardiac action potential, thereby setting the initial potential of the plateau phase and governing its duration and amplitude.
SeqB: Ito is the base of the early phase of repolarization (when the outward current of ions exceeds the inward current) in the cardiac action potental (where unique properties necessary for function of the electrical conduction system of the heart occur), and creates the initial potential of the plateau phase (the time that allows for longer muscle contraction and allows the heart to contract in a steady, uniform, and forceful manner).

SeqA: In Xenopus oocytes, the mutation increased the channel's inactivation time constant and affected its regulation: p.
SeqB: In studies that modeled the cell's biology, the mutation increased the potassium channel's inactivation time (the time when the channel no longer allows potassium to be passed through it) and affected its regulation.

SeqA: S447 resides in a protein kinase C (PKC) phosphorylation site, which normally allows attenuation of Kv4.2 membrane expression.
SeqB: The mutant Kv4.2 showed an impaired response to protein kinase C (PKC), a protein that regulates cells growth and plays a major role in sending signals to the heart.

SeqA: The mutant Kv4.2 exhibited impaired response to PKC; hence, Kv4.2 membrane expression was augmented, enhancing potassium currents.
SeqB: The gene mutation alters Kv4.2's transfer properties, impairs its regulation process, and exerts gain-of-function effect (changes the activity or function of a protein) in both Kv4.2 and Kv4.2-Kv4.3 potassium channels.

SeqA: Coexpression of mutant and wild-type channels (recapitulating heterozygosity in affected individuals) showed results similar to the mutant channel alone.
SeqB: These effects possibly increase the repolarizing potassium current Ito, creating arrhythmogenic substrates (factors that can produce or lead to arrhythmia) for nocturnal atrial fibrillation (an irregular and often very rapid heart rhythm occuring at night that can lead to blood clots in the heart).

SeqA: Finally, in a hybrid channel composed of Kv4.3 and Kv4.2, simulating the mature endogenous heterotetrameric channel underlying Ito, the p.S447R
SeqB: Kv4.2 expression has previously been shown to demonstrate circadian variation (the natural, internal process that regulates the sleep??wake cycle and repeats roughly every 24 hours), with peak expression at daytime, with possible relevance to the nighttime onset of symptoms of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (an irregular heart rate that returns to normal within 7 days on its own or with treatment) in patients.

SeqA: Kv4.2 mutation exerted a gain-of-function effect on Kv4.3.
SeqB: Targeting Kv4.2 might be effective in the treatment of nocturnal paroxysmal atrial fibrillation.

SeqA: In the treatment of arrhythmia, beta-blockers are mainly used to regulate the heart rate.
SeqB: In the treatment of arrhythmia (an irregular heartbeat), beta-blockers (medications that reduce blood pressure) are mainly used to regulate the heart rate.

SeqA: However, beta-blockers are also known as drugs with an antiarrhythmic effect due to the suppression of sympathetic activity.
SeqB: However, beta-blockers are also known as drugs with an antiarrhythmic effect (drugs that slow down the electrical impulses of the heart) due to the suppression of sympathetic activity (the part of the nervous system that increases heart rate, blood pressure, and other heart functions).

SeqA: We evaluated the antiarrhythmic effects of a highly selective beta(1)-blocker, bisoprolol, in patients with diurnal paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (P-AF).
SeqB: Researchers evaluated how electrical impulses of the heart are slowed down when using a beta-blocker called bisoprolol in patients with diurnal (during the day) paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (an irregular heart rate that returns to normal within 7 days on its own or with treatment).

SeqA: A total of 136 patients with symptomatic diurnal P-AF were enrolled.
SeqB: A total of 136 patients with symptomatic daytime paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (P-AF) were included in the study.

SeqA: Patients were divided into a diurnal-specific P-AF group and a diurnal & nocturnal P-AF group, as well as into a bisoprolol single use group and a combined use group with an antiarrhythmic drug.
SeqB: Patients were divided into a daytime P-AF or a daytime and nighttime P-AF group, as well as into a group that only uses bisoproplol and a group that uses a combination of heart treatment drugs.

SeqA: The effects of bisoprolol were evaluated in 3 categories: subjective symptom improvement, quality of life (QOL) improvement, and elimination of P-AF episode in Holter electrocardiograms (ECGs).
SeqB: The effects of bisoprolol are evaluated in 3 categories: symptom improvement, quality of life improvement, and elimination of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (P-AF) events, which are measured using a portable device called Holter electrocardiograms (ECGs) to record heart rhythms.

SeqA: For patients with effective treatment, a long-term effect up to 24 months was evaluated.
SeqB: For patients with effective treatment, a long-term effect up to 24 months was evaluated.

SeqA: Five patients (3.7%) discontinued bisoprolol due to side effects.
SeqB: Five patients stopped using bisoprolol due to side effects.

SeqA: Following administration of bisoprolol, 109 patients (80%) experienced subjective symptom improvement, 103 patients (76%) experienced QOL improvement, and elimination of P-AF episodes in ECGs was observed in 84 patients (62%).
SeqB: Following use of bisoprolol, 80% experienced symptom improvement, 76% experienced quality of life improvement, and elimination of P-AF episodes in ECGs was observed in 62%.

SeqA: The elimination rate of P-AF episodes in ECGs was higher in the diurnal P-AF group than in the diurnal & nocturnal P-AF group (P=0.042).
SeqB: The elimination rate of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation episodes in ECGs was higher in the daytime group than in the daytime and nighttime group.

SeqA: There was no significant difference between the bisoprolol single use group and the combined use group.
SeqB: There was no significant difference between the group that only used bisoprolol and the combined use group.

SeqA: A long-term suppressive effect by bisoprolol was observed in 70 of 83 patients (84%).
SeqB: A long-term effect of reducing P-AF using bisoprolol was found in 84% of patients.

SeqA: The results demonstrate that bisoprolol has an antiarrhythmic effect against sympathetic diurnal P-AF, improving subjective symptoms and QOL and eliminating P-AF episodes in ECGs.
SeqB: This study shows that bisoprolol can slow down the electrical impulses of the heart in daytime paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, improve symptoms and quality of life, and eliminate paroxysmal atrial fibrillation episodes in ECGs.

SeqA: In the treatment of arrhythmia, beta-blockers are mainly used to regulate the heart rate.

SeqA: However, beta-blockers are also known as drugs with an antiarrhythmic effect due to the suppression of sympathetic activity.
SeqB: However, beta-blockers also prevent irregular heart beats due to the reduction of nerve-related, stimulating activity.

SeqA: 180 cases of head trauma were classified according to the degree of impairment of consciousness, clinical and neurological symptoms and EEG patterns.
SeqB: We divided 180 cases of head injury based on the level of loss of wakefulness and awareness, medical and brain-related symptoms observed by a doctor, and a common brain function test.

SeqA: Based on the radiological and clinical findings and blood gas analyses a study was made of the incidence and extent of aspiration of blood, vomit or debris into the tracheo-bronchial tree and of the resultant pulmonary complications.
SeqB: Based on x-rays, symptoms observed by a doctor, and blood gas tests, we studied how often and how much blood, vomit or debris entered the airways and the lung complications that occurred as a result.

SeqA: As loss of consciousness became more complete the incidence of aspiration and the amount of material inhaled increased.
SeqB: As consciousness went away, how often material entered the airways and the amount of material breathed in increased.

SeqA: Clinically and radiologically proven aspiration occurred in 60 per cent of cases of severe head trauma.
SeqB: Material entering the airways happened in 60 percent of cases of severe head injury based on symptoms observed by a doctor and x-rays.

SeqA: A comparison of two groups after they had been given first aid and artificial respiration showed that the paO2 values were significantly lower in patients with radiologically proven aspiration and infiltration of the lungs than they were in those with normal chest radiograms.
SeqB: A comparison of two groups after they received first aid and artificial aid to breathe showed that the levels of oxygen dissolved in the blood were much lower in patients with x-rays that showed material entered the airways and the lungs than those with normal chest x-rays.

SeqA: These observations point to the relationship between the quantity of material inhaled and the extent of intra-pulmonary shunting.
SeqB: These findings suggest a relationship between the amount of material breathed in and how much blood put out by the heart lacks enough oxygen.

SeqA: There was no difference in the incidence of aspiration between persons who had been intubated and those who had not been intubated prior to admission to hospital.
SeqB: Persons who had a breathing tube and those who did not before admission to the hospital did not differ in how often material entered the airways.

SeqA: Although in many cases of head trauma aspiration of blood immediately after the accident can not be prevented prompt intubation is the only measure that will mitigate the consequences of aspiration and prevent its recurrence.
SeqB: Although often in head injuries blood entering the airways after the accident cannot be prevented quickly, putting in a breathing tube is the only thing that will lessen the consequences of material entering the airways and prevent it from happening again.

SeqA: As the latter is a very real risk in the unconscious person intubation in these cases is a "must".
SeqB: As the second result is a very real risk in the unconscious person, putting in a breathing tube in these cases is a "must".

SeqA: The study also showed that aspiration of foreign material into the tracheobronchial system and the resultant pulmonary complications can be successfully treated even if the head trauma is very severe.
SeqB: The study also showed that material from outside the body entering the airways and the lung complications that occurred as a result can be successfully treated even if the head injury is very severe.

SeqA: In none of the cases studied was death attributable to these causes.
SeqB: In the cases we looked at, death did not result from any of these causes.

SeqA: Apart from intubation and bronchial toilet artificial respiration with oxygen-enriched gas mixtures has a decisive influence on the course of the aspiration-induced pulmonary complications.
SeqB: Aside from putting in a breathing tube and clearing mucus and secretions from the airways, substituting a person's breathing with gas mixtures with high levels of oxygen plays a big role in lung complications from material entering the airways.

SeqA: The patient who presents with a serious head injury is often very difficult to manage.

SeqA: As the pCO2 level decreases, vasoconstriction occurs.
SeqB: As the amount of carbon dioxide gas dissolved in the blood decreases, blood vessels narrow.

SeqA: If the level falls too low, cerebral perfusion is restricted, and profound cerebral anoxia may ensue.
SeqB: If the amount of carbon dioxide gas dissolved in the blood gets too low, blood flow to the brain is limited, and not enough oxygen getting to the brain may follow.

SeqA: Current standards call for a ventilatory rate to allow for moderate respiratory alkalosis, in theory to mildly constrict teh vessels but still provide adequate perfusion.
SeqB: Current standards suggest a rate of movement of air into and out of the lungs to allow for a decrease in carbon dioxide gas dissolved in the blood, in theory to narrow the vessels but still allow enough circulation of blood through organs and tissues.

SeqA: Remember that the anatomy of the meningeal layers places the arteries primarily in the epidural space and the veins in the subdural space.

SeqA: A bleed in the epidural space often presents with a rapid onset of signs and symptoms, as was obvious in this traumatized patient.

SeqA: When a bleed occurs in the subdural space, the onset is usually more insidious, and an accurate history is a key to field diagnosis.

SeqA: As the hemorrhage expands, compression displaces the brain within the cranial vault.
SeqB: As the bleeding spreads, pressure pushing on the brain moves the brain within the skull.

SeqA: This displacement causes pressure to be exerted on the medulla of the brainstem.
SeqB: This movement of the brain puts pressure on the area of the brain that controls things like heartbeat and breathing (medulla).

SeqA: Cushing's Traid is a result of this pressure on the medulla and is evidence by the pulse slowing while systolic blood pressure rises and respirations become ataxic.
SeqB: Pressure on the medulla causes Cushing's Triad, which is a slowing heartbeat while blood pressure increases and breathing becomes abnormal.

SeqA: Vomiting is often associated, and as the bleed continues, herniation syndrome begins.

SeqA: Decorticate posturing is displayed, followed by decerebrate posturing if relief is not provided.

SeqA: It is important to distinguish between decorticate and decerebrate posturing.

SeqA: Any solid object can work as a foreign body and cause an airway obstruction--mechanical obstruction.
