SeqA: The BNT162b2 vaccine is highly effective against COVID-19 infection and was delivered with a 3-week time interval in registration studies 1.
SeqB: The BNT162b2 vaccine (Pfizer) is highly effective against COVID-19 infection.

SeqB: It is not known how antibody responses or cellular immune responses are influenced by delaying the second dose.

SeqA: This enhanced antibody response may offer a longer period of clinical protection and delay the need for booster vaccination.

SeqA: Introduction: Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) vaccines are nothing short of a miracle story halting the pandemic across the globe.

SeqB: Nearly half of the global population has received at least one dose.

SeqA: Nevertheless, antibody levels in vaccinated people have shown waning, and breakthrough infections have occurred.
SeqB: Nevertheless, antibody blood levels in vaccinated people drop over time, and breakthrough infections have occurred.

SeqA: Our study aims to measure antibody kinetics following AZD1222 (ChAdOx1) vaccination six months after the second dose and the factors affecting the kinetics.

SeqA: Results:
SeqB: We used statistical methods to measure the change in antibody blood levels over time.

SeqA: Our study included 122 participants (mean age, 41.5 years; 66 men, 56 women).
SeqB: Our study included 122 participants (mean age, 41.5 years; 66 men, 56 women).

SeqA: The geometric mean IgG titers were 138.01 binding antibody units (BAU)/mL in Round 1, 176.48 BAU/mL in Round 2, and 112.95 BAU/mL in Round 3.

SeqA: Seven participants showed seroreversion, and 11 had breakthrough infections.
SeqB: Seven participants showed a complete loss of measurable blood antibodies, and 11 had breakthrough infections.

SeqA: Eighty-six participants showed a substantial decline in antibody titer from Rounds 2 to 3.
SeqB: Eighty-six participants showed a substantial decline in antibody levels from Rounds 2 to 3.

SeqA: Persons aged 45 or older had higher mean titer than people aged younger than 45 years.
SeqB: Persons aged 45 or older had higher antibody levels than people aged younger than 45 years.

SeqA: Overweight and obese (BMI ?????? 25 kg/m2) had a higher mean titer than average or underweight persons.
SeqB: Overweight and obese people (body mass index larger than 25) had higher antibody levels than average or underweight persons.

SeqA: The only significant predictor of IgG titers at six months was SARS-CoV-2 infection on mixed model analysis.
SeqB: The only people who maintained high levels of antibodies at 6 months were in people who had been infected with SARS-CoV2.

SeqA: Conclusion: We found a substantial decline in antibody levels leading to seven cases of seroreversion in healthcare professionals who received the ChAdOx1 vaccine.
SeqB: We found a substantial decline in antibody levels leading to seven cases of loss of antibodies in healthcare professionals who received the ChAdOx1 vaccine.

SeqA: History of prior COVID-19 was the only significant factor in antibody levels at six months.
SeqB: A history of prior COVID-19 infection was the only significant reason for high antibody levels at six months.

SeqA: The timing of the development of specific adaptive immunity after natural SARS-CoV-2 infection, and its relevance in clinical outcome, has not been characterized in depth.

SeqA: Upon natural infection, cellular and humoral responses were early and coordinated in mild patients, while weak and inconsistent in severe patients.

SeqA: Nephrotic syndrome (NS) is one of the most common glomerular diseases that affect children.
SeqB: Nephrotic Syndrome (NS) is one of the most common kidney diseases in children.

SeqA: Renal histology reveals the presence of minimal change nephrotic syndrome (MCNS) in more than 80% of these patients.

SeqA: Most patients with MCNS have favorable outcomes without complications.
SeqB: Most people with MCNS can be cured without other issues.

SeqA: However, a few of these children have lesions of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis, suffer from severe and prolonged proteinuria, and are at high risk for complications.
SeqB: However, some children with NS have a different form called focal segmental glomerulosclerosis.

SeqA: Complications of NS are divided into two categories: disease-associated and drug-related complications.
SeqB: Children with this form have excess protein in their urine for long periods of time and are at high risk for additional problems.

SeqA: Disease-associated complications include infections (e.g., peritonitis, sepsis, cellulitis, and chicken pox), thromboembolism (e.g., venous thromboembolism and pulmonary embolism), hypovolemic crisis (e.g., abdominal pain, tachycardia, and hypotension), cardiovascular problems (e.g., hyperlipidemia), acute renal failure, anemia, and others (e.g., hypothyroidism, hypocalcemia, bone disease, and intussusception).
SeqB: Additional problems caused by NS come in two categories: problems caused by the disease, and problems caused by drugs used to treat the disease.

SeqA: The main pathomechanism of disease-associated complications originates from the large loss of plasma proteins in the urine of nephrotic children.
SeqB: Problems caused by the disease include infections, blood clots, shock, heart disease, kidney failure, anemia, and others.

SeqA: The majority of children with MCNS who respond to treatment with corticosteroids or cytotoxic agents have smaller and milder complications than those with steroid-resistant NS.
SeqB: The main way NS causes problems is from the large loss of proteins from the blood through urine.

SeqA: Corticosteroids, alkylating agents, cyclosporin A, and mycophenolate mofetil have often been used to treat NS, and these drugs have treatment-related complications.
SeqB: Most children with MCNS that is treatable with drugs have fewer additional problems that children with NS that drugs cannot help.

SeqA: Early detection and appropriate treatment of these complications will improve outcomes for patients with NS.
SeqB: Several drugs have been used to treat NS.

SeqA: Serious complications developed in eight (14.8 %) patients, i.e., two (3.7 %)
SeqB: The disease came back in 7% of patients with MN and 47% of patients with MCNS.

SeqA: Conclusion: Renal biopsy is a valuable diagnostic tool for elderly Japanese NS patients.
SeqB: For example, two of them died, four were hospitalized for infections, and two developed malignant tumors.

SeqA: patients reached remission without immunosuppressive treatment.

SeqA: One or more relapses were observed in 57 (54%) patients who received initial corticosteroid treatment.

SeqA: At the last follow-up, 113 (90%)
SeqB: Nine percent of patients had blood clots.

SeqB: Among these diseases, we compared how often proteinuria (too much protein in the urine) was cured and came back.

SeqA: MCD was significantly associated with hospitalization for infection than MN.

SeqA: Nephrotic syndrome (NS) encompasses a variety of disease processes leading to heavy proteinuria and edema.
SeqB: Nephrotic syndrome (NS) includes a variety of underlying diseases that lead to serious proteinuria (too much protein in the blood) and edema (fluid buildup).

SeqB: Minimal change disease (MCD) is still the most common cause of NS, and is the most responsive to treatment with drugs, often with little or no chronic kidney disease.

SeqA: Other causes of NS include focal segmental glomerulosclerosis, which follows MCD, and secondary causes, including extrarenal or systemic diseases, infections, and drugs.
SeqB: Other causes of NS include focal segmental glomerulosclerosis, which follows MCD, and secondary causes, including diseases outside the kidneys, infections, and drugs.

SeqA: Although initial diagnosis relies on clinical findings as well as urine and blood chemistries, renal biopsy and genetic testing are important diagnostic tools, especially when considering non-MCD NS.
SeqB: The initial diagnosis relies on signs and symptoms observed by a doctor.

SeqA: Moreover, biomarkers in urine and serum have become important areas for research in this disease.

SeqA: NS progression and prognosis are variable and depend on etiology, with corticosteroids being the mainstay of treatment.
SeqB: This is especially true for NS not caused by MCD.

SeqA: Other alternative therapies found to be successful in inducing and maintaining remission include calcineurin inhibitors and rituximab.
SeqB: Additionally, signs of disease in blood and urine have become important areas for research in this disease.

SeqA: Disease course can range from recurrent disease relapse with or without acute kidney injury to end-stage renal disease in some cases.

SeqA: Given the complex pathogenesis of NS, which remains incompletely understood, complications are numerous and diverse and include infections, electrolyte abnormalities, acute kidney injury, and thrombosis.
SeqB: Corticosteroids are the main treatment.

SeqA: Pediatricians must be aware of the presentation, complications, and overall long-term implications of NS and its treatment.

SeqB: To figure out what puts children more at risk for serious kidney damage, we followed up with children who had this problem during the first two weeks of hospitalization.

SeqA: patients were male.

SeqA: Of the 54 patients hospitalized, 42 (77.8%) were admitted with infection-associated relapses while 22.2% of children had relapse alone.

SeqA: Twenty-three (42.6%) children developed AKI according to the KDIGO definition and 27 (50%) using the pRIFLE classification.

SeqB: Within 10 years, the risk of a blood clot in an artery was 14%, the risk of a blood clot in a vein was 8%, and the risk of bleeding was 17%.

SeqA: [3.40-4.75]) compared with the general population comparators after adjusting for confounders.

SeqA: Conclusion: Adults with nephrotic syndrome have a high risk of arterial thromboembolism, venous thromboembolism, and bleeding compared with the general population.

SeqA: Background: Steroid resistant nephrotic syndrome (SRNS), while uncommon in children, is associated with significant morbidity.
SeqB: Steroid Resistant Nephrotic Syndrome (SRNS) is a group of kidney-related symptoms that cannot be treated with steroids.

SeqA: Calcineurin inhibitors (CNIs) remain the first line recommended therapy for children with non-genetic forms of SRNS, but some children fail to respond to them.
SeqB: Though it is not common in children, it is associated with many serious health problems.

SeqA: Intravenous (IV) cyclophosphamide (CTX) has been shown to be effective in Asian-Indian children with difficult to treat SRNS (SRNS-DTT).
SeqB: Immune system suppressing drugs called Calcineurin Inhibitors (CNIs) are the preferred treatment for children with SRNS that is not inherited.

SeqA: Our study evaluated the outcome of IV CTX treatment in North American children with SRNS-DTT.

SeqA: Methods: Retrospective review of the medical records of children with SRNS-DTT treated with IV CTX from January 2000 to July 2019 at our center.
SeqB: Another drug called Cyclophosphamide (CTX), given by IV, has been shown to be effective in Asian-Indian children with SRNS that is difficult to treat (SRNS-DTT).

SeqA: Data abstracted included demographics, histopathology on renal biopsy, prior and concomitant use of other immunosuppressive agents and serial clinical/laboratory data.
SeqB: Our study looked at the outcome of IV CTX treatment in North American children with this disease.

SeqA: Primary outcome measure was attainment of complete remission (CR).
SeqB: The study was a review of previous medical records of children with SRNS-DTT treated with IV CTX from January 2000 to July 2019 at our center.

SeqA: Results: Eight children with SRNS-DTT received monthly doses (median 6; range 4-6) of IV CTX.
SeqB: From these records, we looked at demographics, kidney tissue samples, and the use of drugs to suppress the immune system.

SeqA: Four (50%) went into CR, 1 achieved partial remission and 3 did not respond.
SeqB: We also looked at notes from office visits and lab results recorded over time.

SeqA: Three of the 4 responders had minimal change disease (MCD).
SeqB: The main outcome that we measured was complete reversal of the disease.

SeqA: Excluding the 1 child who responded after the 4th infusion, the median time to CR was 6.5 (range 0.5-8) months after completion of IV CTX infusions.
SeqB: We found that 8 children with SRNS-DTT were given monthly doses of IV CTX.

SeqA: Three remain in CR at a median of 8.5 years (range: 3.7-10.5 years) after completion of CTX; one child relapsed and became steroid-dependent.
SeqB: Four were completely cured, one was partially cured, and three did not respond to the treatment.

SeqA: No infections or life-threatening complications related to IV CTX were observed.
SeqB: Three of the four patients that were cured had a particular type of SRNS that was caused by Minimal Change Disease (MCD).

SeqA: Conclusions: IV CXT can induce long term remission in North-American children with MCD who have SRNS-DTT.
SeqB: Except for the one child who responded to treatment after the 4th dose, the average time to reverse the disease was about six and a half months after completing all the IV CTX doses.

SeqA: Chylothorax is an uncommon and serious clinical condition, typically induced by trauma, either postsurgical or accidental injury, but the mechanism of chylothorax caused by nephrotic syndrome is still unclear.
SeqB: Chylothorax is an uncommon and serious medical condition where fluid from the lymphatic system builds up around the lungs.

SeqA: Here, we report a case of primary nephrotic syndrome with membranous nephropathy (MN) in a 66-year-old man who presented with severe chylothorax.

SeqB: However, we don??t know how a cluster of kidney-related symptoms called Nephrotic Syndrome (NS) causes chylothorax.

SeqA: After treatment, the patient's pleural effusion decreased, and the chyle gradually became clear.
SeqB: In this article we describe a case of NS with a kidney disease called Membranous Nephropathy (MN) in a 66 year old man with severe chylothorax.

SeqA: We discuss the causes of MN with chylothorax.

SeqA: We considered that the hypoproteinemia changed the permeability of mucous membranes and lymphatic vessels, leading to leakage of chylous particles and chylous pleural effusion formation.

SeqA: Chylothorax may also have been caused by severe tissue edema, edema of the lymphatic walls, and increased pressure, resulting in increased permeability or rupture of the lymphatic wall, and leakage of chylous fluid into the thoracic cavity.

SeqB: We thought that maybe too little protein in the blood allowed fluid from the lymphatic system to leak through tissues and cause the buildup around the lungs.
